column21: The Rolex Daytona, named after the race circuit in Florida that hosts the Rolex twenty-four hour race, epitomises the ultimate driver’s watch. The dial, unburdened by a date window, is clear and easy to read. The tachymeter offers quick speed calculations, while the shape is instantly recognisable and supremely comfortable. Its smaller size and smart design makes it a versatile watch capable of working well with both casual jeans and a formal suit. Here available in steel with a stunning Cerachrom bezel, this watch represents the Daytona's first major upgrade in 16 years, but it sticks closely to the gorgeous retro design of the original.

The Audemars Piguet Royal Oak Offshore, first introduced in 1993 and designed by Emmanuel Gueit, takes the bold nature of the Royal Oak to the next level. It's the brand's sportiest collection, featuring large case sizes and striking or exaggerated designs. Often described as “larger-than-life”, the Offshore is visually impressive, with dramatic design cues that exaggerate and heighten those of its predecessor. The watch develops ideas from the original Royal Oak, pioneered by the legendary Gerald Genta in 1972. This is a remarkable example of one of the most iconic collections from an ultra-prestigious Swiss brand.

Patrouille Suisse is the acclaimed aerobatics team of the Swiss Air Force. Flying since 1964, the team was known for its Hawker Hunter aircraft until the 1990s, when it switched to the Northrop F-5Es that it currently uses. There are many partnerships between aerobatics teams and watch companies, but perhaps none more perfect than this of Patrouille Suisse and Breitling, the Swiss watchmaking giant known for its prestigious history of pilots watches. This piece is indeed a limited edition Chronomat, sharing a name with one of the earliest and most influential Breitling watches in the second half of the 20th century. Featuring a special patch in the 9 o'clock subdial, and using a superb Swiss movement with an automatic chronograph and a second time zone, this watch celebrates Patrouille Suisse's 50th anniversary.

Created by Gerald Genta and like many of his famous watches, the Nautilus is a horological legend. Patek Philippe's most well known and desirable sports watch, it's celebrated for some of the best examples of emblematic Genta trademarks: large, angular bezel, comparatively thin case, integrated bracelet and bold, if straightforward, dial. The design is based on the traditional shape of portholes, up to and including the hinges often found on the sides—hence the Nautilus' unmistakable 'ears'. This model brings extra appeal in the form of a stunning movement with several additional complications: a small seconds, a power reserve indicator, and most impressively, a combined date and moonphase display.

This watch is not just a classic Submariner—one of the most popular and iconic watches in the world—but a striking and highly collectible variant edition. The watch is easily recognisable thanks to its rare green bezel and dial, causing collectors to give it the affectionate nickname “Hulk”, although LV itself stands for Lunette Vert (“Green Bezel”). This larger version updates the previous LV model ref 16610 (called “Kermit”) that was originally introduced in 2003 for the 50th anniversary of the Submariner. This edition boasts ceramic inserts in the bezel, with numerals in platinum.

The Royal Oak is one of the most iconic watches in history – a product of the same genius designer, Gerald Genta, who was responsible for the likes of Patek Philippe's Nautilus and IWC's Ingenieur. The story is a dramatic one – Audemars Piguet had been lingering on the edge of collapse since the Depression, but the unprecedentedly bold lines, steel case and luxury pricing turned Genta's creation into an enormous success that saved the prestigious company. The Offshore collection, meanwhile, was designed by Emmanuel Gueit in 1993, and represents the next step in the evolution of the brand's signature creation. While sticking to the classic elements of the original Royal Oak, the Offshore takes its bold nature even further.

The Speedmaster is so closely associated with NASA and the Moon landings these days that it's easy to forget that when it was first released in the 1950s, it was not remotely intended for space travel. Rather, as the name suggests, the Speedy was designed as a sports watch for timing things like motor racing. Certain models, both vintage and modern, have re-established that link somewhat, including a number of “racing” editions with checkered patterns on the dials resembling finish flags. This wonderful example made a big splash at Baselworld 2013 and has been nicknamed “Tintin”, because of its red and white pattern, directly inspired by the spaceship used by the comic book hero to go to the Moon.

The Alinghi team, under the colours of the Swiss yacht club, made history in 2003 when it challenged for and won the ultra-prestigious America's Cup in Aukland (a.k.a. “City of Sails”) on its first attempt. Audemars Piguet, which had sponsored the previous Swiss team Be Happy, also got behind Alinghi, releasing a number of very special limited edition watches, including this marvellous and highly collectible Royal Oak, in honour of the event. The piece also commemorates the 30th anniversary of the legendary Royal Oak itself, one of the most celebrated watch designs to emerge in the second half of the 20th century.

This masterful Luminor 1950 from Panerai features a “double” or “split seconds” chronograph (also known as a rattrapante), one of high-end watchmaking's most challenging mechanical complications to manufacture. Where a regular chronograph simply records time elapsed between pushing the start and stop buttons, a split seconds chrono allows you to time laps or intermediate intervals. There are in fact two seconds hands, one of them ingeniously hidden; an extra pusher at 8 o'clock stops the first hand, recording the initial time, while the other hand continues to run. The PAM 213 uses the OP XVIII movement, based on a stunning and unusual column wheel Valjoux 7750.

Having a date indicator on a watch is taken for granted these days, but before 1945, the concept didn't exist at all—that is until Rolex added a simple, yet game-changing element to their famous Oyster watch: the date window. This small aperture changed the role of wristwatches from then on, from mere timekeeping devices to calendars as well. The Datejust was (and is) also known for its classic elegance—the watch is striking in its magnificent, minimalist beauty. Many of these timepieces feature dials or cases made with rare and exquisite materials, which only adds to their graceful and luxurious reputation. In 2009 the look was slightly adjusted and modernised with the Datejust II—the main difference being the change in case size from 36 to 41mm.

Due to age, this Rolex may not fall within our typical expected tolerances for timekeeping, and is no longer suitable for use in wet environments or submersion in water. Originally an ancient fortress in Spain, Calatrava was the site of key medieval battles between Christian and Muslim forces and the foundation of the noble brotherhood of religious knights, the Order of Calatrava. The emblem of these knights was to be adopted many centuries later by perhaps Switzerland's most prestigious and revered watchmaker of all time, Patek Philippe, as the brand logo. And its flagship watch collection was bestowed the name Calatrava in honour of this historical connection. Calatrava watches are among the most elegant and distinguished in the world, displaying a flawless, understated stylishness rooted in the finest Swiss traditions, combined with the avant-guard aesthetic in vogue at the time of the first Calatravas in the early 1930s.

This Rolex Daytona Cosmograph was designed to meet the needs of professional racing drivers upon its original release in 1963, with a reliable chronograph and bezel with tachymetric scale, allowing drivers to measure average speeds of up to 400 MPH. The name nods to Daytona, Florida—the home of a strong passion for speed and motor racing that emerged in the early 20th century. The relationship between Rolex and motor racing strengthened in 2013 when the watchmaker decided to enter the world of Formula 1, as Global Partner and Official Timepiece of the exhilarating sport. The 116520 introduced the in-house calibre 4130, a replacement to the Zenith-sourced 4030 in the previous 16520 and has become one of the most popular sports models ever created.

In watch form, the Carrera has been in existence since 1964, when it continued Heuer’s great legacy in providing racing drivers with high quality timing instruments. Named after the intense ‘Carrera Panamericana’ road race of the 1950s (which also gave its name to the eponymous Porsche), the Carrera continues to provide timing for some of the world’s most prestigious racing teams today. This addition to the Carrera fold fully embodies that racing heritage while daring to forge its own path.

Born as the amalgamation of incredible new technologies developed by Rolex, COMEX (the French deep-sea diving company) and the US Navy during the late 60s, the Sea-Dweller is Rolex's ultra-durable dive computer. In production for more than four decades, the 16600 model featured such pioneering technology as a helium escape valve and a 1,220m water resistance, and received a major upgrade in the form of the 116660 Deepsea model seen here. With a three-piece “Ringlock” case, “Triplock” crown system and 5mm sapphire crystal, this watch can survive pressures that would flatten a submarine. Its water resistance rating is an incredible 3,900m—deeper than the average depth of the ocean.

The GMT Master was first commissioned in the 1950s by pioneering airline Pan Am, and was designed for aviation. An increase in flight distances created demand for a watch that was able to tell the time in two different parts of the world simultaneously, so Rolex built it with an additional hand that could be set to a second time zone. By the 1980s, the watch had developed into the GMT Master II and was already a favourite among collectors.

Like many of its iconic watch families, Rolex's Milgauss was created in 1956 with a specific market in mind: scientists, power station workers and anyone else exposed to high magnetic fields. It was designed to be able to resist fields up to 1,000 gauss (hence the name—“mille” is Latin for thousand). The watch built a solid reputation with only two models until 1988, and was happily revived two decades later in a modern re-edition that remains faithful to the original purpose and aesthetics—including the beloved lightning bolt hand. This gorgeous GV version (Glace Verte) has a green-tinted dial crystal, and uses a Parachrom-Blu hairspring for even better magnetic and shock resistance.

The GMT Master was first commissioned in the 1950s by pioneering airline Pan Am, and was designed for aviation. An increase in flight distances created demand for a watch that was able to tell the time in two different parts of the world simultaneously, so Rolex built it with an additional hand that could be set to a second time zone. By the 1980s, the watch had developed into the GMT Master II and was already a favourite among collectors. This model represents a significant upgrade for the watch, boasting an aerospace-grade steel case and cerachrom inserts in the bezel. A variant on the regular 116710, this reference features gold elements in the bezel, crown, hands, indices and of course the bracelet.

The Air King was named in honour of the brave RAF pilots of WWII, when Hans Wilsdorf, founder of Rolex, discovered they were ditching their standard issue watches for his Oyster Perpetual. As one of its longest continuously manufactured and most affordable watches, the Air King is a beloved staple of Rolex's range. At Baselworld 2016, the brand released this superbly updated model. It refreshes the classic look, upgrading size, durability and calibre precision while staying true to its aviation heritage in such key elements as the iconic 1950s Air-King font. Many believe that the dial design is inspired by the custom dashboard timepieces Rolex supplied to the Bloodhound SSC land speed record attempt.

The Ballon Bleu, one of Cartier's newest watch collections, has been hugely successful since its 2007 release. With a unique, curving, organic case, a cleverly integrated sapphire crown and a multi-facetted guilloché dial, the watch can rightly be called a gem in every sense, blending the best of classical elegance and futuristic originality. Creating beauty through simplicity, the watch showcases everything that makes Cartier such a prestigious and highly-sought brand. This model uses a superb Swiss automatic movement underneath the traditional Roman numerals and blue sword hands on the dial. It's a timepiece that has to been seen in the flesh to get the full effect.

column21: Invented in the 1930s as one of the first wristwatches made to be as precise as a marine chronometer, the Portuguese collection has a long history, though it wasn't produced in serious numbers until the 1990s. Today they are among IWC's finest watches, beloved by collectors for their graceful, uncluttered design and classic aesthetic featuring thin bezels and sword-like hands. This exquisite model runs on an automatic movement, IWC calibre 79240, with a superb chronograph mechanism. Adding a dash of sporting appeal to this elegant watch, the chrono display is subtly integrated and in no way detracts from the clean, sophisticated design.

Originally an evolution of its early automatics, the IWC Ingenieur was designed to combine the self-winding movement with the shock and magnetic resistance pioneered in some of the brand's pilot's watches. While the concept was successful and enjoyed various upgrades (including input from the legendary Gerald Genta), it was beginning to peter out in the early naughties. Seeking to refresh the collection, IWC partnered with Mercedes' high performance division, AMG, to create a series of cutting-edge timepieces that demonstrated both brands' commitment to the highest precision engineering. This model is made from zirconium-based ceramic, inspired by AMG's disc brakes, and houses the famous in-house Caliber 80110.

The GMT Master was first commissioned in the 1950s by pioneering airline Pan Am, and was designed for aviation. An increase in flight distances created demand for a watch that was able to tell the time in two different parts of the world simultaneously, so Rolex built it with an additional hand that could be set to a second time zone. By the 1980s, the watch had developed into the GMT Master II and was already a favourite among collectors. This model represents a significant upgrade for the watch, boasting an aerospace-grade steel case and cerachrom inserts in the bezel. A variant on the regular 116710, this reference features gold elements in the bezel, crown, hands, indices and of course the bracelet.

This Panerai has undergone a thorough inspection of accuracy, functionality and condition at our Panerai certified service centre to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. This modern Rolex GMT Master II features a superb calibre 3186 (with parachrom hairspring and Breguet overcoil) and a gorgeous white gold case. But its most impressive asset is the classic-looking bezel, returning in the original blue and red. The GMT Master has long been known for its two-tone bezel, to differentiate day and night for pilots using the watch for long-distance flights, but this one is made of a single block of cerachrom, using a patented process that makes it one of the first watches to feature ceramic components in multiple colours.

This Rolex has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history. All our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind.

This Rolex Daytona Cosmograph was designed to meet the needs of professional racing drivers upon its original release in 1963, with a reliable chronograph and bezel with tachymetric scale, allowing drivers to measure average speeds of up to 400 MPH. The name nods to Daytona, Florida—the home of a strong passion for speed and motor racing that emerged in the early 20th century. The relationship between Rolex and motor racing strengthened in 2013 when the watchmaker decided to enter the world of Formula 1, as Global Partner and Official Timepiece of the exhilarating sport. The 116520 introduced the in-house calibre 4130, a replacement to the Zenith-sourced 4030 in the previous 16520 and has become one of the most popular sports models ever created.

The legendary 5205 features several great complications, chief among which is surely the annual calendar. Patek revolutionised calendar complications when it invented the annual calendar in the 1990s, a complication with almost as much complexity and convenience as its perpetual counterpart, only needing to be set once per year. As in the equally well-known ref. 5960, the 5205's calendar is displayed via three small, instant-jumping and remarkably easy-to-read windows at the top of the watch. They nicely mirror a moonphase and 24-hour subdial combined at the bottom. With a concentric dial design, the watch takes on a wonderful, almost sporty appeal, while retaining every inch of the elegance for which Patek Philippe is so well loved.

It's rare for Rolex to create completely new watch collections, but this is what happened in 2012 with the exceptional Sky-Dweller. It's not just the design that's new – the watch also features a complication never seen in a Rolex watch before, the annual calendar. This difficult mechanical addition has been ever so subtly integrated. The main way you will even notice it is when the date magically jumps after months with only 30 days. There's a small indicator next to each hour marker; the black one shows the current month. This would all be remarkable in itself, but it's arguably overshadowed by the innovative new GMT display, occupying much of the central dial, and the even more innovative bezel. The latter has been upgraded with a “Ring Command” function that allows you to set the time and the other complications in a simple, intuitive fashion.

Invented in 1904, the Santos was the first ever men's wristwatch, originally invented for aviation pioneer Alberto Santos-Dumont to make it easier to check the time while flying. The watch was a game-changer in the industry thanks to Santos-Dumont's huge popularity and fame, and to celebrate the origins of the timepiece, Cartier produced a wonderful series of Santos watches called the Santos 100. Modern Santos watches still maintain the classic hallmarks of the original, including the rounded square case, Roman numeral hour markers and fully incorporated lugs.

The GMT Master was first commissioned in the 1950s by pioneering airline Pan Am, and was designed for aviation. An increase in flight distances created demand for a watch that was able to tell the time in two different parts of the world simultaneously, so Rolex built it with an additional hand that could be set to a second time zone. By the 1980s, the watch had developed into the GMT Master II and was already a favourite among collectors. This recent model represents a significant upgrade for the watch, boasting a cutting-edge movement, a magnificent gold case and bracelet, and high-tech cerachrom inserts in the bezel. The LN moniker stands for Lunette Noir—signifying that it uses an all-black bezel.

Calatrava watches, named after an order of ancient Spanish knights, are among the most elegant and distinguished in the world. They are known for their flawless, understated stylishness rooted in the finest Swiss traditions, combined with the avant-garde aesthetic in vogue at the time of the first Calatravas in the early 1930s. This version in yellow gold is as understated as they come and features an intricate hobnail-effect bezel within which the lacquered-finish white dial stands out. The elegant Roman numerals and simple stick hands in black—matching the crocodile leather strap— add to the timeless aesthetic and the automatic movement is housed in an especially slim case that makes it perfect for formal occasions.

A superb diving watch, TAG Heuer's Aquaracer was first launched in 2004 as an evolution of the equally superb Heuer 2000 divers conceived by Jack Heuer in the 1980s. In 2009, the design received a significant overhaul, leading to a new range of magnificent models like the very special, limited edition, black titanium watch for sale here, with its ceramic bezel, black lume, and striking, uncluttered dial. The black nylon strap is also an appreciated addition to the overall sleek, stealthy aesthetic. The piece maintains an excellent 300 meter water resistance, protecting the fine Swiss movement inside the Calibre 5.

For a long time known as “just” Rolex's junior partner, the Tudor brand finally came into its own in 2010 with the exceptional Heritage collection. The company was originally created by Hans Wilsdorf in 1946 as a more affordable version of Rolex – watches built to the same quality standards but without the in-house movements. Capturing the glorious vintage essence of Tudor watches from yesteryear, but without any faux-vintage affectations, the recent Heritage models represent a perfect meeting of old and new. The Black Bay in particular draws on a wonderful synthesis of historic Tudor design cues, from the big crown to the snowflake hands and the rich brown and gold colour palette.

Part of Patek Philippe’s long-running Calatrava line, the Pilot Travel Time, released in 2015, nods to the aesthetic simplicity of the Calatrava while incorporating several practical features that take it way beyond its time-only dress watch origins. Set in a superb rose gold case, the mesmerising black-brown gradient dial is complemented by gold applied Arabic numerals with luminescent coating for excellent legibility in all conditions. The sub-dial at 6 o’clock displays the date, and a second hour hand—skeletonised—gives a second time zone, along with day and night indicators for each zone. It’s powered by the Caliber 324 S C FUS, an automatic movement with 18k gold rotor visible through the transparent caseback. This is a useful, elegant yet robust timepiece from this hallowed brand.

A superb diving watch, TAG Heuer's Aquaracer was first launched in 2004 as an evolution of the equally superb Heuer 2000 divers conceived by Jack Heuer in the 1980s. The series was devoted to professionals and adventurers, as well as water-sportsmen of all kinds, and particularly sailors and yachtsmen. The watches have improved and evolved over the years, leading to a range of magnificent models like the one for sale here, with its unidirectional bezel, exceptionally legible design and superb finishing and craftsmanship. The piece maintains an excellent 300 meter water resistance, protecting the TAG Heuer Calibre 5 inside.

The Luminor design originated in the early 1950s, when Panerai finally decided to sell its prestigious watches to the civilian market—though it remained firmly rooted in the look and feel of the military watches of the '30s and '40s when the company was born. The new watches somewhat modernised the iconic look while remaining true to the brand's historical aesthetics, adding strong clean lines and new curves to the powerful cushion case, and a crown guard to boost muscle and water resistance. The 44mm PAM 312 is particularly attractive thanks to its use of the stunning P.9000 movement, made in-house by Panerai, with a power reserve of 3 days.

This is a special limited edition Speedmaster made by Omega to commemorate the 40th anniversary of Apollo 11. The first time humans landed on the moon, this was also the occasion on which the Speedmaster officially became the legendary Moonwatch, as Buzz Aldrin wore one during the inaugural moonwalk (Neil Armstrong left his onboard as a backup for a malfunctioning computer). This limited edition features the famous Apollo 11 “eagle” mission patch on the small seconds subdial and engraved on the caseback, and also has an extra line of text on the dial that remembers the exact time that Armstrong made his “one small step”.

The Cartier Tank, inspired by an actual tank, has been a design milestone since its inception in the early 20th century. Unlike the modified pocket watches being made by other manufacturers, the Tank used a new case design that actually incorporated the lugs into its shape, rather than adding them as an afterthought. Other iconic design elements include the blued sword hands, Roman numerals, elegant square dial and octagonal crown complete with sapphire cabochon. The Française collection adds a somewhat sportier, more modern feel to an already superb timepiece, making it bolder and more versatile, in large part thanks to its chain-link bracelet, not to mention the subtle and effective use of gold in this reference.

The GMT Master was first commissioned in the 1950s by pioneering airline Pan Am, and was designed for aviation. An increase in flight distances created demand for a watch that was able to tell the time in two different parts of the world simultaneously, so Rolex built it with an additional hand that could be set to a second time zone. By the 1980s, the watch had developed into the GMT Master II and was already a favourite among collectors. This model represents a significant upgrade for the watch, boasting an aerospace-grade “superalloy” steel case and cerachrom inserts in the bezel. The LN moniker stands for Lunette Noir—signifying that it uses an all-black bezel.

Rolex has long been popular among women who know their horology. Unlike some brands that relegate ladies' watches to mere fashion statements, Rolex devotes just as much care and attention to its mechanical credentials as it does for watches aimed at men. The 'Lady' Oyster Perpetual participates in the same legendary history of Rolex's groundbreaking introduction of vital new technologies in the early 20th century, the Oyster case providing the first real water resistance, and the perpetual rotor allowing watches to run without manual winding. Slimmed-down in size to a 26mm case, this model with black dial and quarter Arabic numerals carries the same stunning elegance and attention to detail with which Rolex is synonymous.

The Speedmaster is one of the most iconic watches ever made by Omega, if not any brand. The company has done a strong trade in developing the watch's stratospheric reputation as the first and only timepiece worn on the Moon during the Apollo missions. Of the many special editions released, the all-ceramic “Dark Side of the Moon” was among the most memorable. This incredible version updates the Dark Side (originally inspired by the extraordinary Apollo 8 mission) with an edition called “Black Black”. The case, bezel and dial are all made of a deep black ceramic with black Super-LumiNova that creates even fewer contrasts than its predecessor. There's even a pitch black nylon strap.

It's the watch that originally made Rolex the industry-leading, super-desirable brand that it is today. First developed in the 1920s and 30s, the Oyster Perpetual combined the brand's groundbreaking waterproof case (Oyster) with its superb self-winding, in-house movement (Perpetual), creating an icon of watchmaking that would supply the foundation for legends like the Submariner. Today, the name is still used for many of its finest watches, but the true product survives in this stunning ref. 116000, new in 2014. Retaining the watch's flawless, classic design, evolved subtly for modern tastes, and its peerless mechanical prowess, this is a gorgeous timepiece for those who want something timeless.

The case is smoother and more rounded than other Rolex sports models, even more so than it initially appears.

The Air King was named in honour of the brave RAF pilots of WWII, when Hans Wilsdorf, founder of Rolex, discovered they were ditching their standard issue watches for his Oyster Perpetual. As one of its longest continuously manufactured and most affordable watches, the Air King is a beloved staple of Rolex's range. At Baselworld 2016, the brand released this superbly updated model. It refreshes the classic look, upgrading size, durability and calibre precision while staying true to its aviation heritage in such key elements as the iconic 1950s Air-King font. Many believe that the dial design is inspired by the custom dashboard timepieces Rolex supplied to the Bloodhound SSC land speed record attempt.

The Yacht-Master, introduced by Rolex in 1992 in a gold case, was the first all-new watch from the brand since the Daytona in the 1960s. The watch was designed for adventurers and sportsmen—the topside equivalent to the diver's Submariner, to which it bears a strong similarity, though with more of a luxury than a tool watch feel. By 1999 it had become one of the most highly sought and desirable models in the Rolex stable after the introduction of a platinum version, though it wasn't until 2005 that the Rolesor reference 16623 arrived. Rolesor is the brand's term for two-tone watches that use both steel and gold, which this one does so in serious style. Like all Yacht-Masters, the bezel is made of a single block of solid gold.

Born as the amalgamation of incredible new technologies developed by Rolex, COMEX (the French deep-sea diving company) and the US Navy during the late 60s, the Sea-Dweller is Rolex's ultra-durable dive computer. In production for more than four decades, the 16600 model featured such pioneering technology as a helium escape valve and a 1,220m water resistance, and received a major upgrade in the form of the 116660 Deepsea model seen here. With a three-piece “Ringlock” case, “Triplock” crown system and 5mm sapphire crystal, this watch can survive pressures that would flatten a submarine. Its water resistance rating is an incredible 3,900m—deeper than the average depth of the ocean.

The “California” style dial, famous for its combination of Roman numerals, Arabic numerals and regular indexes, as well as the lack of brand name or other lettering, was used in Panerai's very earliest watches from the 1930s. The name comes from a company in California that was known for refurbishing many such dials. The 448 is based very closely on the original prototype Californias commissioned in 1936 by the Royal Italian Navy. This modern version with superb finishing is particularly delightful thanks to the stunning case, authentic black dial and the blue hands and minute track that go so nicely with it.

Due to age, this Rolex may not fall within our typical expected tolerances for timekeeping, and is no longer suitable for use in wet environments or submersion in water. In the interests of preserving original features, utmost care has been taken to sympathetically restore this watch. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history.

Partnering with one of the biggest American companies of the last century, Pan American Airways, Rolex created a watch that was capable of telling the time in more than one place or time zone—the GMT-Master. In 1983 the updated GMT-Master II was released, gaining the nickname “The Fat Lady” due to its chunky case. Later, in 2005, Rolex redesigned and rereleased the GMT-Master on its 50th anniversary by launching the GMT-Master II. This new release became the first Rolex sport watch with the new, larger case and ceramic bezel—famed for its scratch resistance and immunity to fading. Its updated 3186 calibre boasted some improvements compared to the older 3185, making the hour hand a lot easier to set. It also featured a new hairspring which was a lot less sensitive to temperature changes and magnetism—perfect for flying and travelling, just as the original intended. This special GMT-Master II—made of white gold—is the sequel to the watch that introduced the much-anticipated Pepsi ceramic bezel, now coming with a blue dial instead of white, for this second generation run.

Originally designed in 1971 for the admittedly niche market of cave explorers, the Rolex Explorer II was later updated to fit the aesthetic codes of the brand's other sports watch families. The watch builds on the heritage of the legendary Explorer I, which has always been a firm favourite among enthusiasts—the watch was first established in the public mind after its pioneering ascent of Everest during the expedition of Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay. Today the Explorer II deviates in some ways from the original look, but it continues to represent an exceptional, hardy, modernised tool watch with a top-of-the-range in-house movement and a design that does justice to its legacy in both sports and adventure.

This is a very special Sea-Dweller diving watch that represents several major firsts for Rolex. Released in honour of director James Cameron's headline-grabbing solo descent to the Challenger Deep at the bottom of the Marianas Trench, the watch has the highest water resistance rating of any piece made available to the public (3,900m)—although not as high as the concept watch Cameron took with him. Another first is the remarkable dial, which shifts like the ocean from blue to black. The green text matches the colour of Cameron's submarine, the 'Deepsea Challenger'. Finally, perhaps rarest of all, the watch was unveiled at a special press event in the summer of 2014. It's almost unheard of for the brand to launch anything outside of Baselworld.

Rolex has long been popular among women who know their horology. Unlike some brands that relegate ladies' watches to mere fashion statements, Rolex gives just as much care and attention to their mechanical credentials as it does for watches aimed at men. The Lady Datejust participates in the same legendary horological history of Rolex's groundbreaking introduction of the date window in 1945, and still bears the famous 'Superlative Chronometer Officially Certified' on the dial. Its slimmed-down size allows for stunning elegance and attention to detail, and its exceptionally attractive minimalism has ensured it remains a popular choice for sophisticated women.

The Yacht-Master was originally introduced by Rolex in 1992—the first all-new model from the brand since the Daytona in 1964. The watch was designed for adventurers and sportsmen, like the topside equivalent of the diver's Submariner, to which it bears certain similarities. This version updates the classic model with extraordinary mechanical upgrades. The chronograph mechanism has been tailored specifically to yachtsmen's needs, with a programmable 10-minute countdown feature for timing start sequences at regattas. The bezel, built with flawless ceramic inserts, is even more ingenious. Its bidirectional turning is linked to the movement, meaning you can use its simple and intuitive 'ring command system' to set the watch and its complications.

Having a date indicator on a watch is taken for granted these days, but before 1945, the concept didn't exist at all—until Rolex added a simple, yet game-changing element to their famous Oyster watch: the date window. This small aperture changed the role of wristwatches from mere timekeeping devices to calendars as well. The Datejust was (and is) known for its classic elegance—the watch is striking in its magnificent, minimalist beauty. This delightful 'mid-size' model, which comes in a variety of dial colours and materials, is intended for use by both men and women.

The brainchild of legendary watch designer Gerald Genta, the Nautilus was introduced in 1976 to compete with Audemars Piguet’s Royal Oak, another now-iconic Genta-designed steel sports watch launched a few years earlier. Its case shape, with ear-like projections either side, was like nothing the industry had seen before and despite not being an immediate hit it’s now one of the most sought-after Patek models around. Notably, this all-steel reference 5980 model from 2008 features a single, concentrically designed sub-dial at 6 o’clock to display its chronograph functions, while a small aperture at 3 o’clock displays the date, discreetly set amongst the signature horizontal ridges of the stunning blue-grey dial. Through the transparent caseback, the gold rotor of the automatic Caliber CH 28-520 movement can be viewed. This is a highly sought-after timepiece, now discontinued, from arguably the world’s most illustrious watch brand.

column21: Patek Philippe, one of the most prestigious watch firms in all of Switzerland, has a sparkling history when it comes to timepieces for ladies. For at leat 150 years, its jewellery watches have been the best of the best, and the acclaimed Twenty-4 collection is no exception. Launched in 1999, it is inspired by, and in many ways represents an evolution of, the brand's famed Gondolo watches, and draws on the timeless Art Deco style that Patek Philippe does so well. This gorgeous rectangular model features a consummately elegant, minimalist design with diamonds in two rows (on the case and as indices on the dial) framing single Roman numerals at 6 and 12. At once classic, refined and dazzling, this is a phenomenal piece of horology is not to be missed.

It was in 1904 that Louis Cartier gave a watch to his good friend and aviation pioneer Alberto Santos-Dumont that was designed to be worn on the wrist. The Santos watch was the first ever men's wristwatch, originally invented to make it easier to check the time while flying. It was a game-changer in the industry thanks to Santos-Dumont's huge popularity and fame, as well as a very early example of the iconic Art Deco style that would influence fashion and watchmaking for decades. The modern Santos watches maintain the classic hallmarks of the original, including the rounded square case, Roman numerals and fully incorporated lugs—as well as the stunning guilloché dial on this model.

For a long time known as 'just' Rolex's younger sibling, the Tudor brand finally came into its own in 2010 with the exceptional Heritage collection. The company was originally created by Hans Wilsdorf in 1946 as a more affordable alternative to Rolex—watches built to the same quality standards but without the in-house movements. Capturing the glorious essence of Tudor watches from yesteryear, but without any faux-vintage affectations, the recent Heritage models represent a perfect meeting of old and new. The Black Bay in particular draws on a wonderful synthesis of historic Tudor design cues, from the big crown to the snowflake hands and the gorgeous burgundy bezel.

Longines added a new dive model to its Heritage line with this 2014 release. Inspired by the brand’s diving watches of the 1970s, the Heritage Diver is a true homage to the watchmaker’s past, but with modern additions such as updated movements. This piece features a 43mm cushion-shaped case which adds to the retro aesthetic of the watch, as well as a date window at 6 o’clock and two chronograph sub dials at 3 and 9 o’clock—making this a useful timepiece indeed. The additional crown at 10 o’clock moves the inner bezel and the black dial flaunts a pop of colour thanks to the red markings and second hand. Powered by an automatic movement, this watch is perfect for fans of vintage watches, and one that’ll see you through land and sea with ease.

column21: In watch form, the Carrera has been in existence since 1964, and continued Heuer’s great legacy in providing racing drivers with timing instruments. Named after the intense ‘Carrera Panamericana’ road race of the 1950’s (which also gave its name to the eponymous Porsche), the Carrera continues to provide timing for some of the world’s most prestigious racing teams today. This recent addition to the Carrera fold fully embodies that racing heritage with its lovely, paired-down tribute to vintage timepieces. The watch uses TAG's famous 1887 movement, a smooth column-wheel chronograph that features a modern version of the remarkable oscillating pinion first patented by the brand in 1887.

In both name and spirit, the Calibre 01 represents the first of what is expected to become a series of modernised upgrades for TAG Heuer timepieces masterminded by legend of the watchmaking world, Jean-Claude Biver. This model sees the familiar and iconic shape of the Carrera enhanced with an avant-garde (and larger) case build and a striking skeletonised dial. The 45mm titanium-carbide coated case is modular in design, constructed entirely in-house. The same goes for the movement (a modified version of the brand's superb Cal. 1887), which together with the skeletonisation and the red highlights creates a hi-tech aesthetic that builds on the watch's historical race car legacy.

Due to age, this Tudor may not fall within our typical expected tolerances for timekeeping, and is no longer suitable for use in wet environments or submersion in water. In the interests of preserving original features, utmost care has been taken to sympathetically restore this watch. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history.

For a long time known as 'just' Rolex's younger sibling, the Tudor brand finally came into its own in 2010 with the exceptional Heritage collection. The company was originally created by Hans Wilsdorf in 1946 as a more affordable alternative to Rolex—watches built to the same quality standards but without the in-house movements. Capturing the glorious essence of Tudor watches from yesteryear, but without any faux-vintage affectations, the recent Heritage models represent a perfect meeting of old and new. The Black Bay in particular draws on a wonderful synthesis of historic Tudor design cues, from the big crown to the snowflake hands and the gorgeous burgundy bezel.

Introduced in 2013, the Blackbird is a seriously good looking update for Breitling's Avenger series, and a welcome new member of the brand's growing compendium of awesome “stealth” (black-on-black) pieces. The watch may be a reference to the equally cool, black and stealthy SR-71 Blackbird – a legendary US Air Force reconnaissance plane that played a key part in the Cold War. With its carbon-treated titanium case and comparatively slim profile, this Blackbird is as ergonomic and lightweight as its namesake. The dial is super legible and glare-proof, while the movement is based on a premium Swiss chronometer.

The Chronospace uses Breitling's iconic digital-analogue display, pioneered in the early '80s when it played a major part in reviving the brand after the trials and tribulations of the quartz crisis. The design stays true to the company's legendary aviation heritage, with an imposing 48mm case that prioritises ruggedness and practicality—but doesn't neglect its stylish aesthetics. The watch features a memorable dial with oversize numerals at 3 and 9, and boasts a top-of-the-range, thermocompensated Superquartz movement with a host of functionalities. There's also the superb quality finishing and the consummate attention to detail that characterises all Breitling timepieces.

Rolex has long been popular among women who know their horology. Unlike some brands that relegate ladies' watches to mere fashion statements, Rolex gives just as much care and attention to their mechanical credentials as it does for watches aimed at men. After all, the brand's founder, Hans Wilsdorf, launched his original, groundbreaking Oyster Perpetual on the neck of the legendary female swimmer Mercedes Gleitze on her record-breaking crossing of the English Channel. The Datejust introduced another world first in 1945 when it added a date window, and its slim, elegant and minimalist design has made it one of the top choices for sophisticated women ever since.

One of the oldest watchmakers in the world—only Blancpain has been around longer, at just three years more—Jaquet Droz has produced some remarkable creations. In its early years, the watchmaker extended its craft outside of horology when founder Pierre Jaquet-Droz created three automatas—a kind of mechanical puppet—which dazzled audiences at the time. Aside from the animatronics, Jaquet Droz has created this Grande Seconde Email Ivoire. Inside, this watch is powered by the Frederic Piguet calibre 1150—a world-class movement also used by both Blancpain and Breguet. Flaunting a minimalistic aesthetic with a cream enamel dial created using the painstaking Grand Feu process—baking fine enamel powder onto a copper blank at almost one thousand degrees Celsius—this is a process at which Jaquet Droz are industry leaders. The watch also features a large sub-seconds dial, as well as hours and minutes dial. This is a unique piece from an incredibly charming watchmaker.

In 2014, when Jaguar announced it was making the six “remaining” Lightweight versions of the iconic E-Type (the gorgeous 60s model described as the most beautiful car ever made), it partnered with another British high-end brand, Bremont, to release six very special accompanying timepieces. Due to popular demand, these watches have since gone into production and the Jaguar has become a beloved member of the Bremont stable. Its success stems from its stunning use of E-Type design codes, from the Dunlop tyre tread on the crown to the Jaguar heritage logo, to the tachometer-inspired dial design with the same font and “red line quadrant” as the original cars.

“A true collaboration in research and development”, this watch hails from an exceptional collection that represents a groundbreaking partnership between aerospace giant Boeing and British horological brand-of-the-hour, Bremont. These timepieces use the most cutting-edge materials from Boeing's state-of-the-art facilities, although Bremont is keen to stress that in spirit they pay homage to an earlier chapter of the company's aircraft-building history. This exceptionally rare GMT limited edition, boasting an advanced aerospace-grade titanium case, was made exclusively for Royal Navy crew members who operate a Merlin helicopter—an image of which can be seen on the dial.

“A true collaboration in research and development”, this watch hails from an exceptional collection that represents a groundbreaking partnership between aerospace giant Boeing and British horological brand-of-the-hour, Bremont. These timepieces use the most cutting-edge materials from Boeing's state-of-the-art facilities, although Bremont is keen to stress that in spirit they pay homage to an earlier chapter of the company's aircraft-building history – none more so than this special edition celebrating Boeing's centenary. Carbon fibre from the famed Boeing Dreamliner testbed aircraft, ZA004, has been integrated into the watch's crown, while the case is made of advanced aerospace-grade titanium. Boeing's first widely used logo from the 1930s can be found on the dial.

The de Havilland DH-88 Comet was a legendary aircraft known for setting a string of extraordinary records in the 1930s. The plane was built for the famous MacRobertson Air Race from London to Melbourne in 1934 because there were no other British aircraft suitable for entry. Three teams flew DH-88 Comets on the race, and one of them, named Grosvenor House, won it—setting a new record of just under three days, despite the two pilots having to deal with severe exhaustion and mechanical failures. This fantastic limited edition commemorates this remarkable chapter with gorgeous rose gold and steel GMT timepieces that incorporates a fragment of original spruce plywood from the undercarriage of Grosvenor House in the rotor. Proceeds from sales were donated by Bremont to the Shuttleworth Trust to help maintain the aircraft, which continues to give regular displays.

For many Panerai collectors, the “Base” Luminor models are considered an excellent purchase, as they tend to represent fantastic value for money and many are rare thanks to their small production runs. This model, for example, was made in only 2,000 units sold exclusively at boutique stores. The Base watches are similar if not identical in many respects to other models that cost far more. The key difference is the hour numerals, which are painted rather than cut out of a sandwich dial. While sandwiches are more closely identified with Panerai and arguably more authentic, many prefer the look and feel of the painted version, which is said to “pop” better than its counterpart.

The highly anticipated Rio Olympics are fast approaching, and naturally they have provided good cause for Omega to celebrate its enduring position as Official Timekeeper with a range of superb new special watches. This colourful limited edition is a take on the brand's legendary, ultra-rare 1969 “Bullhead” stopwatch. The name, of course, is derived from the unusual positioning of the crown and pushers on the top of the case. This stunning vintage reproduction stays faithful in most respects to the look of the original, with its distinctive wedge-shaped case and the 6 o'clock crown (which controls the internal bezel). The biggest change is the Olympic-themed colour scheme, and of course the fantastic modern movement 3113.

In 2014, when Jaguar announced it was making the six “remaining” Lightweight versions of the iconic E-Type (the gorgeous 60s model described as the most beautiful car ever made), it partnered with another British high-end brand, Bremont, to release six very special accompanying timepieces. Due to popular demand, these watches have since gone into production and the Jaguar has become a beloved member of the Bremont stable. Its success stems from its stunning use of E-Type design codes, from the Dunlop tyre tread on the crown to the Jaguar heritage logo, to the tachometer-inspired dial design with the same font and “red line quadrant” as the original cars.

Named after the quaint Alpine village where the company's workshops are located, the Villeret collection undoubtedly comprises Blancpain's most classic and elegant watches. Like the town of Villeret itself, the watches are rooted in the oldest and most admirable qualities of Swiss watchmaking. The aesthetic is understated but confident in its exquisite design and finishing of premium quality materials. All of Blancpain's 300 years of experience at the very highest levels of haute horlogerie is brought to bear in this beautiful series. This particularly excellent model features a complete set of calendar and moonphase complications, marking it as a superb example of high-end mechanical accomplishment.

Ayrton Senna was one of the most gifted racing drivers of all time. Tragically killed in an accident at the San Marino Grand Prix when he was 34, Senna made his name with his terrific skill, three world championships and notorious rivalries, and his legend endures to this day. The great man is honoured by this extraordinary all-ceramic Hublot limited edition, featuring his Brazilian colours on the dial (as well as a flag on the side of the case), and the Ayrton Senna Institute logo on the caseback. As an energetic Formula 1 tribute with an explosive design and build, the watch features amazing complications, including an impressive split seconds chronograph and the foudroyante (jumping) eighth of a second subdial.

Due to age, this Omega may not fall within our typical expected tolerances for timekeeping, and is no longer suitable for use in wet environments or submersion in water. In the interests of preserving original features, utmost care has been taken to sympathetically restore this watch. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history.

Luxury watchmaking in England was given a welcome boost with the launch of Bremont in 2002. Founded by brothers Giles and Nick English, it began by making beautifully crafted pilots’ watches, most of which are ISO chronometer rated, and has brought out a number of intriguing limited editions that incorporate history into the actual watch in the most literal sense. This model features an actual piece of fabric used on the 1903 Wright Flyer aircraft that marked the beginning of the pioneer era of aviation. It can be seen through the transparent caseback, as can the automatic movement, which is powered by a rotor that bears the words ‘Wright Flyer’, the initials of the Wright brothers, Wilbur and Orville, and a delightful propellor design. This hugely collectible watch, with a 50-hour power reserve, is one of just 300 pieces.

Still based in the alpine village of Le Locle where it was founded in 1865, Zenith has become inseparably associated with pioneering aviation watches. In 1909, father of aviation Louis Blériot wore a Zenith timepiece when he became the first man to fly the English Channel—in many respects, the DNA of that original pilot's watch has changed little. The Montre d'Aeronef watch itself was born in the 1930s as a cockpit clock, a vital tool for pilots through many generations. This modern example uses many design elements from these historic timepieces with very few changes—although it is, of course, equipped with a superb modern, in-house Elite movement complete with a classic GMT complication. How better to capture Zenith's extraordinary legacy of horology for pilots?

column21: Before the legendary Calibre 360, which made headlines as the first mechanical chronograph movement capable of measuring hundredths of a second, there was the Calibre 36. Equally legendary, in its way, it boasts a super-high frequency of 5Hz (most high-end chronographs beat at 4Hz). This might remind you of another famous chronograph movement, and you'd be right: the Calibre 36 is a modified version of Zenith's El Primero—ironic, considering Heuer and Zenith were competitors in the famous 1969 race to build the first automatic chrono—although this one has been upgraded with additional flyback capability. This gorgeous, cutting-edge Carrera has been called the “hero model” of the Calibre 36 range, thanks to its titanium case and sleek black titanium carbide exterior.

column21: This magnificent pilot's timepiece from top Swiss brand IWC features a very special complication. The world timer is widely considered the cream of luxury travelling watches. Rather than simply adding an extra hand to show a second time zone, the watch features a somewhat more complex—yet intuitive and satisfying—operation. The time in the home city is shown by the primary hands on the dial, while the wearer can simultaneously see the time in every major city around the world by the position of the rotating 24-hour disk between the city names and the main dial (conveniently distinguishing between day and night). In this supremely well engineered and finished example, the cities themselves do not move, allowing the wearer to get used to looking for them always in the same place.

This gorgeous black Luminor is one of a limited run with reference PAM 508. The 508 is significant for being the first Luminor Submersible with a ceramic case, made from zirconium oxide with an added heat-resistant pigment that provides the deep black colouring. A sandblasted finishing creates the matt appearance. The result is incredibly hard, lightweight and scratch-resistant, and looks amazing in its imposing 47mm form. The black leather strap completes the look. The watch runs on the in-house P.9000 movement, which boasts a 3-day power reserve from two barrels, and allows the wearer to change the time in convenient 1-hour increments.

First held in 2009, the Lamborghini Blancpain Super Trofeo is a series of motor racing tournaments held around the world, in which amateur and pro-amateur drivers compete using Lamborghini Cup cars. The event is an exclusive showcase of the alliance between these two giants of the luxury industry, sharing their passion for superlative aesthetics and technology. Aiming to match the quality and style of the prestigious Gallardo cars created for the race, Blancpain unveiled this extra special Super Trofeo chronograph. Based on the brand's L-Evolution series, the watch is magnificently sporty and good looking without going over the top, and it houses an exceptionally sophisticated flyback movement.

The Speedmaster is so closely associated with NASA and the Moon landings these days that it's easy to forget that when it was first released in the 1950s, it was not remotely intended for space travel. Rather, as the name suggests, the Speedy was designed as a sports watch for timing motor racing and other fast, or indeed furious, events. Today it's very rare to encounter Speedies from the long lost pre-Moon era, but when you do find something like this gorgeous vintage piece from 1967, be sure to snap it up for your collection.

Known as one of the foremost purveyors of ultra-elegant jewellery, Cartier has long made superb watches, with excellent mechanical pedigree – but its principal strong suit has been high-fashion and style. The Calibre de Cartier collection represents a big step forward for the brand into the world of true haute horlogerie. Without losing an ounce of its customary sophistication and stylishness, the watches are equipped with the first self-winding movement entirely manufactured by Cartier SA: the glorious 1904 MC (named for the year that Louis Cartier famously made his first timepiece for Alberto Santos-Dumont). You can see it through the sapphire caseback.

In 2008, IWC announced a new collection of six vintage revivals, each from a different beloved watch series, to celebrate the 140th anniversary of the prestigious brand's founding in 1868. Each watch was designed and created based on the very first model from their respective family—in the case of this gorgeous Portuguese, this was the original piece from 1939 that began the extraordinary Portuguese legacy of ultra-elegant, high-precision chronometers. While it looks substantially different from today's models, this vintage reincarnation maintains the timeless, uncluttered beauty and sophistication that we still associate with the series.

The Air King was named in honour of the brave RAF pilots of WWII, when Hans Wilsdorf, founder of Rolex, discovered they were ditching their standard issue watches for his Oyster Perpetual. As one of its longest continuously manufactured and most affordable watches, the Air King is a beloved staple of Rolex's range. At Baselworld 2016, the brand released this superbly updated model. It refreshes the classic look, upgrading size, durability and calibre precision while staying true to its aviation heritage in such key elements as the iconic 1950s Air-King font. Many believe that the dial design is inspired by the custom dashboard timepieces Rolex supplied to the Bloodhound SSC land speed record attempt.

column21: Originally introduced in 1956, the Day-Date was the first watch to indicate the day of the week spelt out in full when it was launched, making it an innovative piece. In 2008, Rolex released the Day-Date II, a modern update of the timelessly classic Day-Date, which features a larger case than the original watch. However, this has since been replaced by the Day-Date 40, introduced back in 2015. This Day-Date II, then, features a rose gold bracelet, fluted bezel and case, both effortlessly paired with the black baton dial that features baguette-cut diamond and ruby hour markers. This piece is perfect for those after a little bling, or with a taste for rare and discontinued Rolex models.

Launched by Rolex in 1963 as a racing chronograph, the Daytona was initially a slow seller, but the post-quartz crisis revival of mechanical watches and a famous association with Hollywood legend Paul Newman—who wore a model bought for him by his wife—has seen it become hugely desirable. Indeed, Newman’s very own watch once held the record for the most expensive wristwatch sold at auction. Once a manual-wind watch that relied on outsourced movements, the Daytona has been automatic since 1988, and is now powered by Rolex’s in-house caliber 4130, a superlative chronometer that holds a power reserve of 72 hours. This incredible 40mm model in 18k Everose gold features a spellbinding sunburst dial that stands out beautifully within the black bezel. Presented on a black rubber Oysterflex bracelet, this is a spectacular timepiece that is currently one of the most sought-after watches around.

The classic Explorer I has always been a firm favourite amongst enthusiasts, its heritage and good looks being very hard to resist. Established in the public mind after Rolex’s involvement in the pioneering ascent of Everest with Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay, the Explorer I has a delightfully clear, readable face, uncluttered by a date complication. The case is smoother and more rounded than other Rolex sports models, even more so than it initially appears.

The Rolex Explorer is one of the most highly valued and sought out models for buyers with a lot of experience in the often complicated world of vintage watch collecting. Originally based on the model worn by Tenzing Norgay in the first ever successful ascent of Everest in 1953, the Explorer was a versatile timepiece that enjoyed numerous variations. This reference 14270 is an excellent example. Starting in 1989, it brought a well-received modern upgrade to the Explorer family, while staying faithful to the original model—and also introduced the superb calibre 3000.

Like many of its iconic watch families, Rolex's Milgauss was created in 1956 with a specific market in mind: scientists, power station workers and anyone else exposed to high magnetic fields. It was designed to be able to resist fields up to 1,000 gauss (hence the name—“mille” is Latin for thousand). The watch built a solid reputation with only two models until 1988, and was happily revived two decades later in a modern re-edition that remains faithful to the original purpose and aesthetics—including the beloved lightning bolt hand. This gorgeous GV version (Glace Verte) has a green-tinted dial crystal, and uses a Parachrom-Blu hairspring for even better magnetic and shock resistance.

This Rolex has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. Having a date indicator on a watch is taken for granted these days, but before 1945, the concept didn't exist at all—until Rolex added a simple, yet game-changing element to their famous Oyster watch: the date window. This small aperture changed the role of wristwatches from mere timekeeping devices to calendars as well. The Datejust was (and is) known for its classic elegance—the watch is striking in its magnificent, minimalist beauty. This delightful 'mid-size' model, which comes in a variety of dial colours and materials, is intended for use by both men and women.

The Seamaster is one of the most iconic diving watches of all time. Following Omega's Marine in 1932, the world's first commercially available diving watch, the legend of the Seamaster officially debuted in 1948. By the time of 1957's 300M, it was among the most dependable and professionally sought dive watches from any brand, and it soon pioneered some of the sporty must-have features we associate with such watches, including unidirectional bezels, phosphorescent hands and the helium escape valve. This excellent example takes the familiar technical specs and design cues and updates them with a stunning chronograph dial featuring sporty red highlights.

It has also been checked against our records to ensure authenticity. All our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind.

This exceptional limited edition Panerai honours the incredible, record-setting expedition by legendary South African explorer Mike Horn to the North Pole in 2006. It was the first time anyone had reached the pole without dogs or motorised transport; they went on skis or foot in total darkness for 60 days. This watch, which boasts the expedition's route map and Horn's signature engraved on the caseback, is a very special Luminor. It uses an advanced type of lubricant to prevent it freezing up in arctic conditions, and also features inner protection made of soft iron to make it resistant to magnetic fields. Add in the compass bezel, and you've got the perfect watch for any true adventurer.

This is a rare opportunity to own a truly remarkable version of the iconic Rolex Submariner. The LB (“lunette bleu”) watch features a dazzling blue bezel and dial on top of all that lovely Rolex design and prestige—and best of all, it comes in a gorgeous white gold case. The Submariner is one of the greatest legends in the world of watches, perhaps ever. Developed with Jacques-Yves Cousteau in 1953, it quickly became the quintessential diver's watch, a reputation only cemented by appearances in the early Bond films. Today, its timeless design and unbeatable mechanical pedigree continue to make it one of the brand's best-selling pieces.

In 2008, Rolex released the Day-Date II, a modern update of the timelessly classic Day-Date, which features a larger case (41mm) than the original. This in turn was replaced in 2015 by the Day-Date 40 which, as the name implies, comes in a 40mm case. This version in white gold features a signature fluted bezel, within which is a sublime dark green dial bearing applied Roman numerals. The date at 3 o’clock lies beneath the signature Rolex Cyclops magnifying lens for better legibility. It comes on a President bracelet and runs on the Caliber 3255 automatic movement. Famously, the Day-Date was the first watch to indicate the day of the week spelt out in full when it was launched in 1956, and it has gone on to be worn by everyone from the Dalai Lama to numerous US presidents, hence its ‘President’ nickname.

Launched by Rolex in 1963 as a racing chronograph, the Daytona was initially a slow seller, but the post-quartz crisis revival of mechanical watches and a famous association with Hollywood legend Paul Newman—who wore a model bought for him by his wife—has seen it become hugely desirable. Indeed, Newman’s very own watch once held the record for the most expensive wristwatch sold at auction. Once a manual-wind watch that relied on outsourced movements, the Daytona has been automatic since 1988, and is now powered by Rolex’s in-house caliber 4130, a superlative chronometer that holds a power reserve of 72 hours. This incredible 40mm model in 18ct yellow gold features a spellbinding dark green dial that stands out beautifully within the gold bezel. It’s a spectacular timepiece that is currently one of the most sought-after models around.

Describing its aesthetic as elegant, simple and creative, Vacheron Constantin has continually aimed to enhance and reinvent the art of fine watchmaking since its introduction over 265 years ago. The oldest Swiss watchmakers in continuous operation, it has cemented its place within the top three watchmakers in the world. Encapsulating that aesthetic, this 18-karat gold piece boasts an array of features on its dial. These comprise a leap year indicator between 1 and 2 o'clock, 30-minute recorder at 3 o'clock, date and moon phase display at 6 o'clock, small seconds at 9 o'clock and day and month windows at 12 o'clock. The manual wind movement—the Vacheron Constantin Calibre 1141 QP—is also perfectly displayed through the open case back. This watch is perfect for those after a timepiece packed full of features from one of the world’s best watchmakers.

The Ballon Bleu, one of Cartier's newest watch collections, has been hugely successful since its 2007 release. With a unique, curving, organic case, a cleverly integrated sapphire crown and a multi-facetted guilloché dial, the watch can rightly be called a gem in every sense, blending the best of classical elegance and futuristic originality. Creating beauty through simplicity, the watch showcases everything that makes Cartier such a prestigious and highly-sought brand. This model uses a superb Swiss automatic movement underneath the traditional Roman numerals and blue sword hands on the dial. It's a timepiece that has to been seen in the flesh to get the full effect.

The Air King was named in honour of the brave RAF pilots of WWII, when Hans Wilsdorf, founder of Rolex, discovered they were ditching their standard issue watches for his Oyster Perpetual. As one of its longest continuously manufactured and most affordable watches, the Air King is a beloved staple of Rolex's range. At Baselworld 2016, the brand released this superbly updated model. It refreshes the classic look, upgrading size, durability and calibre precision while staying true to its aviation heritage in such key elements as the iconic 1950s Air-King font. Many believe that the dial design is inspired by the custom dashboard timepieces Rolex supplied to the Bloodhound SSC land speed record attempt.

The Yacht-Master was originally introduced by Rolex in 1992—the first all-new model from the brand since the Daytona in 1964. The watch was designed for adventurers and sportsmen, like the topside equivalent of the diver's Submariner, to which it bears certain similarities. This version updates the classic model with extraordinary new materials. The bezel is black ceramic, the case is glorious 'Everose' gold (a unique Rolex alloy), and perhaps most exciting of all, the strap is made of rubber—a major first for Rolex—that the brand is calling 'Oysterflex'. In fact, it's not natural rubber but a special material known as elastomer. Inside, you'll find the stunning calibre 3135.

This watch is not just a classic Submariner—one of the most popular and iconic watches in the world—but a striking and highly collectible variant edition. The watch is easily recognisable thanks to its rare green bezel and dial, causing collectors to give it the affectionate nickname “Hulk”, although LV itself stands for Lunette Vert (“Green Bezel”). This larger version updates the previous LV model ref 16610 (called “Kermit”) that was originally introduced in 2003 for the 50th anniversary of the Submariner. This edition boasts ceramic inserts in the bezel, with numerals in platinum.

This Rolex has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history. Our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind, in conjunction with any remaining manufacturer’s warranty from new or from service.

The Daytona features on the must-have list of pretty much every watch enthusiast out there, and what better way is there to enjoy the clean lines and classic design of this Rolex icon than with the added warmth that gold brings? Not only that, but this is one of the last Daytonas to feature the modified Zenith El Primero movement, Calibre 4030 (distinguished by the seconds hand at 9 o'clock rather than 6). This movement is proving to be very popular with collectors and is holding its value well.

The Rolex Daytona, named after the race circuit in Florida that hosts the Rolex twenty-four hour race, epitomises the ultimate driver’s watch. The dial, unburdened by a date window, is clear and easy to read. The tachymeter offers quick speed calculations, while the shape is instantly recognisable and supremely comfortable. Its smaller size and smart design makes it a versatile watch capable of working well with both casual jeans and a formal suit. Here available in steel with a stunning Cerachrom bezel, this watch represents the Daytona's first major upgrade in 16 years, but it sticks closely to the gorgeous retro design of the original.

This watch is not just a classic Submariner—one of the most popular and iconic watches in the world—but a striking and highly collectible variant edition. The watch is easily recognisable thanks to its rare green bezel and dial, causing collectors to give it the affectionate nickname “Hulk”, although LV itself stands for Lunette Vert (“Green Bezel”). This larger version updates the previous LV model ref 16610 (called “Kermit”) that was originally introduced in 2003 for the 50th anniversary of the Submariner. The Cartier Tank has been a design milestone since its inception in the early 20th century. Unlike the modified pocket watches being made by other manufacturers, the Tank used a new case design—inspired by the shape of a tank—that actually incorporated the lugs into its shape, rather than adding them as an afterthought. Other iconic design elements include the blued sword hands, Roman numerals, elegant square dial and octagonal crown complete with sapphire cabochon. The Française collection adds a somewhat sportier, more modern feel to an already superb timepiece, making it bolder and more versatile, in large part thanks to its chain-link bracelet.

Added to the beloved Aquatimer collection just last year, this new watch represents a significant step forward for IWC's divers in a number of respects. First and foremost, the watch has been widely acclaimed for its innovative external/internal bezel. Using a special clutch system positioned to look like a left hand crown, the bezel is set by unidirectional rotation as normal, in a manner that combines the ease of outer bezels with the safety advantages of inner ones. Then there's the water resistance—the watch can cope with pressures up to 30 bar, more than double its previous specs. Finally, there's the updated appearance. Effortlessly legible, clean and elegant, the chronograph is nevertheless a rugged and imposing 44mm sports watch in striking monochrome.

This wonderful black dial Luminor features striking white displays for small seconds and – more unusually – the power reserve. The Luminor design originated in the early 1990s, when Panerai finally decided to sell its prestigious watches to the civilian market after more than 50 years as a military-only contractor. It somewhat modernised the Panerai look while remaining true to the brand's historical aesthetics, adding strong clean lines and new curves to the distinctive cushion case, and a crown guard to boost water resistance. This model has a lightweight titanium case with a depth rating of 300m, and is powered by the OP IX movement.

The classic Explorer I has always been a firm favourite amongst enthusiasts, its heritage and good looks being very hard to resist. Established in the public mind after Rolex’s involvement in the pioneering ascent of Everest with Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay, the Explorer I has a delightfully clear, readable face, uncluttered by a date complication. The case is smoother and more rounded than other Rolex sports models, even more so than it initially appears.

This Panerai has undergone a thorough inspection of accuracy, functionality and condition at our Panerai certified service centre to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been checked against our records to ensure authenticity. All our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind.

This extraordinary limited edition is an almost exact reissue of the iconic first watch made by Officine Panerai in 1936 for the Royal Italian Navy. At that time, Panerai was making technical instruments (depth gauges, compasses, even torpedo launchers) but not watches. To make the watch, it bought cushion cases, purely because they were popular at the time, and movements from Rolex. It added a new Panerai invention: radiomir, a luminous material to make the watches legible in the dark. The watch was so well made that it passed all the military tests with flying colours, and has remained a legend in Panerai history ever since. There are no brand markings on the famous California dial in order to prevent the enemy discovering the navy's supplier, should the watch fall into the wrong hands.

The Air King was named in honour of the brave RAF pilots of WWII, when Hans Wilsdorf, founder of Rolex, discovered they were ditching their standard issue watches for his Oyster Perpetual. As one of its longest continuously manufactured and most affordable watches, the Air King is a beloved staple of Rolex's range. At Baselworld 2016, the brand released this superbly updated model. It refreshes the classic look, upgrading size, durability and calibre precision while staying true to its aviation heritage in such key elements as the iconic 1950s Air-King font. Many believe that the dial design is inspired by the custom dashboard timepieces Rolex supplied to the Bloodhound SSC land speed record attempt.

This Panerai has undergone a thorough inspection of accuracy, functionality and condition at our Panerai certified service centre to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been checked against our records to ensure authenticity. When Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay became the first people to reach the summit of Everest in 1953, their expedition team were supplied with watches by Rolex and the British company Smith’s. Rolex designed a watch specifically for the expedition, which came to be known as the Explorer, one of the less prominent models in the Rolex stable but one that has been a constant since its launch. A far plainer looking watch back then, the Explorer aesthetic is now characterised by the Mercedes hour hand, three-quarter numeral black dial and Oyster bracelet. This model, with a 36mm case, is the first to come in two-tone steel and yellow gold and runs on a Caliber 3230 which holds a power reserve of almost 70 hours.

Panerai has several watches with amazingly long power reserves, yet even by its standards, this 8-day Radiomir is pretty darn cool. The watch harnesses three large mainspring barrels to generate this much power, and the superb mechanical specs of the in-house P.2002 movement ensure that this energy is distributed cleanly and evenly without any compromise of timekeeping precision. In addition to the power reserve, which has a 'linear' display at 6 o'clock, the watch also boasts a stunning black aesthetic made possible by the extraordinary ceramic case material, formed from the isostatic pressing of zirconium oxide.

Launched by Rolex in 1963 as a racing chronograph, the Daytona was initially a slow seller, but the post-quartz crisis revival of mechanical watches and a famous association with Hollywood legend Paul Newman—who wore a model bought for him by his wife—has seen it become hugely desirable. Indeed, Newman’s very own watch once held the record for the most expensive wristwatch sold at auction. Once a manual-wind watch that relied on outsourced movements, the Daytona has been automatic since 1988, and is now powered by Rolex’s in-house caliber 4130, a superlative chronometer that holds a power reserve of 72 hours. This incredible 40mm model in 18k Everose gold features a spellbinding sunburst dial that stands out beautifully within the black bezel. Presented on a black rubber Oysterflex bracelet, this is a spectacular timepiece that is currently one of the most sought-after watches around.
