The El Primero legend is one of the great stories of 20th century watchmaking. Invented in 1969, it represented the end of an intense race between three major horological research teams to create the world's first automatic chronograph; a race that many believe it won. Today, the El Primero remains one of the most highly regarded movements in the world, and one of only a small number to use the stunning frequency of 5Hz for maximum precision. The marvellous timepiece for sale here allows you to keep an eye on this superb piece of horological history with a partially skeletonised dial that shows the escapement (and small seconds) in a cutaway at 10 o'clock. There's also a useful power reserve complication at 6 o'clock.

The Royal Oak is one of the most iconic watches in history – a product of the same genius designer, Gerald Genta, who was responsible for the likes of Patek Philippe's Nautilus and IWC's Ingenieur. The story is a dramatic one – Audemars Piguet had been lingering on the edge of collapse since the Great Depression, but the Royal Oak's unprecedentedly bold lines, steel case and luxury pricing turned Genta's creation into an enormous success that saved the prestigious company. Since then, the legendary watch has gone from strength to strength, and continues to serve as a key showcase for the best elements of the brand's historic and peerless watchmaking abilities.

Invented in the 1930s as one of the first wristwatches made to be as precise as a marine chronometer, the Portuguese collection has a long history, though it wasn't produced in serious numbers until the 1990s. Today they are among IWC's finest watches, beloved by collectors for their graceful, uncluttered design and classic aesthetic featuring thin bezels and sword-like hands. This exquisite model runs on an automatic movement, IWC calibre 79240, with a superb chronograph mechanism. Adding a dash of sporting appeal to this elegant watch, the chrono display is subtly integrated and in no way detracts from the clean, sophisticated design.

Panerai watches tend to follow certain conventions and design codes that make them instantly recognisable – but some watches move away from this formula, providing a welcome breath of fresh air. And few Panerai models have left the beaten track as much as the FER00003, the third watch from the brand's short-lived partnership with Ferrari. It's still got the distinctive cushion case shape, but other than that, there's little that says “Panerai” here – even the crown guard has been removed. Despite this, the Ferrari watches are lovely timepieces in their own right, and they possess the enviable combination of being both rare and relatively affordable. Indeed, unlike the first two Ferrari watches, this is a strictly limited edition.

The Cartier Tank, inspired by an actual tank, has been a design milestone since its inception in the early 20th century. Unlike the modified pocket watches being made by other manufacturers, the Tank used a new case design that actually incorporated the lugs into its shape, rather than adding them as an afterthought. Other iconic design elements include the blued sword hands, Roman numerals, elegant square dial and octagonal crown complete with sapphire cabochon. The Française collection adds a somewhat sportier, more modern feel to an already superb timepiece, making it bolder and more versatile, in large part thanks to its chain-link bracelet.

When Buzz Aldrin stepped out of the lunar module, codenamed ‘Eagle’, and onto the powdery surface of the moon, the Omega Speedmaster on his wrist became the legendary Moonwatch. Tested to the limits by NASA for the rigours of space flight, the Speedmaster had in fact been into space before the testing had even begun. In October 1962, astronaut Wally Schirra took his own personal Speedmaster on board Sigma 7 and orbited Earth a total of six times for the Mercury 7 mission. The Speedmaster continued to provide NASA astronauts with invaluable service for the Apollo 13 mission, when it was used to time the crucial burn that would return the astronauts safely to Earth.

The Cartier Tank, inspired by an actual tank, has been a design milestone since its inception in the early 20th century. Unlike the modified pocket watches being made by other manufacturers, the Tank used a new case design that actually incorporated the lugs into its shape, rather than adding them as an afterthought. Other iconic design elements include the blued sword hands, Roman numerals, elegant square dial and octagonal crown complete with sapphire cabochon. The Française collection adds a somewhat sportier, more modern feel to an already superb timepiece, making it bolder and more versatile, in large part thanks to its chain-link bracelet.

Launched by Rolex in 1963 as a racing chronograph, the Daytona was initially a slow seller, but the post-quartz crisis revival of mechanical watches and a famous association with Hollywood legend Paul Newman—who wore a model bought for him by his wife—has seen it become hugely desirable. Indeed, Newman’s very own watch once held the record for the most expensive wristwatch sold at auction. Once a manual-wind watch that relied on outsourced movements, the Daytona has been automatic since 1988, and is now powered by Rolex’s in-house caliber 4130, a superlative chronometer that holds a power reserve of 72 hours. This Daytona flaunts an uber-cool meteorite dial—no two are the same— which perfectly complements the white gold case and burgundy alligator strap. This is an ideal timepiece for those after a classic Rolex with a bit of pizazz.

The IWC Portuguese Laureus Sport for Good Foundation prominently features a galvanised blue dial that goes perfectly with the alligator strap. Limited to 2,000 pieces, this watch was made to raise money for the Laureus Sport for Good Foundation, a charity that helps disadvantaged children through sports programs – proceeds from each watch were donated to the foundation. IWC makes a Limited Edition Laureus watch every year, always featuring the foundation's “colour of hope” (blue) and a caseback engraving of a child’s drawing, the winner of a themed annual competition. These watches have become highly collectable for fans of IWC.

Sleek, menacing and black as night, the PAM 438's dark allure is not the result of any external PVD or DLC. Dubbed the “Tuttonero” (from the Italian for All Black), it's a fully ceramic case, much harder than steel and amazingly durable, the result of an exceptionally long and high-tech process to achieve the gorgeous matte finish. The Tuttonero name is not an exaggeration—it's not just the case that's black. The entire strap is made from the same ceramic, and even the beautiful in-house P.9001 movement has undergone a blackening process to achieve a uniform look. It also has an impressive power reserve of three days and features a GMT complication.

The Royal Oak is one of the most iconic watches in history – a product of Gerald Genta, the same genius designer who was responsible for the likes of Patek Philippe's Nautilus and IWC's Ingenieur. The story is quite dramatic – Audemars Piguet had been lingering on the edge of collapse since the Depression, but the unprecedentedly bold lines, steel case and luxury pricing turned Genta's creation into an enormous success that saved the prestigious company. The Offshore collection, meanwhile, was designed by Emmanuel Gueit in 1993, and represents the next step in the evolution of the brand's signature creation. While sticking to the classic elements of the original Royal Oak, the Offshore takes its bold nature even further.

Created by Gerald Genta and like many of his famous watches, the Nautilus is a horological legend. Patek Philippe's most well known and desirable sports watch, it's celebrated for some of the best examples of emblematic Genta trademarks: large, angular bezel, comparatively thin case, integrated bracelet and bold, if straightforward, dial. The design is based on the traditional shape of portholes, up to and including the hinges often found on the sides—hence the Nautilus' unmistakable 'ears'. This model brings extra appeal in the form of a stunning movement with several additional complications: a small seconds, a power reserve indicator, and most impressively, a combined date and moonphase display.

This Rolex has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history. Many Panerai watches were made in relatively small production runs, but it's much more rare to find models that are officially limited. The PAM 005 represents just such a limited edition, and at a comparatively reasonable price. The watch is a close cousin of the beloved 000 “Base”, featuring the same desirable logo dial and painted numerals, which many collectors prefer to the classic “sandwich” dials (like the PAM 111, another close relative of the 005). This is a beautiful Luminor Marina with superb luminova, an understated small seconds subdial, and a gorgeous, COSC-certified movement.

When Buzz Aldrin stepped out of the lunar module, codenamed ‘Eagle’, and onto the powdery surface of the moon, the Omega Speedmaster on his wrist became the legendary Moonwatch. Tested to the limits by NASA for the rigours of space flight, the Speedmaster had in fact been into space before the testing had even begun. In October 1962, astronaut Wally Schirra took his own personal Speedmaster on board Sigma 7 and orbited Earth a total of six times for the Mercury 7 mission. The Speedmaster continued to provide NASA astronauts with invaluable service for the Apollo 13 mission, when it was used to time the crucial burn that would return the astronauts safely to Earth.

Named after the speedway track in Florida that hosts a legendary, Rolex-sponsored twenty-four hour race, the Daytona is the quintessential driver’s watch and was given a boost in popularity when Hollywood icon Paul Newman wore an early version of it. The dial, with its three subdials, is clear and easy to read while a tachymeter on the bezel offers quick speed calculations. It’s powered by Rolex’s Caliber 4130 automatic chronograph movement which holds a power reserve of 72 hours. Introduced in 1963 it’s been in continuous production ever since, although this particular reference is discontinued. Its smaller size and smart design makes it a versatile watch capable of working well with both casual jeans and a formal suit.

The Luminor design originated in the early 1950s, when Panerai finally decided to sell its prestigious watches to the civilian market—though it remained firmly rooted in the look and feel of the military watches of the '30s and '40s when the company was born. The new watches somewhat modernised the iconic look while remaining true to the brand's historical aesthetics, adding strong clean lines and new curves to the powerful cushion case, and a crown guard to boost muscle and water resistance. Here the legendary Luminor is available in all its classic glory, with a clear and legible dial boasting stunning luminova indices and hands.

Tudor has stepped out of the shadow of its older sister brand Rolex in recent years, offering watches that feature some of the hallmarks of its more illustrious sibling but at a more accessible price point. It forged its distinct personality largely by delving into its archives and reviving old models, including the Pelagos, a version of a Tudor Submariner from the 1970s. This model is powered by an MT5612 in-house calibre, which replaced the ETA movement of previous Pelagos models. It bears the now-iconic Tudor ‘snowflake’ hands, echoed in the square indexes, and the date is displayed in the window at 3 o’clock. The 42mm case is a blend of steel and titanium, while the bezel—also titanium—is coated in matt black ceramic. A handsome and versatile divers’ watch, it is water resistant to 500 metres, boasts a helium escape valve at 9 o’clock and holds a 70-hour power reserve.

This vintage-looking Seamaster 300 is a 60th Anniversary tribute to one of three classic timepieces released in 1957. Like all three watches in the trilogy, it is cased in brushed and polished stainless steel and features a beautiful black 'tropical' dial, with deepened dagger indexes filled with aged-looking Super-LumiNova, enhancing the retro aesthetic. The arrow hour hand is also delightfully retro, and is something shared by Omega’s collectible Ranchero model. It also bears an engraving of the 1957 Seahorse on the caseback. Limited to just 3,557 pieces, it is powered by the self-winding Master Chronometer 8806, featuring the lubricant-free co-axial escapement invented by the illustrious English horologist George Daniels. The power reserve is 55 hours and it is water-resistant to 200 metres.

A superb diving watch, TAG Heuer's Aquaracer was first launched in 2004 as an evolution of the equally superb Heuer 2000 divers conceived by Jack Heuer in the 1980s. The series was devoted to professionals and adventurers, as well as water-sportsmen of all kinds, and particularly sailors and yachtsmen. The watches have improved and evolved over the years, leading to a range of magnificent models like the one for sale here, with its unidirectional bezel, exceptionally legible design and superb finishing and craftsmanship. The piece maintains an excellent 300 meter water resistance, protecting the TAG Heuer Calibre 5 inside.

When Patek Philippe released the Aquanaut in 1997 it was considered part of the Gerald Genta-designed Nautilus collection and shared some of its famous design elements, including the rounded octagonal bezel that drew inspiration from a porthole. It was also the first Patek Philippe to come on a rubber strap. Having branched off from the Nautilus family and gone its own way, it’s now a popular watch within the brand’s catalogue and is perhaps its sportiest model, combining a dynamic and compact design with casual elegance. This flyback chronograph model is the first of its kind in white gold and pairs a gradient blue ‘grenade’ pattern dial with midnight-blue rubber strap. The sub-dial at 6 o’clock comprises the 60-minute counter and there’s a date aperture at 3 o’clock. It runs on the automatic Caliber CH 28-520 S C which holds a power reserve of up to 45 hours and is visible through the case back, revealing the 21k gold rotor engraved with the brand’s Calatrava cross. This is a versatile luxury sports watch that has seen its demand soar in recent years.

Created by Gerald Genta—and like many of his famous watches—the Nautilus is a horological legend. By far Patek Philippe's best known and most desirable sports watch, it's renowned for some of the best examples of emblematic Genta trademarks, large, angular bezel, comparatively thin case, integrated bracelet and bold, if simple, dial. The design is based on the traditional shape of portholes, up to and including the hinges often found on the sides—hence the Nautilus' unmistakable “ears”. This new example is particularly interesting for its unusual white dial that uses strong black borders on the hands and indexes to maintain the high contrast legibility we're used to, while adding a sporty new flavour.

High value watches such as this one remain in their sealed boxes due to a recent manufacturer service, ensuring they are not only protected but in the best possible condition when they reach the customer.

The Luminor 127 is a unique and very special watch in the Panerai pantheon, one close to the hearts of many collectors and affectionately nicknamed the “Fiddy”. First released in 2002, it is an uncanny recreation of a gorgeous vintage timepiece from 1950 (hence the limited edition number), and is known for many important features. For a start, it is 47mm in diameter, a large size with which the brand would subsequently become associated (some claim that Panerai were the ones who launched the whole oversize trend). Then there's the unique form of sandwich dial, rarely seen before, which combined with the crown guard and domed sapphire crystal to create an extremely cool aura of vintage Italian style—one that few others have achieved.

This beautiful dress watch from Jaeger-LeCoultre is not just exceptionally well-designed, with a clean, easily readable face and gorgeous case proportions, it also represents phenomenal value for money on its movement, which features several intricate complications. The watch, released in 2014 and inspired by a vintage 1945 piece from the JLC archives, has a moonphase and a complete calendar with displays for date, day of the week, and month. With all this, it still manages to maintain a refined, minimalist aesthetic based around a highly uncluttered dial—in large part thanks to the uncommon pointer-type date display around the dial's circumference.

In watch form, the Carrera has been in existence since 1964, when it continued Heuer’s great legacy in providing racing drivers with high quality timing instruments. Named after the intense ‘Carrera Panamericana’ road race of the 1950s (which also gave its name to the eponymous Porsche), the Carrera continues to provide timing for some of the world’s most prestigious racing teams today. This recent addition to the Carrera fold fully embodies that racing heritage while daring to forge its own path, boasting an energetic modern design with classic racing-red highlights, along with superb finishing and the excellent calibre 16 inside.

The Ballon Bleu, one of Cartier's newest watch collections, has been hugely successful since its 2007 release. With a unique, curving, organic case, a cleverly integrated sapphire crown and a multi-facetted guilloché dial, the watch can rightly be called a gem in every sense, blending the best of classical elegance and futuristic originality. Creating beauty through simplicity, the watch showcases everything that makes Cartier such a prestigious and highly-sought brand. This model uses a superb Swiss automatic movement underneath the traditional Roman numerals and blue sword hands on the dial. It's a timepiece that has to been seen in the flesh to get the full effect.

The Yacht-Master was originally introduced by Rolex in 1992—the first all-new model from the brand since the Daytona in 1964. The watch was designed for adventurers and sportsmen, like the topside equivalent of the diver's Submariner, to which it bears certain similarities. This version updates the classic model with extraordinary new materials. The bezel is black ceramic, the case is glorious 'Everose' gold (a unique Rolex alloy), and perhaps most exciting of all, the strap is made of rubber—a major first for Rolex—that the brand is calling 'Oysterflex'. In fact, it's not natural rubber but a special material known as elastomer. Inside, you'll find the stunning calibre 3135.

It's rare for Rolex to create completely new watch collections, but this is what happened in 2012 with the exceptional Sky-Dweller. It's not just the design that's new—the watch also features a complication never seen in a Rolex watch before, the annual calendar. This difficult mechanical addition has been ever-so-subtly integrated. The main way you will even notice it is when the date magically jumps after months with only 30 days. There's also a small indicator next to each hour marker; the white one shows the current month. This would all be remarkable in itself, but it's arguably overshadowed by the innovative new GMT display, occupying much of the central dial, and the even more innovative bezel. The latter has been upgraded with a “Ring Command” function that allows you to set the time and the other complications in a simple, intuitive fashion.

This Panerai has undergone a thorough inspection of accuracy, functionality and condition at our Panerai certified service centre to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been checked against our records to ensure authenticity. For many, Patek Philippe will always be the ultimate brand of the dress watch. The ancient and incredibly prestigious firm may be best remembered for its haute horlogerie elegance, but one mustn't forget its equal mastery in the realm of sports watches. And we don't just mean the Nautilus, which has been the iconic go-to Patek for many decades. Many collectors have realised that its younger brother, the wonderful Aquanaut, fulfils most of the same sterling credentials at a lower price. This model, the brand's most recent, is a particularly fine example, and features the extraordinary in-house movement 324 SC.

Like many of its iconic watch families, Rolex's Milgauss was created in 1956 with a specific market in mind: scientists, power station workers and anyone else exposed to high magnetic fields. It was designed to be able to resist fields up to 1,000 gauss (hence the name—“mille” is Latin for thousand). The watch built a solid reputation with only two models until 1988, and was happily revived two decades later in a modern re-edition that remains faithful to the original purpose and aesthetics—including the beloved lightning bolt hand. This gorgeous GV version (Glace Verte) has a green-tinted dial crystal, and uses a Parachrom-Blu hairspring for even better magnetic and shock resistance.

This watch is not just a classic Submariner—one of the most popular and iconic watches in the world—but a striking and highly collectible variant edition. The watch is easily recognisable thanks to its rare green bezel and dial, causing collectors to give it the affectionate nickname “Hulk”, although LV itself stands for Lunette Vert (“Green Bezel”). This larger version updates the previous LV model ref 16610 (called “Kermit”) that was originally introduced in 2003 for the 50th anniversary of the Submariner. This edition boasts ceramic inserts in the bezel, with numerals in platinum.

This exceptional chronograph from the Master Compressor collection of Jaeger-LeCoultre, one of Switzerland's most prestigious and desirable watch brands, has many stand-out features. The energetic-yet-elegant, red, white and black design is immediately attention grabbing, and closer inspection only reveals yet greater marvels. The watch is fitted with one of the first examples of JLC's cutting-edge shock absorbing system, using an air cushion to protect the exquisitely engineered movement. Calibre 752 is one of the brand's first in-house automatic chronographs, and uses a vertical coupling system for extreme precision. This example is even more remarkable for its extra complications, including the stunning world timer, showing the time in all 24 zones simultaneously.

Partnering with one of the biggest American companies of the last century, Pan American Airways, Rolex created a watch that was capable of telling the time in more than one place or time zone—the GMT-Master. In 1983 the updated GMT-Master II was released, gaining the nickname “The Fat Lady” due to its chunky case. Later, in 2005, Rolex redesigned and rereleased the GMT-Master on its 50th anniversary by launching the GMT-Master II. This new release became the first Rolex sport watch with the new, larger case and ceramic bezel—famed for its scratch resistance and immunity to fading. Its updated 3186 calibre boasted some improvements compared to the older 3185, making the hour hand a lot easier to set. It also featured a new hairspring which was a lot less sensitive to temperature changes and magnetism—perfect for flying and travelling, just as the original intended. This special GMT-Master II—made of white gold—is the sequel to the watch that introduced the much-anticipated Pepsi ceramic bezel, now coming with a blue dial instead of white, for this second generation run.

This technically superlative Ingenieur from IWC features a “double” or “split seconds” chronograph, one of the most difficult and challenging mechanical complications in high-end watchmaking. Where a regular chronograph simply records time elapsed between pushing the start and stop buttons, a split seconds chrono allows you to time laps or intermediate intervals. There are in fact two seconds hands, one of them ingeniously hidden behind the other; an extra pusher at 10 o'clock stops the first hand, recording the initial time, while the other seconds hand continues to run. As well as being mechanically impressive, this Double Chrono is also an imposing wear, with a large titanium case and bezel, five ceramic screws and a rubber-coated crown and pushers—all materials inspired by IWC's partnership with the Mercedes Formula One team.

Expanding on their hugely admired Heritage Black Bay series, Tudor released its Black Bay Fifty-Eight in 2018, inspired by the brand’s reference 7924 Oyster Prince Submariner, released in 1958—hence the name. Previously released Black Bays, still in production, had bigger cases—41mm, or even 43mm for the bronze model—but at 39mm the Black Bay Fifty-Eight is noticeably smaller and will suit those with a smaller wrist. A classic steel dive watch with a retro feel, including the faux-aged lume and distinctive red triangle on the aluminium bezel, this is a COSC-certified chronometer with 200m water resistance and an in-house movement—unlike the earliest Black Bays. Increasingly sought-after, this is a future classic that has further enhanced Tudor’s reputation and allowed it to step out of the shadow of its older sibling, Rolex.

The “California” style dial, famous for its combination of Roman numerals, Arabic numerals and regular indexes, as well as the lack of brand name or other lettering, was used in Panerai's very earliest watches from the 1930s. The name comes from a company in California that was known for refurbishing many such dials. The 448 is based very closely on the original prototype Californias commissioned in 1936 by the Royal Italian Navy. This modern version with superb finishing is particularly delightful thanks to the stunning case, authentic black dial and the blue hands and minute track that go so nicely with it.

Tudor has stepped out of the shadow of its older sister brand Rolex in recent years, offering watches that feature some of the hallmarks of its more illustrious sibling but at a more accessible price point. It forged its distinct personality largely by delving into its archives and reviving old models, including the Pelagos, a version of a Tudor Submariner from the 1970s. This left-hand winder is powered by an MT5612 in-house calibre, which replaced the ETA movement of previous Pelagos models. It bears the now-iconic Tudor ‘snowflake’ hands, echoed in the square indexes, and the date is displayed in the window at 3 o’clock. The 42mm case is a blend of steel and titanium, while the bezel—also titanium—is coated in matt black ceramic. A handsome and versatile divers’ watch, it is water resistant to 500 metres, boasts a helium escape valve at 3 o’clock and holds a 70-hour power reserve.

While this “Deep Two” watch is not the first IWC to feature a mechanical depth gauge—one of the most extraordinary complications you can find in a dive watch—it represents an evolution of the brand's previous model. The second generation of this super-practical diving family, the Deep Two can measure your current depth (up to 50 meters) as well as your max depth on a particular dive. The intuitive display functions more or less as a complete dive computer that can be used for any underwater calculations a diver needs to make. With excellent water- and shock-resistance, this is the ultimate tool for serious divers and horological enthusiasts alike.

The brainchild of legendary watch designer Gerald Genta, the Nautilus was introduced in 1976 to compete with Audemars Piguet’s Royal Oak, another now-iconic Genta-designed steel sports watch launched a few years earlier. Its case shape, with ear-like projections either side, was like nothing the industry had seen before and despite not being an immediate hit it’s now one of the most sought-after Patek models around, particularly the 5711 model which was discontinued in 2021. This version in 18ct rose gold features the signature horizontally embossed dial in a rich chocolate brown with rose gold hands and applied hour markers. The date window at 3 o'clock  is also framed with a rose gold border. This magnificent piece is powered by the automatic Caliber 324 S C which holds a power reserve of up to 45 hours. The movement is visible through the caseback, revealing the 21k gold rotor engraved with the brand’s Calatrava cross and decorated with côte de Genève stripes. This is a truly outstanding timepiece from the world's most illustrious watchmaker.

Released in 1953, the same year as the Submariner, Blancpain’s Fifty Fathoms was the brand’s first ever dive watch and was the result of a request by Captain Bob Maloubier, a British secret agent during World War II who later became leader of the French military’s diving corps. He asked that the watch be as clear as that of a “guiding star for a shepherd” and Blancpain duly delivered with a dial that was highly legible. The first ever Fifty Fathoms, like the first Submariner, was water resistant to 100 metres, but modern versions can withstand 300 metres. This version in a large 45mm, hand-polished rose gold case features a flying, one-minute tourbillon—visible through an aperture in the dial—which also has a pointed arm that serves as a small-seconds hand. The power reserve is 168 hours and the amount of reserve is shown via the display above 6 o’clock. Through the exhibition caseback is displayed the Caliber 25A automatic movement with skeletonised rotor. This is an exceptional version of an iconic dive watch from Switzerland’s oldest watchmaker.

The GMT Master was first commissioned in the 1950s by pioneering airline Pan Am, and was designed for aviation. An increase in flight distances created demand for a watch that was able to tell the time in two different parts of the world simultaneously, so Rolex built it with an additional hand that could be set to a second time zone. By the 1980s, the watch had developed into the GMT Master II and was already a favourite among collectors. This model represents a significant upgrade for the watch, boasting an aerospace-grade “superalloy” steel case and cerachrom inserts in the bezel. The LN moniker stands for Lunette Noir—signifying that it uses an all-black bezel.

The Rolex Daytona, named after the race circuit in Florida that hosts the Rolex twenty-four hour race, epitomises the ultimate driver’s watch. The dial, unburdened by a date window, is clear and easy to read. The tachymeter offers quick speed calculations, while the shape is instantly recognisable and supremely comfortable. Its smaller size and smart design makes it a versatile watch capable of working well with both casual jeans and a formal suit. Here available in steel with a stunning Cerachrom bezel, this watch represents the Daytona's first major upgrade in 16 years, but it sticks closely to the gorgeous retro design of the original.

The Ballon Bleu, one of Cartier's newest watch collections, has been hugely successful since its 2007 release. With a unique, curving, organic case, a cleverly integrated sapphire crown and a multi-facetted guilloché dial, the watch can rightly be called a gem in every sense, blending the best of classical elegance and futuristic originality. Creating beauty through simplicity, the watch showcases everything that makes Cartier such a prestigious and highly-sought brand. This model uses a superb Swiss automatic movement underneath the traditional Roman numerals and blue sword hands on the dial. It's a timepiece that has to been seen in the flesh to get the full effect.

Originally designed in 1971 for the admittedly niche market of cave explorers, the Rolex Explorer II was later updated to fit the aesthetic codes of the brand's other sports watch families. The watch builds on the heritage of the legendary Explorer I, which has always been a firm favourite among enthusiasts—the watch was first established in the public mind after its pioneering ascent of Everest during the expedition of Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay. Today the Explorer II deviates in some ways from the original look, but it continues to represent an exceptional, hardy, modernised tool watch with a top-of-the-range in-house movement and a design that does justice to its legacy in both sports and adventure.

Just like the Sea-Dweller, the Sky-Dweller is purpose-built for the elements—no surprises which element here. Custom made for the skies and pilots this watch, first released at Baselworld in 2012, will see you soaring through the air in style with its crisp white dial and yellow gold fluted bezel and case and the black rubber bracelet. Inside, the 326238 features the calibre 9001, a superlative performer from Rolex that is one of its most complex in-house movements to date. Featuring the Sky-Dweller’s famed second time zone display on the dial, as well as an annual calendar with date and month display, this piece is as useful as it is stunning—making it perfect for jetsetters and those leading a busy lifestyle.

Launched by Rolex in 1963 as a racing chronograph, the Daytona was initially a slow seller, but the post-quartz crisis revival of mechanical watches and a famous association with Hollywood legend Paul Newman—who wore a model bought for him by his wife—has seen it become hugely desirable. Indeed, Newman’s very own watch once held the record for the most expensive wristwatch sold at auction. Once a manual-wind watch that relied on outsourced movements, the Daytona has been automatic since 1988, and is now powered by Rolex’s in-house caliber 4130, a superlative chronometer that holds a power reserve of 72 hours. This white gold Daytona flaunts a stunning dial with a deep blue hue and white hour markers and branding, giving it an appealing understated look that oozes effortless cool.

The Omega Speedmaster has earned legendary status as the first watch to accompany NASA astronauts to the Moon. There are now countless variations of this timepiece but easily among the most collectible are the prized Snoopy limited editions. Presented by NASA to Omega in 1970, the Silver Snoopy Award was given to the brand for its contributions to “the success of human space flight missions”, while the reason it was named after the famous Peanuts cartoon-strip character was because of its role as an on-board mascot for the astronauts. This model celebrates the 45th anniversary of the award and features a Super-Luminova Snoopy himself on the seconds subdial at 9 o’clock, lying beneath a cartoon ‘thought bubble’ stating ‘Failure is not an option’ – a line from the film Apollo 13. The watch itself features the standard Speedmaster dial layout but in all white, with a black ceramic insert bezel and applique indices. This model, bearing a Snoopy engraving on the caseback, is limited to just 1,970 pieces and is powered by a manual calibre 1861 with 48-hour power reserve.

This masterful Radiomir from Panerai features a “double” or “split seconds” chronograph (also known as a rattrapante), one of the most difficult and challenging mechanical complications in high-end watchmaking. Where a regular chronograph simply records time elapsed between pushing the start and stop buttons, a split seconds chrono allows you to time laps or intermediate intervals. There are in fact two seconds hands, one of them ingeniously hidden; an extra pusher at 8 o'clock stops the first hand, recording the initial time, while the other hand continues to run. The PAM 214 uses the OP XVIII movement, based on a stunning and unusual column wheel Valjoux.

The Luminor as we know it originated in the early 1990s, when Panerai finally decided to sell its prestigious watches to the civilian market after more than 50 years as a military contractor. These watches somewhat modernised the iconic look while remaining true to the brand's historical aesthetics, adding strong clean lines and new curves to the powerful cushion case, and a crown guard to boost muscle and water resistance. Here the legendary Luminor is available in all its classic glory, staying remarkably true to its historic legacy.

Sleek, menacing and black as night, the PAM 441's dark allure is not the result of any external PVD or DLC. It's a fully ceramic case, much harder than steel and amazingly durable, the result of an exceptionally long and arduous process of diamond-wheel machining and microglass blasting to achieve the gorgeous matt finish. The material is too hard to mould and is originally created by extreme isostatic pressing of zirconium oxide followed by sintering at around 1,500°C. The beautiful in-house P.9000 movement has an impressive power reserve of three days and also features a GMT complication.

This Rolex has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history. Although best known for its Reverso collection, Jaeger-LeCoultre is one of a handful of Swiss bands consistently producing watches with high-prestige complications, such as tourbillons and perpetual calendars. This particular model is one of the highlights of its Master series, a stunning, open-face minute repeater in 18k rose gold with both power reserve and torque indicators on the left and right of the dial, respectively. Unusual for minute repeaters, which rely on a ‘closed’ watch to help amplify the sounds of the gongs, this is an open-face dial, allowing a rare view of this enchanting mechanism, which innovates by having the chiming gongs fused to the crystal. Limited to just 175 pieces, this discontinued watch, a hand-winder with sapphire caseback, is an exceptional piece and justifies JLC’s status as the ‘Watchmaker’s watchmaker’.

Designed by Emmanuelle Gueit to celebrate twenty years since the 1972 release of its now-iconic older brother, the Royal Oak, the Offshore range is said to have influenced the trend for oversized watches that began in the mid 1990s. Despite being very similar to its forebear, designed by Gerald Genta, the Royal Oak Offshore is bigger and bolder, often paired with tough rubber straps. This particular limited edition chronograph model comes in 18k rose gold, with rose gold Arabic numerals and hands on the brown dial which lies within a hefty 48mm case. Besides the three chronograph registers there is a date aperture at 3 o’clock and water resistance is 100 metres. The watch, which comes on a pin-buckle rubber strap, runs on the brand’s in-house self-winding Caliber 3126/3840 which has a power reserve of 55-60 hours. Just 350 pieces of this watch were made.

The brainchild of legendary watch designer Gerald Genta, the Nautilus was introduced in 1976 to compete with Audemars Piguet’s Royal Oak, another now-iconic Genta-designed steel sports watch launched a few years earlier. Its case shape, with ear-like projections either side, was like nothing the industry had seen before and despite not being an immediate hit it’s now one of the most sought-after Patek models around, particularly the 5711 model which was discontinued in 2021. This version in 18ct rose gold features the signature horizontally embossed dial in a rich chocolate brown with rose gold hands and applied hour markers. The date window at 3 o'clock  is also framed with a rose gold border. This magnificent piece is powered by the automatic Caliber 324 S C which holds a power reserve of up to 45 hours. The movement is visible through the caseback, revealing the 21k gold rotor engraved with the brand’s Calatrava cross and decorated with côte de Genève stripes. This is a truly outstanding timepiece from the world's most illustrious watchmaker.

If you're a big fan of Panerai, the legendary Italian watchmaker, chances are you've encountered Paneristi.com, the “unofficial resource” and forum where collectors and enthusiasts meet and discuss everything Panerai-related. In a spectacular gesture of good will towards its loyal supporters, the brand itself agreed to create a very limited run of watches in collaboration with the Paneristi site moderators themselves. PVD case, painted patina dial, OP logo, and even a special caseback inscription that commemorates the forum's 10th anniversary—this is the ultimate Panerai for collectors. Competition to own one couldn't have been more fierce.

Named after the speedway track in Florida that hosts a legendary, Rolex-sponsored twenty-four hour race, the Daytona is the quintessential driver’s watch and was given a boost in popularity when Hollywood icon Paul Newman wore an early version of it. The dial, with its three subdials, is clear and easy to read while a tachymeter on the bezel offers quick speed calculations. It’s powered by Rolex’s Caliber 4130 automatic chronograph movement which holds a power reserve of 72 hours. Introduced in 1963 it’s been in continuous production ever since, although this particular reference is discontinued. Its smaller size and smart design makes it a versatile watch capable of working well with both casual jeans and a formal suit.

The GMT Master was first commissioned in the 1950s by pioneering airline Pan Am, and was designed for aviation. An increase in flight distances created demand for a watch that was able to tell the time in two different parts of the world simultaneously, so Rolex built it with an additional hand that could be set to a second time zone. By the 1980s, the watch had developed into the GMT Master II and was already a favourite among collectors.

Many Panerai watches were made in relatively small production runs, but it's much more rare to find models that are officially limited. The PAM 005 represents just such a limited edition, and at a comparatively reasonable price. The watch is a close cousin of the beloved 000 “Base”, featuring the same desirable logo dial and painted numerals, which many collectors prefer to the classic “sandwich” dials (like the PAM 111, another close relative of the 005). This is a beautiful Luminor Marina with superb luminova, an understated small seconds subdial, and a gorgeous, COSC-certified movement.

This technically superlative IWC features a “double” or “split seconds” chronograph, one of the most difficult and challenging mechanical complications in high-end watchmaking. Where a regular chronograph simply records time elapsed between pushing the start and stop buttons, a split seconds chrono allows you to time laps or intermediate intervals. There are in fact two seconds hands, one of them ingeniously hidden; an extra pusher at 10 o'clock stops the first hand, recording the initial time, while the other seconds hand continues to run. The impressive complication is particularly welcome in IWC's wonderful Portuguese collection, long famed for its peerless elegance and classic aesthetics.

This exceptional diving watch from the Master Compressor collection of Jaeger-LeCoultre, one of Switzerland's most prestigious and desirable watch brands, has many stand-out features. The energetic-yet-elegant, blue, white and black design is immediately attention grabbing, and closer inspection only reveals yet greater marvels. Calibre 979 features a world timer GMT complication, showing the time in all 24 zones simultaneously, easily adjusted by the crown at 4. The crowns themselves boast an innovative “butterfly collar” design (as opposed to simple screw-down) that ensures water resistance. Most impressive, however, is the rare mechanical depth gauge on the left of the case, with the depth displayed up to 80m by the blue hand from the centre.

Invented in the 1930s as one of the first wristwatches made to be as precise as a marine chronometer, the Portuguese collection has a long history, though it wasn't produced in serious numbers until the 1990s. Today they are among IWC's finest watches, beloved by collectors for their graceful, uncluttered design and classic aesthetic featuring thin bezels and sword-like hands. This exquisite model runs on an automatic movement, IWC calibre 79240, with a superb chronograph mechanism. Adding a dash of sporting appeal to this elegant watch, the chrono display is subtly integrated and in no way detracts from the clean, sophisticated design.

The Altiplano collection is known for its extraordinary elegance and ultra-thin cases (a recent record-setting watch measured 3.65mm high). This “Double Jeu” model is no exception: while the total thinness is 11.7mm, this is spread across two stunning cases (both in rose gold). The top one flips on a subtly integrated hinge to reveal the second dial, each with its own movement. The lower uses the incredible 830P ultra-thin (just 2.5mm), while the upper has the 838P—the only difference being the small seconds dial and the ability to admire it through the middle caseback. Each dial has its own crown, allowing for multiple timezone settings, while the watch is opened by the latch at 3 o'clock.

Audemars Piguet sponsored the Alinghi Team at the world-famous America's Cup for most of the 2000s, including its major wins in 2003 and 2007. This watch was the last of the special editions made in honour of Alinghi, here seen in a stunningly rare and collectible gold version limited to just 600 pieces. The watch boasts a very special ten-minute countdown complication designed especially for use at regattas, and is also notable for being one of the first watches ever to make use of forged carbon in the phenomenal bezel. This cutting-edge material, pioneered by Audemars Piguet, is even stronger and lighter than most kinds of carbon fibres.

Added to the beloved Aquatimer collection just last year, this new watch represents a significant step forward for IWC's divers in a number of respects. First and foremost, the watch has been widely acclaimed for its innovative external/internal bezel. Using a special clutch system positioned to look like a left hand crown, the bezel is set by unidirectional rotation as normal, in a manner that combines the ease of outer bezels with the safety advantages of inner ones. Then there's the water resistance—the watch can cope with pressures up to 30 bar, more than double its previous specs. Finally, there's the updated appearance. Effortlessly legible, clean and elegant, the chronograph is nevertheless a rugged and imposing 44mm sports watch in striking monochrome.

As part of the Windrider series, the Cockpit combines the best of Breitling design in a smaller, more elegant case. Many other Breitlings are too large for some people to wear comfortably, so this 41mm case size makes a refreshing change for those who like the brand but don’t want an oversized watch—and the 14mm height is also not unwieldy. Much more rarely encountered on the market than other Breitling watch families, the Cockpit cuts to the core of the brand's aviation-based appeal, while updating the design with the best of modern manufacturing. As with every Breitling, the build quality and finish are fantastic. The gold elements on the case and dial of this model are particularly attractive.

The modern Luminor design originated in the early 1990s, when Panerai finally decided to sell its prestigious watches to the civilian market after more than 50 years as a military-only contractor. Three limited edition pieces created at this time set the style for what would soon become modern Luminor. It somewhat modernised the 1940s-era look while remaining true to the brand's historical aesthetics, adding strong clean lines and new curves to the distinctive cushion case, and a crown guard to boost water resistance. This lovely example has an in-house movement, the P.3002, with a power reserve of three days that is displayed in a sophisticated retrograde indicator on the dial.

The brainchild of legendary watch designer Gerald Genta, the Nautilus was introduced in 1976 to compete with Audemars Piguet’s Royal Oak, another now-iconic Genta-designed steel sports watch launched a few years earlier. Its case shape, with ear-like projections either side, was like nothing the industry had seen before and despite not being an immediate hit it’s now one of the most sought-after Patek models around. The 5990/1A, now discontinued, enhances an already remarkable watch with a host of extremely useful functions, comprising a second time zone—with a day and night indicator for both local and home zones—a date, displayed on the sub dial between 11 and 1 o’clock, subsidiary seconds and a flyback chronograph. Stainless steel, with a horizontally embossed black dial and white gold applied hour markers, it exudes high-end luxury and is powered by the automatic Caliber 28-520 S C FUS which holds a power reserve of 45 hours. The movement is visible through the case back, revealing the 21k gold rotor engraved with the brand’s Calatrava cross and decorated with côte de Genève stripes.

Originally designed in 1971 for the admittedly niche market of cave explorers, the Rolex Explorer II was later updated to fit the aesthetic codes of the brand's other sports watch families. Reference 16550 is one of only three Explorer II variants since the first one, and also one of the rarest. It was in production for just one and a half or two years starting in 1985, and offered an improved, simpler look, new dial colours, GMT functionality and the first sapphire crystal in an Explorer.

When Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay became the first people to reach the summit of Everest in 1953, their expedition team were supplied with watches by Rolex and the British company Smith’s. Rolex designed a watch specifically for the expedition, which came to be known as the Explorer, one of the less prominent models in the Rolex stable but one that has been a constant since its launch. A far plainer looking watch back then, the Explorer aesthetic is now characterised by the Mercedes hour hand, three-quarter numeral black dial and Oyster bracelet. This model, with a 36mm case, is the first to come in two-tone steel and yellow gold and runs on a Caliber 3230 which holds a power reserve of almost 70 hours.

Bremont describes the Supermarine collection as “divers watches inspired by our aviation principles”. This doesn't mean the Supermarine is a pilot's watch, but rather a traditional, good-looking and high-grade diver that is—at heart—a Bremont. Demonstrating the brand's no-nonsense British clarity and effortless sense of refinement, the Supermarine also boasts the impressive technical credentials for which Bremont, a relatively small independent brand, is rightly acclaimed. The watch uses Bremont's anti-shock mount, a Faraday cage and a helium escape valve to make itself seriously durable, with this limited edition further fortified by a DLC coating. Meanwhile, accuracy is guaranteed by the Swiss chronometer inside, lovingly embellished and assembled in Bremont's Henley factory.

Due to age, this Tag Heuer may not fall within our typical expected tolerances for timekeeping, and is no longer suitable for use in wet environments or submersion in water. In the interests of preserving original features, utmost care has been taken to sympathetically restore this watch. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history.

The Cartier Tank, inspired by an actual tank, has been a design milestone since its inception in the early 20th century. Unlike the modified pocket watches being made by other manufacturers, the Tank used a new case design that actually incorporated the lugs into its shape, rather than adding them as an afterthought. Other iconic design elements include the blued sword hands, Roman numerals, elegant square dial and octagonal crown complete with sapphire cabochon. The Française collection adds a somewhat sportier, more modern feel to an already superb timepiece, making it bolder and more versatile, in large part thanks to its chain-link bracelet.

This Tudor has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. The classic Explorer I has always been a firm favourite amongst enthusiasts, its heritage and good looks being very hard to resist. Established in the public mind after Rolex’s involvement in the pioneering ascent of Everest with Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay, the Explorer I has a delightfully clear, readable face, uncluttered by a date complication. The case is smoother and more rounded than other Rolex sports models, even more so than it initially appears.

The watch is limited edition and was created as a tribute to the legendary pilot's watch, the 'Cairelli' CP2 .

This re-edition timepiece stays true to the aesthetic and size of the original CP2, which was first produced for the Italian Air Force in the 1960's, by the watchmaker A.Cairelli. The watch features a bi-directional bezel and lumed hands on a matte black dial, making the piece as functional as a pilots watch as the original timepiece. 

The vintage style pump pushers and applied Zenith pointed star on the dial complete the aesthetic of the piece, an accurate and detailed re-edition of a much loved vintage pilot's watch.

The Rolex Daytona, named after the race circuit in Florida that hosts the Rolex twenty-four hour race, epitomises the ultimate driver’s watch. The dial, unburdened by a date window, is clear and easy to read. The tachymeter offers quick speed calculations, while the shape is instantly recognisable and supremely comfortable. Its smaller size and smart design makes it a versatile watch capable of working well with both casual jeans and a formal suit. Here available in steel with a stunning Cerachrom bezel, this watch represents the Daytona's first major upgrade in 16 years, but it sticks closely to the gorgeous retro design of the original.

One of the most iconic vintage watches of the 20th century, the Heuer Monaco achieved a legendary status primarily for three reasons: for its innovative, square-cased design; for being the first watch to house the famous calibre 11, one of the very first automatic chronograph movements in history; and for its association with cult actor Steve McQueen, who wore the watch during the filming of the great 1972 motorsports film Le Mans, personifying the timeless cool of the classic race car era. This superb modern Monaco model remains exceptionally faithful to the original style of the watch's heyday.

A superb diving watch, TAG Heuer's Aquaracer was first launched in 2004 as an evolution of the equally superb Heuer 2000 diver conceived by Jack Heuer in the 1980s. The series was devoted to professionals and adventurers, as well as water-sportsmen of all kinds, and particularly sailors and yachtsmen. The watches have improved and evolved over the years, leading to a range of magnificent models like the one for sale here, with its 300m water resistance, big date and chronograph functionality. Impressively, there's a tenth of a second counter at 6 o'clock, which is testament to the exceptional reliability and accuracy of the caliber inside.

column21: There are many travellers watches with GMT complications, but having an alarm function accompanying it on a gorgeous mechanical timepiece like this is considerably more rare. The alarm function has an intuitive setting system via one of the dual crowns, and produces a distinctive buzzing sound. Many watches with an extra time zone display can start to look cluttered, but this phenomenal timepiece retains its stylish Panerai look with a brilliant design that places the GMT indication in a subtle 24-hour wheel window in the bottom of the dial. All this is thanks to the extraordinary Girard-Perregaux movement, Calibre 59, which is based on the AS 5008 (later the La Joux-Perret 5900).

When Patek Philippe released the Aquanaut in 1997 it was considered part of the Gerald Genta-designed Nautilus collection and shared some of its famous design elements, including the rounded octagonal bezel that drew inspiration from a porthole. It was also the first Patek Philippe to come on a rubber strap. Having branched off from the Nautilus family and gone its own way, it’s now a popular watch within the brand’s catalogue and is perhaps its sportiest model, combining a dynamic and compact design with casual elegance. This model, with a khaki grenade-pattern dial featuring applied Arabic numerals in white gold, comes on a matching green rubber strap. The white gold case, a fraction over 42mm, houses the automatic Caliber 324 S C which holds a power reserve of up to 45 hours. The movement is visible through the case back, revealing the 21k gold rotor engraved with the brand’s Calatrava cross and decorated with côte de Genève stripes.

Named after the speedway track in Florida that hosts a legendary, Rolex-sponsored twenty-four hour race, the Daytona is the quintessential driver’s watch and was given a boost in popularity when Hollywood icon Paul Newman wore an early version of it. The dial, with its three subdials, is clear and easy to read while a tachymeter on the bezel offers quick speed calculations. It’s powered by Rolex’s Caliber 4130 automatic chronograph movement which holds a power reserve of 72 hours. Introduced in 1963 it’s been in continuous production ever since, although this particular reference is discontinued. Its smaller size and smart design makes it a versatile watch capable of working well with both casual jeans and a formal suit.

The Rolex Daytona, named after the race circuit in Florida that hosts the Rolex twenty-four hour race, epitomises the ultimate driver’s watch. The dial, unburdened by a date window, is clear and easy to read. The tachymeter offers quick speed calculations, while the shape is instantly recognisable and supremely comfortable. Its smaller size and smart design makes it a versatile watch capable of working well with both casual jeans and a formal suit. Here available in steel with a stunning Cerachrom bezel, this watch represents the Daytona's first major upgrade in 16 years, but it sticks closely to the gorgeous retro design of the original.

The Rolex Daytona, named after the race circuit in Florida that hosts the Rolex 24-hour race, epitomises the ultimate driver’s watch. The dial, unburdened by a date window, is clear and easy to read. The tachymeter offers quick speed calculations, while the shape is instantly recognisable and supremely comfortable. Its size and smart design makes it a versatile watch capable of working well with both casual jeans and a formal suit. This model is particularly well-known for its flawless good looks, featuring Rolex's unique and glorious gold alloy, called 'Everose'.

Launched by Rolex in 1963 as a racing chronograph, the Daytona was initially a slow seller, but the post-quartz crisis revival of mechanical watches and a famous association with Hollywood legend Paul Newman—who wore a model bought for him by his wife—has seen it become hugely desirable. Indeed, Newman’s very own watch once held the record for the most expensive wristwatch sold at auction. Once a manual-wind watch that relied on outsourced movements, the Daytona has been automatic since 1988, and is now powered by Rolex’s in-house caliber 4130, a superlative chronometer that holds a power reserve of 72 hours. With a black and gold colourway, this Daytona offers an understated bit of bling via its yellow gold case, as well as some additional sporty appeal thanks to its comfortable black rubber strap.

The Royal Oak was an industry revelation on its release in 1972, becoming the first luxury steel sports watch—with a luxury price to match. Probably Gerald Genta’s most famous watch design, it stood in stark contrast to other watches owing to its octagonal bezel and robust integrated bracelet, one of the most distinctive ever designed. This stunning chronograph version in striking 18-carat yellow gold is now discontinued and features a silvered tapisserie dial, giving it  exquisite depth and texture, together with gold details including the hands and markers. The three sub-dials feature hours, minutes and small seconds, and there’s also a date aperture between 4 and 5 o’clock. It runs on an AP Caliber 2385 automatic movement which holds a power reserve of around 40 hours. A high-quality black alligator strap enhances the look of unbridled luxury with which this now-iconic watch is synonymous.

The ref 6263 is one of the most coveted models from the most desirable watch family of all time: the Rolex Daytona. Rolex manufactured the 6263 from 1971 to 1988 in relatively low numbers. It features an evolution of the iconic screw-down pushers, first seen in ref 6240, that gave the Cosmograph such strong water resistance, and which gives the 6263 its distinct Daytona 'look'. It runs on the workhorse Valjoux 72 movement, making the watch more than durable enough for everyday wear, despite its remarkable vintage.

The hour markers and hands echo the rose gold case and are applied with luminescent coating for night or low-light visibility. The automatic movement within is the brand’s own calibre 2329-2846.

The Rotonde De Cartier offers a stark contrast to the traditional, small rectangular cases with which this brand is synonymous. It features a 40mm circular case and beautiful tourbillon on the dial—a rare example of the famed French jeweller letting its hair down. The Rotonde collection consists primarily of watches with added complications, hence the flying tourbillon seen here. Made in a stunning rose gold, the reference W1556215 houses the hand-wound calibre 9452 MC, while boasting a celebrated Geneva Seal and 142 parts and 19 jewels and a frequency of 21600 vph—all visible through the open case back. This watch is an impressive piece that is sure to turn heads with its elegant and refined looks, while displaying the very best of Cartier’s watchmaking skills.

column21: Launched by Rolex in 1963 as a racing chronograph, the Daytona was initially a slow seller, but the post-quartz crisis revival of mechanical watches and a famous association with Hollywood legend Paul Newman—who wore a model bought for him by his wife—has seen it become hugely desirable. Indeed, Newman’s very own watch once held the record for the most expensive wristwatch sold at auction. Once a manual-wind watch that relied on outsourced movements, the Daytona has been automatic since 1988, and is now powered by Rolex’s in-house caliber 4130, a superlative chronometer that holds a power reserve of 72 hours. This glitzy Daytona features a white gold case with a diamond-studded bezel and a white mother-of-pearl dial that boasts even more diamonds via the hour markers. This is a unique Daytona perfect for those into bedazzling timepieces.

The unmistakeable Luminor case, launched in 1993, was later joined by the 1950 case, introduced in 2002— inspired by the Panerai model from 1950, hence the name. A limited-edition piece of just 100 watches released, this 1950 features the in-house P.2005/B calibre movement, which boasts Panerai’s patented cage technology. This movement contains the balance wheel and escapement which rotates on an axis perpendicular to the balance, not parallel with it. This cuts the usual amount of time for a complete revolution from sixty seconds to just thirty. This reference also boasts hours, minutes, small seconds, GMT, 24-hour indicator, six-day power reserve indicator visible through the case back and a tourbillon—all presented in a slick, black ceramic case.

Self-proclaimed specialists in the “art of fusion”, Hublot shook up the watch world back in 2015 with its new Big Bang Tourbillion 5-Day Power Reserve Indicator. The tourbillion complication is on full display thanks to the striking, skeletonised dial, which is encased in either titanium or 18k King Gold—depending on personal preference. A limited edition watch with only 99 pieces ever made, this is hugely sought after by Hublot aficionados. After the appointment of CEO Jean-Claude Biver in 2004, Hublot released their new Big Bang series, with the objective to modernise the brand with this new, flagship collection. Unveiled at Basel in 2005, the Big Bang certainly lived up to its name, gathering a mass of fans and great acclaim. The series takes inspiration from Hublot’s original 1980 launch model, featuring the now-familiar porthole-inspired round bezel, exposed screws and rubber strap—all of which are synonymous with Hublot today.

This exceptional and rarely seen Breguet tourbillon and 24-hour power reserve comes from Breguet's “Classique Complication” family of truly extraordinary complex timepieces, known for fusing the very best of aesthetic and technical beauty With these astonishing timepieces, mostly released in highly limited editions, the company demonstrates its continuing command of its founder Abraham-Louis Breguet's greatest talent: utter mechanical mastery. This particular watch features a gorgeous platinum case and an exquisite engine-turned dial, as well as several impressive complications including an integrated seconds hand tourbillon at 6 o'clock (symmetrically mirroring the main display above) and retrograde indicators for the power reserve and AM/PM to the left and right respectively. The overall effect is one of classical harmony and breathtaking horological proficiency.

From the brand founded by arguably the greatest watchmaker ever—Louis Breguet—the Breguet Tradition 7047BR/G9/9ZU was introduced at 2012’s Baselworld. The Tradition 7047BR Tourbillon Fusee and Chain is one of the watchmaker’s most interesting watches to date. This is in part down to the 7047BR movement and its unique configuration—it is exposed on the dial side of the watch instead of the usual case back side—plus, it is protected by a tall domed sapphire crystal, which adds to its aesthetic appeal. The Tradition 7047BR comes in a 41 mm 18kt white gold or rose gold case, which is fully polished with Breguet’s signature finely fluted caseband. The dial comes in black-coated, engine-turned 18kt gold and is off-centred at 7 o’clock, while a 60-second tourbillon sits at 1 o’clock. The hand-wound manufacture movement, calibre 569, is anthracite coated and features a tourbillon and a constant force fusee and chain transmission. This Breguet is perfect for lovers of unusual watches and the industrial aesthetic.

The Rolex Daytona, named after the race circuit in Florida that hosts the Rolex twenty-four hour race, epitomises the ultimate driver’s watch. The dial, unburdened by a date window, is clear and easy to read. The tachymeter offers quick speed calculations, while the shape is instantly recognisable and supremely comfortable. Its smaller size and smart design makes it a versatile watch capable of working well with both casual jeans and a formal suit. Here available in steel with a stunning Cerachrom bezel, this watch represents the Daytona's first major upgrade in 16 years, but it sticks closely to the gorgeous retro design of the original.

This watch is not just a classic Submariner—one of the most popular and iconic watches in the world—but a striking and highly collectible variant edition. The watch is easily recognisable thanks to its rare green bezel and dial, causing collectors to give it the affectionate nickname “Hulk”, although LV itself stands for Lunette Vert (“Green Bezel”). This larger version updates the previous LV model ref 16610 (called “Kermit”) that was originally introduced in 2003 for the 50th anniversary of the Submariner. This edition boasts ceramic inserts in the bezel, with numerals in platinum.

Zenith won global acclaim in 1969 when it beats its rivals to launch the world’s first automatically wound wristwatch chronograph movement. It named the watch ‘El Primero’— meaning ‘the first’ — and it remains the brand’s most recognisable watch, with numerous versions available. This all-black ‘Spindrift’ model is named after a team that participates in catamaran sailboat racing and comes in a steel-coated, matt-black DLC (Diamond-Like Carbon) case, making it extremely scratch-resistant. The carbon-fibre dial opens up at 10 o’clock to reveal the escapement and there are dual chronograph counters: the 30-minute counter at 3 o’clock and the 12-hour counter at 6 o’clock. ‘Spindrift Racing’ is inscribed on the internal bezel and the team’s logo features on the rotor, seen through the exhibition caseback. Inside you’ll find Zenith’s 4061 El Primero calibre, while the power reserve is 50 hours.

This superb, understated Radiomir features Panerai's special ceramic case material. It's called “composite” instead of ceramic to differentiate it from the ceramics of other watchmakers, which are typically made with a zirconium base. Panerai's is created by electrochemical processes using aluminium, making it harder and tougher than other ceramics, not to mention lighter than even titanium. Not only is the watch made with unique, cutting edge materials, but it also features a highly prestigious in-house movement. P.3000 has a power reserve of three days and a allows the hour to be set in discrete jumps without interfering with the workings of the seconds or minutes.

The Luminor as we know it originated in the early 1990s, when Panerai finally decided to sell its prestigious watches to the civilian market after more than 50 years as a military contractor. Three limited edition pieces created at this time set the style for what would soon become Luminor. It somewhat modernised the 1940s-era look while remaining true to the brand's historical aesthetics, adding strong clean lines and new curves to the distinctive cushion case, and a crown guard to boost muscle and water resistance. Here the legendary Luminor is available in all its classic glory, with a a specialised GMT function and an impressive three-day power reserve, thanks to the stunning in-house movement P.9001.

The Luminor design originated in the early 1990s, when Panerai finally decided to sell its prestigious watches to the civilian market—though it remained firmly rooted in the look and feel of the military watches of the '30s and '40s when the company was born. The new watches somewhat modernised the iconic look while remaining true to the brand's historical aesthetics, adding strong clean lines and new curves to the powerful cushion case, and a crown guard to boost muscle and water resistance. Here the legendary Luminor is available in all its classic glory, with a clear and legible dial boasting stunning luminova indices and hands.

The PAM 569 “Titanio” is a wonderful example of that rare beast in Panerai legend: the left-handed Luminor. Confusingly, Panerai calls these watches “destro”—Italian for “right”. That's because the watch is designed to be worn on the right hand, hence placing the crown on the left. However, this extraordinary limited edition is even more standout than other destro pieces like the 026. Hailing from the brand's impressive Submersible series, this is a rugged, practical titanium diving watch with a handsome, muscular aesthetic. The positioning of the date window at 9 o'clock accentuates the originality of the destro design, which is further perfected with the faux-patina luminova and hobnail dial, not to mention the superb in-house calibre P.9000.

Sleek, menacing and black as night, the PAM 441's dark allure is not the result of any external PVD or DLC. It's a fully ceramic case, much harder than steel and amazingly durable, the result of an exceptionally long and arduous process of diamond-wheel machining and microglass blasting to achieve the gorgeous matt finish. The material is too hard to mould and is originally created by extreme isostatic pressing of zirconium oxide followed by sintering at around 1,500°C. The beautiful in-house P.9000 movement has an impressive power reserve of three days and also features a GMT complication.

Added to the beloved Aquatimer collection just last year, this new watch represents a significant step forward for IWC's divers in a number of respects. First and foremost, the watch has been widely acclaimed for its innovative external/internal bezel. Using a special clutch system positioned to look like a left hand crown, the bezel is set by unidirectional rotation as normal, in a manner that combines the ease of outer bezels with the safety advantages of inner ones. Then there's the water resistance—the watch can cope with pressures up to 30 bar, more than double its previous specs. Finally, there's the updated appearance. Effortlessly legible, clean and elegant, the chronograph is nevertheless a rugged and imposing 46mm sports watch with a silver, black and yellow colour scheme inspired by the brand's work in the Galapagos Islands.

TAG Heuer's Calibre 12 LS automatic chronograph is remarkable for many reasons. The most immediately striking is the gorgeous racing watch design based on the iconic shape of the Monaco, one of the best loved drivers' watches in the world. But the Calibre 12 is not just a pretty red, white and black face. It has also developed an innovative and stunning new way of showing the time: the LS “linear system”, which gives many of the subdials a resemblance to classic dashboard indicators. At the top is the date window, where a whole section of the wheel is purposely visible. Then there's the unique retrograde seconds at 3 o'clock, which uses different coloured “hands” to show half a minute in a line, one after another. Finally the two chronograph counters: hours at 6 o'clock is comparatively conventional, while the 30 minute counter at 9 o'clock is a speedometer; like the seconds, two hands count 15 minutes each. The effect is breathtaking.

column21: Hublot burst onto the Swiss watchmaking scene in 1980 with the most groundbreaking new design that the industry had seen in years. The idea was simple: a luxury gold watch made in the bold “porthole” style, but fitted with a rubber bracelet. The idea of “Fusion” was born—and innovative combinations of materials have remained a key part of the Hublot brand ever since. This extra special piece harks back to Fusion with a glorious skeletonised design that allows for a spectacular view of the ultra-thin movement and its 90-hour power reserve. As ever, the materials are remarkable: there's a stunning titanium case, bezel and screws, a ruthenium anthracite mainplate and bridges, all paired with a fine leather strap.

Tudor has stepped out of the shadow of its older sister brand Rolex in recent years, offering watches that feature some of the hallmarks of its more illustrious sibling but at a more accessible price point. It forged its distinct personality largely by delving into its archives and reviving old models, including the Pelagos, a version of a Tudor Submariner from the 1970s. This model is powered by an MT5612 in-house calibre, which replaced the ETA movement of previous Pelagos models. It bears the now-iconic Tudor ‘snowflake’ hands, echoed in the square indexes, and the date is displayed in the window at 3 o’clock. The 42mm case is a blend of steel and titanium, while the bezel—also titanium—is coated in matt black ceramic. A handsome and versatile divers’ watch, it is water resistant to 500 metres, boasts a helium escape valve at 9 o’clock and holds a 70-hour power reserve.

The Luminor as we know it originated in the early 1990s, when Panerai finally decided to sell its prestigious watches to the civilian market after more than 50 years as a military contractor. Three limited edition pieces created at this time set the style for what would soon become Luminor. It somewhat modernised the 1940s-era look while remaining true to the brand's historical aesthetics, adding strong clean lines and new curves to the distinctive cushion case, and a crown guard to boost muscle and water resistance. Here the legendary Luminor is available in all its classic glory, with a a specialised GMT function and an impressive three-day power reserve, thanks to the stunning in-house movement P.9001.

The Royal Oak Offshore raised eyebrows on its release in 1993 due to its hefty case size of 42mm. So much so it was quickly nicknamed ‘The Beast’. This 2010 release of the iconic Royal Oak Offshore is no exception, featuring a rugged, rose gold octagonal carbon fibre bezel. Audemars Piguet experimented with materials, opting for ones that are known for their high durability, relative lightness, and scratch-resistance: namely, forged carbon fibre and ceramic and a mix of carbon fibre on the case and lugs with a natural alligator leather strap—something more synonymous with fellow Swiss watchmaker Hublot. Boasting a tourbillion chronograph complication, visible through the skeletonised dial, this Royal Oak Offshore makes for an interesting piece within Audemars’ catalogue.

Long known as the “Moonwatch”, Omega's Speedmaster became an instant legend in the 1960s when it was chosen by NASA for official use in space, including the Gemini and Apollo programmes. But it was not originally designed for such a use. So in 1969, Omega produced a new, even more qualified watch—the Speedmaster MkII—for space missions. With a distinctive, tapered case, it came with either a regular black dial or the rarer “racing” dial. Unfortunately, the MkII was rejected by the astronauts for superstitious reasons and seemed destined to fade into the shadows of history until, happily, Omega re-released a modern version more recently. This watch, however, is the original model in all its vintage glory.
