It has also been checked against our records to ensure authenticity. Our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind, in conjunction with any remaining manufacturer’s warranty from new or from service.

The Cartier Tank has been a design milestone since its inception in the early 20th century. Unlike the modified pocket watches being made by other manufacturers, the Tank used a new case design—inspired by the shape of a tank—that actually incorporated the lugs into its shape, rather than adding them as an afterthought. Other iconic design elements include the blued sword hands, Roman numerals, elegant square dial and octagonal crown complete with sapphire cabochon. The Française collection adds a somewhat sportier, more modern feel to an already superb timepiece, making it bolder and more versatile, in large part thanks to its chain-link bracelet.

The classic Explorer I has always been a firm favourite amongst enthusiasts, its heritage and good looks being very hard to resist. Established in the public mind after Rolex’s involvement in the pioneering ascent of Everest with Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay, the Explorer I has a delightfully clear, readable face, uncluttered by a date complication. The case is smoother and more rounded than other Rolex sports models, even more so than it initially appears.

This Panerai Radiomir is 1 of 1000 made and features a ‘tropical’ dial. 
The watch’s dial has been fashioned to resemble the patina seen on vintage Panerai watches which have suffered the effects of radioactive exposure. The Radiomir paint in the vintage watches emitted gamma rays, from the radioactive Radium, and aged the watch in a fashion which turned the originally black paint to a light brown colour. 
Brevetatto, the Italian for patented, is inscribed around the bezel and refers to the design of the watch which adheres to a vintage aesthetic, Panerai have used a 12-sided bezel like those found on prototype watches from the 1930’s.

This Breitling has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history. Our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind, in conjunction with any remaining manufacturer’s warranty from new or from service.

The “California” style dial, famous for its combination of Roman numerals, Arabic numerals and regular indexes, as well as the lack of brand name or other lettering, was used in Panerai's very earliest watches from the 1930s. The name comes from a company in California that was known for refurbishing many such dials. The 424 is based very closely on the original prototype Californias commissioned in 1936 by the Royal Italian Navy. This modern version with superb finishing is particularly delightful thanks to the stunning case, rich brown hue and the gold hands and minute track that go so nicely with it.

The GMT Master was first commissioned in the 1950s by pioneering airline Pan Am, and was designed for aviation. An increase in flight distances created demand for a watch that was able to tell the time in two different parts of the world simultaneously, so Rolex built it with an additional hand that could be set to a second time zone. By the 1980s, the watch had developed into the GMT Master II and was already a favourite among collectors. This model represents a significant upgrade for the watch, boasting an aerospace-grade steel case and cerachrom inserts in the bezel. A variant on the regular 116710, this reference features gold elements in the bezel, crown, hands, indices and of course the bracelet.

This Rolex has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history. All our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind.

When Buzz Aldrin stepped out of the lunar module, codenamed ‘Eagle’, and onto the powdery surface of the moon, the Omega Speedmaster on his wrist became the legendary Moonwatch. Tested to the limits by NASA for the rigours of space flight, the Speedmaster had in fact been into space before the testing had even begun. In October 1962, astronaut Wally Schirra took his own personal Speedmaster on board Sigma 7 and orbited Earth a total of six times for the Mercury 7 mission. The Speedmaster continued to provide NASA astronauts with invaluable service for the Apollo 13 mission, when it was used to time the crucial burn that would return the astronauts safely to Earth.

Named after Lake Geneva, the Blancpain Léman collection seeks to capture the evocative natural beauty of this iconic landmark, as well as its proximity to the heart of Swiss watchmaking heritage. With a strong grasp of traditional designs, the Léman watches are classic and authoritative, while simultaneously contemporary and refreshing. This stunning model, known as the Réveil GMT, is notable for its superb mechanical calibre (visible through the caseback), featuring a range of prestigious complications. These include a second timezone and power reserve display, and perhaps most impressive of all, a mechanical alarm.

Though they were not a mainstay of the company's catalogue until the 1990s, IWC's Portuguese watches originated as consummate maritime chronometers in the early part of the 20th century, and have established a long and outstanding history of both mechanical and design elegance. Now, the Portuguese has been united with IWC's superb 50000 series of movements (this version houses the 50900), with many exceptional features: a seven-day power reserve that ingeniously stops itself when torque runs low, an escape wheel identical to that of the iconic calibre 89, the brand's hallmark Pellaton pawl-winding system and best of all, a glorious Tourbillon Mystere at 12 o'clock.

This watch is not just a classic Submariner—one of the most popular and iconic watches in the world—but a striking and highly collectible variant edition. The watch is easily recognisable thanks to its rare green bezel and dial, causing collectors to give it the affectionate nickname “Hulk”, although LV itself stands for Lunette Vert (“Green Bezel”). This larger version updates the previous LV model ref 16610 (called “Kermit”) that was originally introduced in 2003 for the 50th anniversary of the Submariner. This edition boasts ceramic inserts in the bezel, with numerals in platinum.

The Luminor as we know it originated in the early 1990s, when Panerai finally decided to sell its prestigious watches to the civilian market after more than 50 years as a military contractor. These watches somewhat modernised the iconic look while remaining true to the brand's historical aesthetics, adding strong clean lines and new curves to the powerful cushion case, and a crown guard to boost muscle and water resistance. Here the legendary Luminor is available in all its classic glory, staying remarkably true to its historic legacy.

Named after the quaint Alpine village where the company's workshops are located, the Villeret collection undoubtedly comprises Blancpain's most classic and elegant watches. Like the town of Villeret itself, the watches are rooted in the oldest and most admirable qualities of Swiss watchmaking. The aesthetic is understated but confident in its exquisite design and finishing of premium quality materials. All of Blancpain's 300 years of experience at the very highest levels of haute horlogerie is brought to bear in this beautiful series. This particularly excellent model features a complete set of calendar and moonphase complications, marking it as a superb example of high-end mechanical accomplishment.

This Bremont has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. The Seamaster is one of the most iconic diving watches of all time. By the 1950s, it was among the most dependable and professionally sought dive watches from any brand, and it soon pioneered some of the sporty must-have features we associate with such watches, including unidirectional bezels, phosphorescent hands and the helium escape valve. The year 2005 saw the launch of a modern classic: the Seamaster Planet Ocean. This collection bursts with innovative style and energy, its design clearly rooted in Seamaster heritage yet daring to be original at the same time. The Planet Ocean's popularity only soared after being spotted on the wrist of Daniel Craig's James Bond in Casino Royale and its sequels.

Added to the beloved Aquatimer collection just last year, this new watch represents a significant step forward for IWC's divers in a number of respects. First and foremost, the watch has been widely acclaimed for its innovative external/internal bezel. Using a special clutch system positioned to look like a left hand crown, the bezel is set by unidirectional rotation as normal, in a manner that combines the ease of outer bezels with the safety advantages of inner ones. Then there's the water resistance—the watch can cope with pressures up to 30 bar, more than double its previous specs. Finally, there's the updated appearance. Effortlessly legible, clean and elegant, the chronograph is nevertheless a rugged and imposing 46mm sports watch with a silver, black and yellow colour scheme inspired by the brand's work in the Galapagos Islands.

Originating in Florence, Tuscany, Panerai has a long history of making stylish and extremely reliable watches for professional divers, beginning with its famed WWII contract for the Italian Navy's “Frogmen”. The PAM Submersible pieces are among Panerai's finest diving tools. This superb example features a super-tough black carbon fibre (‘Carbotech’) case and bezel with graduated scale. The watch runs on the in-house P.9000 movement, which boasts a 3-day power reserve from two barrels and allows the wearer to change the time in convenient 1-hour increments. The matching black factory strap is made of a durable rubber that is perfect for diving.

While this watch shares many of the beloved characteristics associated with the Panerai Radiomir—big cushion case; vintage, legible design; sandwich dial; onion crown; leather strap—it is strikingly different in its immediate impact on the viewer. Sleek, menacing and black as night, the PAM 292's dark allure is not the result of any external PVD or DLC. It's a fully ceramic case, much harder than steel and amazingly durable, the result of an exceptionally long and arduous process of diamond-wheel machining and microglass blasting. The material is too hard to mould and is originally created by extreme isostatic pressing of zirconium oxide followed by sintering at around 1,500°C.

This IWC has undergone a thorough inspection of accuracy, functionality and condition at our IWC certified service centre to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been checked against our records to ensure authenticity. All our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind.

The Radiomir collection is named after the distinctive luminescent compound Panerai developed when it sold watches to the Italian Navy in the 1930s. Today it is known for several beloved characteristics that have made it an icon of horology—big cushion case; vintage, legible design; sandwich dial; onion crown; and leather strap. Here we have a gorgeous 47mm limited edition in polished pink gold that positively gleams on the wrist. Known as the Ora Rosa, this version features a superb, paired-down dial. The transparent caseback allows the owner to examine the stunning in-house movement P.3000, which boasts two barrels and three days of power.

column21: Originally an evolution of its early automatics, the IWC Ingenieur was designed to combine the self-winding movement with the shock and magnetic resistance pioneered in some of the brand's pilots' watches. Created by the legendary designer Gerald Genta in the 1970s, the watch was allegedly inspired by a diving helmet, giving Genta the relatively new idea of leaving the functional case elements like screws and bores exposed, instead of hiding them away. The modernist aesthetic was a huge success for IWC, and the Ingenieur has become a horological icon. This fantastic example features the brand's other speciality, the perpetual calendar, with a perfect Ingenieur-faithful design interpretation.

If you're a big fan of Panerai, the legendary Italian watchmaker, chances are you've encountered Paneristi.com, the “unofficial resource” and forum where collectors and enthusiasts meet and discuss everything Panerai-related. In a spectacular gesture of good will towards its loyal supporters, the brand itself agreed to create a very limited run of watches in collaboration with the Paneristi site moderators themselves. PVD case, painted patina dial, OP logo, and even a special caseback inscription that commemorates the forum's 10th anniversary—this is the ultimate Panerai for collectors. Competition to own one couldn't have been more fierce.

Given the Big Bang's origins, with its porthole-inspired design, there have been nautical themes in the collection from the start—if faint ones. So when it came time for Hublot to create its first “serious” diving watch, it made some sense to turn to the King Power, the even bigger, bolder version of the already spectacular Big Bang series. Hublot was never going to do things by halves. Made of lightweight carbon fibre, this “Oceanographic” has a beastly 48mm case distinguished by the monstrous crown at 2 o'clock (its smaller brother at 4 o'clock is for the inner bezel), and a super-legible dial. The crystal is a massive 6.5mm thick, providing the immense water resistance that would keep this extraordinary watch safe and sound on the ocean floor.

The Luminor 127 is a unique and very special watch in the Panerai pantheon, one close to the hearts of many collectors and affectionately nicknamed the “Fiddy”. First released in 2002, it is an uncanny recreation of a gorgeous vintage timepiece from 1950 (hence the limited edition number), and is known for many important features. For a start, it is 47mm in diameter, a large size with which the brand would subsequently become associated (some claim that Panerai were the ones who launched the whole oversize trend). Then there's the unique form of sandwich dial, rarely seen before, which combined with the crown guard and domed sapphire crystal to create an extremely cool aura of vintage Italian style—one that few others have achieved.

Invented in the 1930s as one of the first wristwatches made to be as precise as a marine chronometer, the Portuguese collection has a long history, though it wasn't produced in serious numbers until the 1990s. Today they're among IWC's finest watches, beloved by collectors for their graceful, uncluttered design and classic aesthetic featuring thin bezels and sword-like hands. This exquisite model runs on an automatic movement, IWC calibre 79350, with a superb chronograph mechanism. Adding a dash of sporting appeal to this elegant watch, the chrono display is subtly integrated and in no way detracts from the clean, sophisticated design.

Binding classical watchmaking tradition with modern creativity, the Audemars Piguet Millenary is as playful and unique as it is mesmerising to behold. The collection builds its neo-classical aesthetic by taking inspiration from the best of traditional watchmaking and reimagining it for the third millennium. The Millenary is known for its superb oval case that provides room to play with circular, off-centre sub-dials that overlap in pleasing arrangements. This is the perfect watch for those who want to showcase their avant-guard taste while remaining true to the peerless Audemars Piguet heritage.

Created by the legendary designer Gerald Genta in the 1970s, the watch was allegedly inspired by a diving helmet, giving Genta the relatively new idea of leaving the functional case elements like screws and bores exposed, instead of hiding them away. The modernist aesthetic was a huge success for IWC, and the Ingenieur has become a horological icon. This fantastic example features the brand's other speciality, the perpetual calendar, with a perfect Ingenieur-faithful design interpretation.

This extraordinary Hublot limited edition was made in honour of the Yacht Club de Monaco, and in particular of its flagship beauty, the Tuiga. Built in the legendary William Fife boatyard, Scotland, Tuiga has enjoyed more than a century of prestigious sailing. It was purchased for the Club in 1995 by HSH Prince Albert II, and continues to valiantly represent its values and maritime heritage at major regattas. Originally inspired by the portholes on similar vessels, the Big Bang has a maritime history of its own, making it the perfect choice to commemorate the Tuiga in this very special edition, with a tantalum case and ceramic bezel. An image of the vessel is depicted on the exhibition caseback.

This superb, understated Radiomir features Panerai's special ceramic case material. It's called “composite” instead of ceramic to differentiate it from the ceramics of other watchmakers, which are typically made with a zirconium base. Panerai's is created by electrochemical processes using aluminium, making it harder and tougher than other ceramics, not to mention lighter than even titanium. Not only is the watch made with unique, cutting edge materials, but it also features a highly prestigious in-house movement. P.3000 has a power reserve of three days and a allows the hour to be set in discrete jumps without interfering with the workings of the seconds or minutes.

This IWC has undergone a thorough inspection of accuracy, functionality and condition at our IWC certified service centre to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been checked against our records to ensure authenticity. The Luminor 127 is a unique and very special watch in the Panerai pantheon, one close to the hearts of many collectors and affectionately nicknamed the “Fiddy”. First released in 2002, it is an uncanny recreation of a gorgeous vintage timepiece from 1950 (hence the limited edition number), and is known for many important features. For a start, it is 47mm in diameter, a large size with which the brand would subsequently become associated (some claim that Panerai were the ones who launched the whole oversize trend). Then there's the unique form of sandwich dial, rarely seen before, which combined with the crown guard and domed sapphire crystal to create an extremely cool aura of vintage Italian style—one that few others have achieved.

The Radiomir collection is named after the distinctive luminescent compound Panerai developed when it sold watches to the Italian Navy in the 1930s. Today it is known for several beloved characteristics that have made it an icon of horology—big cushion case; vintage, legible design; sandwich dial; onion crown; and leather strap. Here we have a gorgeous 47mm limited edition in polished pink gold that positively gleams on the wrist. Known as the Ora Rosa, this version features a superb, paired-down dial. The transparent caseback allows the owner to examine the stunning in-house movement P.3000, which boasts two barrels and three days of power.

This special Luminor pays tribute to some of the brand's vintage early 20th century models, when Panerai was making “Marina Militare” watches for the Italian and Egyptian Navies. One rare timepiece built for the latter, the GPF 2/56, became legendary for its huge 66mm size and “Angelus” movement with an eight day power reserve. It had the words “8 giorni brevettato” (“8 days patented”) written around a circle on the dial, a mark which has since become something of a Panerai holy symbol. Only a tiny number of modern references also have this marking, of which this wonderful PAM 590 is one. The modern, in-house P.5000 movement also has an impressive power reserve of eight days, while the caseback has an engraving of a Frogman with his SLC human torpedo (another iconic chapter of Panerai history).

This Panerai has undergone a thorough inspection of accuracy, functionality and condition at our Panerai certified service centre to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been checked against our records to ensure authenticity. All our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind.

The “California” style dial, famous for its combination of Roman numerals, Arabic numerals and regular indexes, as well as the lack of brand name or other lettering, was used in Panerai's very earliest watches from the 1930s. The name comes from a company in California that was known for refurbishing many such dials. The 448 is based very closely on the original prototype Californias commissioned in 1936 by the Royal Italian Navy. This modern version with superb finishing is particularly delightful thanks to the stunning case, authentic black dial and the blue hands and minute track that go so nicely with it.

Invented in the 1930s as one of the first wristwatches made to be as precise as a marine chronometer, the Portuguese collection has a long history, though it wasn't produced in serious numbers until the 1990s. Today they're among IWC's finest watches, beloved by collectors for their graceful, uncluttered design and classic aesthetic featuring thin bezels and sword-like hands. This exquisite model runs on an automatic movement, IWC calibre 79350, with a superb chronograph mechanism. Adding a dash of sporting appeal to this elegant watch, the chrono display is subtly integrated and in no way detracts from the clean, sophisticated design.

This Linde Werdelin has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history. All our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind.

Originating in Florence, Tuscany, Panerai has a long history of making stylish and extremely reliable watches for professional divers, beginning with its famed WWII contract for the Italian Navy's “Frogmen”. The PAM Submersible pieces are among Panerai's finest diving tools. This superb example features a super-tough black carbon fibre (‘Carbotech’) case and bezel with graduated scale. The watch runs on the in-house P.9000 movement, which boasts a 3-day power reserve from two barrels and allows the wearer to change the time in convenient 1-hour increments. The matching black factory strap is made of a durable rubber that is perfect for diving.

Given the Big Bang's origins, with its porthole-inspired design, there have been nautical themes in the collection from the start—if faint ones. So when it came time for Hublot to create its first “serious” diving watch, it made some sense to turn to the King Power, the even bigger, bolder version of the already spectacular Big Bang series. Hublot was never going to do things by halves. Made of lightweight carbon fibre, this “Oceanographic” has a beastly 48mm case distinguished by the monstrous crown at 2 o'clock (its smaller brother at 4 o'clock is for the inner bezel), and a super-legible dial. The crystal is a massive 6.5mm thick, providing the immense water resistance that would keep this extraordinary watch safe and sound on the ocean floor.

Designed by Emmanuelle Gueit to celebrate twenty years since the 1972 release of its now-iconic older brother, the Royal Oak, the Offshore range of watches is said to have influenced the trend for oversized watches that began in the mid 1990s. Similar to its forebear, which was designed by Gerald Genta, the Royal Oak Offshore is bigger and bolder, often paired with tough rubber straps. This particular model features an unusual chocolate brown tapisserie dial paired with blue sub-dials—a truly stunning combination that is complemented by the brown alligator strap. Although the 42mm case is steel, white gold was used for the hour and minutes hands, as well as the rims of the Arabic luminescent numerals. This watch runs on an AP caliber 3126/3840 automatic movement which holds a power reserve of approximately 50 hours.

This masterful Luminor 1950 from Panerai features a “double” or “split seconds” chronograph (also known as a rattrapante), one of high-end watchmaking's most challenging mechanical complications to manufacture. Where a regular chronograph simply records time elapsed between pushing the start and stop buttons, a split seconds chrono allows you to time laps or intermediate intervals. There are in fact two seconds hands, one of them ingeniously hidden; an extra pusher at 8 o'clock stops the first hand, recording the initial time, while the other hand continues to run. The PAM 213 uses the OP XVIII movement, based on a stunning and unusual column wheel Valjoux 7750.

The modern Luminor design originated in the early 1950s, when Panerai finally decided to sell its prestigious watches to the civilian market after more than 50 years as a military contractor. Three limited edition pieces created at this time set the style for what would soon become Luminor. It somewhat updated the look while remaining true to the brand's historical aesthetics, adding strong clean lines and new curves to the powerful cushion case, and a crown guard to boost muscle and water resistance.

In watch form, the Carrera has been in existence since 1964, and continued Heuer’s great legacy in providing racing drivers with timing instruments. Named after the intense ‘Carrera Panamericana’ road race of the 1950’s (which also gave its name to the eponymous Porsche), the Carrera continues to provide timing for some of the world’s most prestigious racing teams today. This recent addition to the Carrera fold fully embodies that racing heritage with its black carbide titanium case, red highlights and ceramic bezel. The watch uses TAG's famous 1887 movement, a smooth column-wheel chronograph that features a modern version of the remarkable oscillating pinion first patented by the brand in 1887.

IWC's Top Gun series stands as a tribute to the elite pilot's training centre for the US Marines in Miramar, California, immortalised by the iconic 1986 Tom Cruise motion picture. The design is built to recall the deck watches of the 1930s and 1940s, referencing IWC's history in pilot's watches.  This impressive watch also features an elaborate Top Gun engraving, stunning anthracite dial and an extra lightweight ceramic and titanium case made with zirconium oxide fired at temperatures approaching 2,000 degrees centigrade. The in-house calibre 51111 has a seven day power reserve, and the watch comes with a military style green textile strap.

The Grand Lange 1 is, as the name suggests, a larger version of the Lange 1, which was one of the four new watches the German brand presented when it was revived in 1994 after decades of dormancy. The company has gone on to be the flagbearer for fine, traditional watchmaking in the east German town of Glashütte. At 41mm it is significantly larger than the 37mm Lange 1 and features a moonphase display within the main sub-dial, while elsewhere can be found a big date display, power reserve indicator and small seconds, all harmoniously positioned within the asymmetrical silver dial. Like the Lange 1, it’s powered by a manual-wind movement seen through display caseback, revealing Glashutte stripes and intricate engraving. The date for months that don’t run to 31 days is corrected via a button on the side of the yellow-gold case and the power reserve is three days.

The Grand Prix de Monaco is one of the most iconic events in all of motor racing. Held since 1929, the race takes place on the streets of the city—challenging for drivers and exhilarating for spectators. Just as the event was updated in the late 90s to become the “Grand Prix de Monaco Historique”, so have Chopard's exceptional racing watches that commemorate it. The Monaco Historique collection, launched in 2014, marks a turning point for the Grand Prix watches. They are no longer simply a bunch of coveted and collectible Limited Editions, but now have a magnificently good-looking permanent backbone on which to build. This beauty in steel showcases all of the Monaco Historique's best qualities.

On the surface, the PAM 141 seems like a relatively typical example of Panerai's iconic Radiomir series, with its big cushion cases, glorious onion crown and leather strap – the same look that has been doing wonders for the brand ever since it started out making watches for the Italian Navy back in the 1930s. But flip this watch over and the stunning view through the sapphire crystal caseback will reveal something you won't see in many other Radiomirs: the 141 is powered by the OP VII, based on the famous Elite movement by fellow Swiss horological giant, Zenith. In fact, it's none other than the Elite 680, a prestigious ultra-thin calibre beating at 28,000 vph. Because of this, the PAM 141 is highly sought-after, particularly as it's thought that only 500 were ever made.

Rolex has long been popular among women who know their horology. Unlike some brands that relegate ladies' watches to mere fashion statements, Rolex gives just as much care and attention to their mechanical credentials as it does for watches aimed at men. The Lady Datejust participates in the same legendary horological history of Rolex's groundbreaking introduction of the date window in 1945, and still bears the famous 'Superlative Chronometer Officially Certified' on the dial. Its slimmed-down size allows for stunning elegance and attention to detail, and this model is equipped with the superb calibre 2235 self-winding movement.

This Oris has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history. All our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind.

Named after the speedway track in Florida that hosts a legendary, Rolex-sponsored twenty-four hour race, the Daytona is the quintessential driver’s watch and was given a boost in popularity when Hollywood icon Paul Newman wore an early version of it. The dial, with its three subdials, is clear and easy to read while a tachymeter on the bezel offers quick speed calculations. It’s powered by Rolex’s Caliber 4130 automatic chronograph movement which holds a power reserve of 72 hours. Introduced in 1963 it’s been in continuous production ever since, although this particular reference is discontinued. Its smaller size and smart design makes it a versatile watch capable of working well with both casual jeans and a formal suit.

In 2008, Rolex released the Day-Date II, a modern update of the timelessly classic Day-Date, which features a larger case (41mm) than the original. This in turn was replaced in 2015 by the Day-Date 40 which, as the name implies, comes in a 40mm case. This version in white gold features the signature fluted bezel, within which is a silver dial bearing baguette diamond indices. The date at 3 o’clock lies beneath the signature Rolex Cyclops magnifying lens for better legibility. It comes on a President bracelet and runs on the Caliber 3255 automatic movement. Famously, the Day-Date was the first watch to indicate the day of the week spelt out in full when it was launched in 1956, and it has gone on to be worn by everyone from the Dalai Lama to numerous US presidents, hence it’s ‘President’ nickname.

In watch form, the Carrera has been in existence since 1964, when it continued Heuer’s great legacy in providing racing drivers with high quality timing instruments. Named after the intense ‘Carrera Panamericana’ road race of the 1950s (which also gave its name to the eponymous Porsche), the Carrera continues to provide timing for some of the world’s most prestigious racing teams today. This addition to the Carrera fold fully embodies that racing heritage while daring to forge its own path, boasting an energetic modern design with classic racing-red highlights.

Nicolas Rieussec was the first collection launched by Montblanc after the company took control of the prestigious Minerva manufacture in Villeret. The watches are named after the French inventor of the chronograph, which was originally a device that measured intervals by moving a pen in contact with rotating paper, drawing an arc as it went (hence the name chronograph, from the Greek for “time-writing”). The Nicolas Rieussec watches were also the first to house an in-house Montblanc movement, propelling the brand into the upper echelons of haute horlogerie. Matching tradition with innovation, this stunning watch is a monopusher column-wheel chrono, with a second timezone on the main dial paired with a day/night indicator that mirrors the date window.

Added to the beloved Aquatimer collection just last year, this new watch represents a significant step forward for IWC's divers in a number of respects. First and foremost, the watch has been widely acclaimed for its innovative external/internal bezel. Using a special clutch system positioned to look like a left hand crown, the bezel is set by unidirectional rotation as normal, in a manner that combines the ease of outer bezels with the safety advantages of inner ones. Then there's the water resistance—the watch can cope with pressures up to 30 bar, more than double its previous specs. Finally, there's the updated appearance. At 42mm, this is the smallest Aquatimer in the collection, and its black, silver and green colours are inspired by the Galapagos Islands.

The Rolex Explorer is one of the most highly valued and sought out models for buyers with a lot of experience in the often complicated world of vintage watch collecting. Originally based on the model worn by Tenzing Norgay in the first ever successful ascent of Everest in 1953, the Explorer was a versatile timepiece that enjoyed numerous variations. This reference 14270 is an excellent example. Starting in 1989, it brought a well-received modern upgrade to the Explorer family, while staying faithful to the original model—and also introduced the superb calibre 3000.

This Rado has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history. The U-2 is one of the most important high-tech spy planes in the US Airforce. Nicknamed the Dragon Lady, early versions of the U-2 were in operation at the beginning of the Cold War, and continue to be flown by exceptional pilots based in Beale, California. Needless to say, this is the type of aviation history that Bremont adores. The U-2 collection is a sincerely heartfelt tribute to these amazing machines and the brave souls who fly them, often over 80,000 feet into the stratosphere for 12 hours or more at a time. The beautifully designed U-2 watches have, like the plane, been tested at even higher altitudes, as well as at temperature extremes of -40ºC or more—including tests “in the field” with the U-2 pilots themselves. The watch's ultra-durable Trip-Tick case contains an inner bezel operated by a crown at 4 o'clock.

Panerai has several watches with amazingly long power reserves, yet even by its standards the Radiomir 10 days is stands out from the crowd. The watch harnesses three large mainspring barrels to generate this much power, and the superb mechanical specs of the in-house P.2003 movement ensure that this energy is distributed cleanly and evenly without any compromise of timekeeping precision. In addition to the power reserve, which is displayed on a subdial at 6 o'clock, the watch also boasts a GMT complication, using an extra hand from the centre (instantly recognisable thanks to its striking arrow head). This is accompanied by a day/night indicator inside the small seconds dial.

Added to the beloved Aquatimer collection just last year, this new watch represents a significant step forward for IWC's divers in a number of respects. First and foremost, the watch has been widely acclaimed for its innovative external/internal bezel. Using a special clutch system positioned to look like a left hand crown, the bezel is set by unidirectional rotation as normal, in a manner that combines the ease of outer bezels with the safety advantages of inner ones. Then there's the water resistance—the watch can cope with pressures up to 30 bar, more than double its previous specs. Finally, there's the updated appearance. Effortlessly legible, clean and elegant, the chronograph is nevertheless a rugged and imposing 44mm sports watch with a striking colour scheme.

Bremont describes the Supermarine collection as “divers watches inspired by our aviation principles”. This doesn't mean the Supermarine is a pilot's watch, but rather a traditional, good-looking and high-grade diver that is—at heart—a Bremont. Demonstrating the brand's no-nonsense British clarity and effortless sense of refinement, the Supermarine also boasts the impressive technical credentials for which Bremont, a relatively small independent brand, is rightly acclaimed. The watch uses Bremont's anti-shock mount, a Faraday cage and a helium escape valve to make itself seriously durable. Meanwhile, accuracy is guaranteed by the Swiss chronometer inside, lovingly embellished and assembled in Bremont's Henley factory.

The GMT Master was first commissioned in the 1950s by pioneering airline Pan Am, and was designed for aviation. An increase in flight distances created demand for a watch that was able to tell the time in two different parts of the world simultaneously, so Rolex built it with an additional hand that could be set to a second time zone. By the 1980s, the watch had developed into the GMT Master II and was already a favourite among collectors. This model represents a significant upgrade for the watch, boasting an aerospace-grade steel case and cerachrom inserts in the bezel. A variant on the regular 116710, this reference features gold elements in the bezel, crown, hands, indices and of course the bracelet.

The modern Luminor design originated in the early 1990s, when Panerai finally decided to sell its prestigious watches to the civilian market after more than 50 years as a military-only contractor. Three limited edition pieces created at this time set the style for what would soon become modern Luminor. It somewhat modernised the 1940s-era look while remaining true to the brand's historical aesthetics, adding strong clean lines and new curves to the distinctive cushion case, and a crown guard to boost water resistance. This lovely example has an in-house movement, the P.3002, with a power reserve of three days that is displayed in a sophisticated retrograde indicator on the dial.

The Cartier Tank, inspired by an actual tank, has been a design milestone since its inception in the early 20th century. Unlike the modified pocket watches being made by other manufacturers, the Tank used a new case design that actually incorporated the lugs into its shape, rather than adding them as an afterthought. Other iconic design elements include the blued sword hands, Roman numerals, elegant square dial and octagonal crown complete with sapphire cabochon. The Française collection adds a somewhat sportier, more modern feel to an already superb timepiece, making it bolder and more versatile, in large part thanks to its chain-link bracelet.

The Luminor as we know it originated in the early 1990s, when Panerai finally decided to sell its prestigious watches to the civilian market after more than 50 years as a military contractor. These watches somewhat modernised the iconic look while remaining true to the brand's historical aesthetics, adding strong clean lines and new curves to the powerful cushion case, and a crown guard to boost muscle and water resistance. Here the legendary Luminor is available in all its classic glory, staying remarkably true to its historic legacy.

Luxury watchmaking in England was given a welcome boost with the launch of Bremont in 2002. Founded by brothers Giles and Nick English, it began by making beautifully crafted pilots’ watches, most of which are ISO chronometer rated, and has brought out a number of intriguing limited editions that incorporate history into the actual watch in the most literal sense. This model features an actual piece of fabric used on the 1903 Wright Flyer aircraft that marked the beginning of the pioneer era of aviation. It can be seen through the transparent caseback, as can the automatic movement, which is powered by a rotor that bears the words ‘Wright Flyer’, the initials of the Wright brothers, Wilbur and Orville, and a delightful propellor design. This hugely collectible watch, with a 50-hour power reserve, is one of just 300 pieces.

It may be known for its iconic aviation watches that have led the industry for decades, but Breitling is more than adept when it comes to good-looking, functional horological tools of other kinds. Many Breitling diving watches are masterful pieces of engineering; the Superocean is surely the greatest example. The first Superocean was unveiled in the 1950s, made for professional and military use. More recently, the Superocean Heritage collection pays tribute to these superb timepieces with a design based on the original, though the technical specs have of course been upgraded to the highest modern standards. This clean and elegant model boasts 200m water resistance and a superb Swiss calibre.

While it's the limited, historical or complicated pieces that often get most of the attention when it comes to Panerai, many collectors are more interested in the more straightforward “Base” models, where they feel that the real essence of the brand can be found. These entry level watches come without distracting bells and whistles, at a comparatively affordable price point, yet they still have all of Panerai's best attributes in spades. Case in point is this lovely PAM560, one of five new Base models in 2014. It's very similar to its predecessor, the PAM112, with one major difference: inside beats the company's amazing in-house movement, Calibre P.5000, complete with double barrelled 8-day power reserve.

Fascinating, innovative and technically unique, Jaeger-LeCoultre's Duometre watches are often overlooked despite being one of the most impressive collections in the brand's stable (no small achievement). The watches use a brilliant “dual wing” movement boasting two separate mainspring power sources. The first is used purely for the main time display, and the other caters to additional complications. In this case, the elegant dial showcases the hours and minutes symmetrically opposite a dial combining the date with a sophisticated dual-hemisphere moonphase display. There is a long seconds hand from the centre, while the 6 o'clock subdial features jumping sixths of a second. It's flanked by exquisite exhibition apertures into the movement's workings—including power reserve indicators for each of the “dual wing” sources.

Since 1946, British aerospace company Martin-Baker has saved the lives of at least 7,450 pilots. That's because it makes ejection seats—one of the most vital pieces of safety equipment on any high-speed aircraft. Martin-Baker seats are the best of the best, tested to the most punishing levels of endurance and extremes of shock, vibration, temperature and more. Amazingly, Bremont's Martin-Baker watches have been put through the same rigours used on the ejection seats, at the same test facility. Fitted with anti-shock movement mounts and Faraday cages, the MB watches are made to be the ultimate endurance chronometer, able to survive just about anything short of a direct meteor strike. They're also not half handsome to look at.

The Cartier Tank, inspired by an actual tank, has been a design milestone since its inception in the early 20th century. Unlike the modified pocket watches being made by other manufacturers, the Tank used a new case design that actually incorporated the lugs into its shape, rather than adding them as an afterthought. Other iconic design elements include the blued sword hands, Roman numerals, elegant square dial and octagonal crown complete with sapphire cabochon. The Française collection adds a somewhat sportier, more modern feel to an already superb timepiece, making it bolder and more versatile, in large part thanks to its chain-link bracelet.

column21: In watch form, the Carrera has been in existence since 1964, continuing Heuer’s great legacy in providing racing drivers with timing instruments. Named after the intense 'Carrera Panamerica' road race of the 1950s (which also gave its name to the eponymous Porsche), the Carrera has long been sought to provide timing for some of the world’s most prestigious racing teams. This addition to the Carrera collection fully embodies that racing heritage with its large 60-second chronograph counter, as well as racing-themed colouring and tachymeter scale on the bezel.

The Seamaster is one of the most iconic diving watches of all time. By the 1950s, it was among the most dependable and professionally sought dive watches from any brand, and it soon pioneered some of the sporty must-have features we associate with such watches, including unidirectional bezels, phosphorescent hands and the helium escape valve. The year 2005 saw the launch of a modern classic: the Seamaster Planet Ocean. This collection bursts with innovative style and energy, its design clearly rooted in Seamaster heritage yet daring to be original at the same time. The Planet Ocean's popularity only soared after being spotted on the wrist of Daniel Craig's James Bond in Casino Royale and its sequels.

This Tudor has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history. From the world’s most revered historical watchmaker comes this exquisite and highly refined Grand Complications model, comprising a split-seconds chronograph, perpetual calendar and moonphase. Patek Philippe’s heritage in producing Grand Complications watches is unrivalled, with the brand famously making pocket watches for the renowned watch-collecting banker, Henry Graves, in the early 20th century. These days it puts its most intricate complications in its wristwatches, like this fine example in 18k rose gold. This being a perpetual calendar—with no need to adjust the watch for shorter months or leap years, at least until the year 2100—there is also a leap-year indicator, together with a day-night indicator. This extraordinary timepiece runs on Patek Philippe’s manually wound Caliber CHR 29 535 PS Q, visible through the sapphire caseback, enabling you to appreciate the movement’s spell-binding hand-finishing.

This is Omega’s first ever world timer model and one of just 87 pieces made, making it one of the brand’s most unusual and rare watches. Most notably, the dial's centre features a colourful hand-crafted enamel world map as viewed from the North Pole, which is surrounded by a 24-hour reference ring giving the time in a number of cities, from Athens to Auckland. The dart 12-hour indices and hands are 18k yellow gold and coated in Super-LumiNova and the 43mm case, unusually for an Omega, is platinum. There is also a discreet date window at 6 o’clock. It comes on a brown leather strap with a platinum-gold foldover clasp, while inside is Omega’s superbly finished Master Chronometer calibre 8939, a self-winding movement with co-axial escapement, which can be viewed through the exhibition caseback.

Describing its aesthetic as elegant, simple and creative, Vacheron Constantin has continually aimed to enhance and reinvent the art of fine watchmaking since its introduction over 265 years ago. The oldest Swiss watchmaker in continuous operation, it has cemented its place within the top three watchmakers in the world. This Patrimony Traditionnelle features a fourteen-day tourbillon, with a power reserve of about 336 hours—that’s two weeks—as well as Vacheron Constantin’s beautiful and prestigious in-house movement, the calibre 2260. As with all models from this watchmaker, it bears the Seal of Geneva—a sign of superior quality, craftmanship and reliability. The piece is also said to be perhaps the longest power reserve tourbillon-based watch with a single mainspring barrel—an impressive feat. The Patrimony Traditionnelle showcases Vacheron Constantin at its best, with a dial that combines modest features and an opening to a strikingly complex mechanism.

Named after Lake Geneva, the Blancpain Léman collection seeks to capture the evocative natural beauty of this iconic landmark, as well as its proximity to the heart of Swiss watchmaking heritage. With a strong grasp of traditional designs, the Léman watches are classic and authoritative, while simultaneously contemporary and refreshing. They speak to the timeless watchmaking legacy of the Blancpain company, which has been creating horological masterpieces since 1735. This stunning model is notable for its superb mechanical calibre (visible through the caseback), featuring a second timezone complication complete with a particularly wonderful day/night indicator.

First released in 1932, back when pocket watches were still popular and the preferred option over wristwatches, the Calatrava is one of Patek Philippe’s most loved watches. A huge influence on watch designs since its release, this Calatrava boasts ornamentation work that took over 30-hours of meticulous artistry from expert craftsmen—and that’s just on the dial. Today, the Calatrava has a healthy number of references to choose from and takes the wearer from day to night, and this limited edition 5088 model from 2015 is certainly a showstopper. It features a beautiful hand-engraved black enamel dial, created using the burin—or engraver—a tiny tool that acts as an extension of the craftsman’s hand and penetrates the material to create the desired pattern. The exquisite enamelling even extends to the sides of the white gold case. Inside the watch is an ultra-thin self-winding mechanical movement with the calibre 240, also visible through the case back. Limited to just 10 pieces worldwide, this Calatrava is the ultimate collector’s piece.

The Da Vinci collection has been around for over 30 years now and this Da Vinci Perpetual Calendar Chronograph in 18-karat 5N gold showcases the very best of the range. With the moon sitting still against the dark blue night sky, the moon-phase indicator disc beneath the dial acts as the Earth’s shadow and lies within the totaliser sub-dial which includes the hour and minute counters, both merged at 12 o’clock. Plus, the handy flyback function allows ongoing chronograph measurements to be instantly “deleted” and a new measurement started without an intermediate stop, whereas the perpetual calendar’s sharp precision is made possible by the in-house 89630 calibre. This timepiece is perfect for any avid fans of IWC’s Da Vinci collection and watches that are as functional as they are beautiful.

This rare and incredibly elegant perpetual calendar is a true technical marvel. It's not just the quantity of data it records, from the date (including a four-digit year display) to the moonphase (with separate indications for northern and southern hemispheres) and even the seriously impressive seven-day power reserve (indicated inside the 3 o'clock subdial). The most extraordinary part of the watch is in fact the humble—yet sophisticated—crown. Based on the original design by the legendary watchmaker Kurt Klaus, the entire watch is set by the single crown; all components are connected so that you don't have to redo each little display one by one.

This Hublot has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. Panerai has several watches with amazingly long power reserves, yet even by its standards this 10-day Luminor stands out from the crowd. The watch harnesses three large mainspring barrels to generate this much power, and the superb mechanical specs of the in-house P.2003 movement ensure that this energy is distributed cleanly and evenly without any compromise of timekeeping precision. In addition to the power reserve, which has a “linear” display at 6 o'clock, the watch also boasts a GMT complication, using an extra hand from the centre (instantly recognisable thanks to its striking arrowhead). This is accompanied by a day/night indicator inside the small seconds dial.

column21: The Bell & Ross BR01 represents the cornerstone of the brand's DNA. The series was launched in 2005, marking Bell & Ross's first significant watch family since it ended its partnership with Sinn, and today makes up the majority of the “Aviation” collection. The BR01 is influenced by Sinn's major theme of practicality and quality, but the Bell & Ross mission is to make these kind of serious, practical instruments accessible to those with more concern for lifestyle and fashion. This can be seen in the BR01's urbane, ultra-legible dials and square cases that would not look out of place on an aircraft dashboard.

Hailing from a period before TAG’s acquisition of Heuer, the timepiece features the vintage Heuer symbol which has since been made popular again by vintage styled pilots watches.

Made specifically for pilots in the German air force, the Bundeswehr, this timepiece was a utilitarian watch that dates from the Cold War era. As the watches of choice of the German Airforce, who were tasked with the defence of Western Germany, this timepiece represents a tangible link to a compelling period in modern European history.

This Heuer timepiece is a premium example of a vintage pilot’s watch, featuring an ultra-legible dial that is specifically designed to be read in all lighting conditions. The timepiece features a fly back mechanism which is particularly useful for the synchronisation of timing between two aircraft and it bears a dial lumed with tritium, befitting of its vintage status.

Fascinating, innovative and technically unique, Jaeger-LeCoultre's Duometre watches are often overlooked despite being one of the most impressive collections in the brand's stable (no small achievement). The watches use a brilliant “dual wing” movement boasting two separate mainspring power sources. The first is used purely for the main time display, and the other caters to additional complications. In this case, the elegant dial showcases the hours and minutes symmetrically opposite a dial combining the date with a sophisticated dual-hemisphere moonphase display. There is a long seconds hand from the centre, while the 6 o'clock subdial features jumping sixths of a second. It's flanked by exquisite exhibition apertures into the movement's workings—including power reserve indicators for each of the “dual wing” sources.

Since its first release in 2000, Richard Mille has made the industry stand up and take note with its outlandish, mostly skeletonised watches. Blending design innovation with unorthodox materials, these timepieces are also tough enough to be worn by elite athletes in the thick of the action. Tennis player Rafa Nadal famously wears his on court. This incredible flyback chronograph deep sea dive model stands out among Richard Mille watches for its round, rather than tonneau, case. But all the other signature brand elements are there, including the lightweight titanium case, integrated rubber strap and skeletonization. Striking looks aside, this watch complies with ISO 6425 international dive watch requirements and is water-resistant to 300 metres. Its inwardly sloping bezel also features push-buttons at opposite sides that are held down simultaneously to move the bezel, which is otherwise locked for added safety. The automatic movement holds a power reserve of 45-50 hours, depending on whether the chronograph is running, and it also features an annual calendar. An attention-grabber thanks to its 50mm case size, it’s nonetheless a watch that excels technically.

In watch form, the Carrera has been in existence since 1964, when it continued Heuer’s great legacy of providing racing drivers with high quality timing instruments. Named after the intense ‘Carrera Panamericana’ road race of the 1950s (which also gave its name to the eponymous Porsche), the Carrera continues to provide timing for some of the world’s most prestigious racing teams today. This recent addition to the Carrera fold fully embodies that racing heritage with its very special Limited Edition carbon fibre dial and superb calibre 16 automatic chronograph movement, fitted with a special day and date function at 3 o'clock.

Known as one of the foremost purveyors of ultra-elegant jewellery, Cartier has long held a reputation for superb watches, mostly with excellent mechanical pedigree, but its principal strong suit has been high-fashion and style. The Calibre de Cartier collection represents a big step forward for the brand into the world of true haute horlogerie. Without losing an ounce of its customary sophistication and stylishness, the watches are equipped with the first self-winding movement entirely manufactured by Cartier SA: the glorious 1904 MC (named for the year that Louis Cartier famously made a wristwatch for pilot Alberto Santos-Dumont).

Originally designed in 1971 for the admittedly niche market of cave explorers, the Rolex Explorer II was later updated to fit the aesthetic codes of the brand's other sports watch families. The watch builds on the heritage of the legendary Explorer I, which has always been a firm favourite among enthusiasts—the watch was first established in the public mind after its pioneering ascent of Everest during the expedition of Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay. Today the Explorer II deviates in some ways from the original look, but it continues to represent an exceptional, hardy, modernised tool watch with a top-of-the-range in-house movement and a design that does justice to its legacy in both sports and adventure.

The GMT Master was first commissioned in the 1950s by pioneering airline Pan Am, and was designed for aviation. An increase in flight distances created demand for a watch that was able to tell the time in two different parts of the world simultaneously, so Rolex built it with an additional hand that could be set to a second time zone. By the 1980s, the watch had developed into the GMT Master II and was already a favourite among collectors.

Established in the public mind after Rolex’s involvement in the pioneering ascent of Everest with Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay, the Explorer I has a delightfully clear, readable face, uncluttered by a date complication. The case is smoother and more rounded than other Rolex sports models, even more so than it initially appears.

An increase in flight distances created demand for a watch that was able to tell the time in two different parts of the world simultaneously, so Rolex built it with an additional hand that could be set to a second time zone. By the 1980s, the watch had developed into the GMT Master II and was already a favourite among collectors.

By the 1980s, the watch had developed into the GMT Master II and was already a favourite among collectors.

The classic Explorer I has always been a firm favourite amongst enthusiasts, its heritage and good looks being very hard to resist. Established in the public mind after Rolex’s involvement in the pioneering ascent of Everest with Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay, the Explorer I has a delightfully clear, readable face, uncluttered by a date complication. The case is smoother and more rounded than other Rolex sports models, even more so than it initially appears.

Introduced in 2013, the Blackbird is a seriously good looking update for Breitling's Avenger series, and a welcome new member of the brand's growing compendium of awesome “stealth” (black-on-black) pieces. The watch may be a reference to the equally cool, black and stealthy SR-71 Blackbird – a legendary US Air Force reconnaissance plane that played a key part in the Cold War. With its carbon-treated titanium case and comparatively slim profile, this Blackbird is as ergonomic and lightweight as its namesake. The dial is super legible and glare-proof, while the movement is based on a premium Swiss chronometer.

Before the legendary Calibre 360, which made headlines as the first mechanical chronograph movement capable of measuring hundredths of a second, there was the Calibre 36. Equally legendary, in its way, the 36 displays tenths of a second thanks to its super-high frequency of 5Hz (most high-end chronographs beat at 4Hz). This might remind you of another famous chronograph movement, and you'd be right: the Calibre 36 is a modified version of Zenith's El Primero – ironic, considering Heuer and Zenith were competitors in the famous 1969 race to build the first automatic chrono – although this one has been upgraded with additional flyback capability. This gorgeous, cutting-edge Carrera evolves the remarkable Mikrograph design with a darker ring encompassing a gloriously brushed anthracite centre.

Invented in the 1930s as one of the first wristwatches made to be as precise as a marine chronometer, the Portuguese collection has a long history, though it wasn't produced in serious numbers until the 1990s. Today they're among IWC's finest watches, beloved by collectors for their graceful, uncluttered design and classic aesthetic featuring thin bezels and sword-like hands. This exquisite model runs on an automatic movement, IWC calibre 79350, with a superb chronograph mechanism. While adding a dash of sporting appeal to this elegant watch, the chrono display is subtly integrated and in no way detracts from the clean, sophisticated design.

Based in the historic watch-making German town from which it takes its name, Glashutte Original was a company that was absorbed into the collectivized VEB Glashutter Uhrenbetriebe group of watchmakers in the former communist East Germany. After the country’s reunification it re-launched and has been thriving ever since, along with its illustrious neighbour A. Lange & Sohne. This skeletonised edition of the Senator Manual model showcases its manually wound Calibre 49-18 movement, with almost every visible part of it embellished by the exquisite skills of the company’s hand engravers. Adding to the aesthetic beauty is a highly polished 42mm red gold case, within which is galvanized silver dial with black roman numerals and blued-steel leaf hands. The power reserve is a respectable 40 hours.

Since 1946, British aerospace company Martin-Baker has saved the lives of at least 7,450 pilots. That's because it makes ejection seats—one of the most vital pieces of safety equipment on any high-speed aircraft. Martin-Baker seats are the best of the best, tested to the most punishing levels of endurance and extremes of shock, vibration, temperature and more. Amazingly, Bremont's Martin-Baker watches have been put through the same rigours used on the ejection seats, at the same test facility. Fitted with anti-shock movement mounts and Faraday cages, the MB watches are made to be the ultimate endurance chronometer, able to survive just about anything short of a direct meteor strike. They're also not half handsome to look at.

The U-2 is one of the most important high tech spy planes in the US Airforce. Nicknamed the Dragon Lady, early versions of the U-2 were in operation at the beginning of the Cold War, and continue to be flown by exceptional pilots based in Beale, California. Needless to say, this is the type of aviation history that Bremont adores. The U-2 collection is a sincerely heartfelt tribute to these amazing machines and the brave souls who fly them, often over 80,000 feet into the stratosphere for 12 hours or more at a time. The beautifully designed U-2 watches have, like the plane, been tested at even higher altitudes, as well as at temperature extremes of -40ºC or more, including tests “in the field” with the U-2 pilots themselves. The watch's ultra-durable Trip-Tick case contains an inner bezel operated by a crown at 4 o'clock and comes with a DLC coating.

The Engineer Hydrocarbon is perhaps Ball's most impressive watch collection, at least in terms of cutting-edge technology and imposing designs. These timepieces are big, practical and good looking, and their engineering is as exquisite as any of the brand's watches. Ball has created several brilliant Hydrocarbons over the years, but arguably none quite as remarkable as the Spacemaster. This model is known for its incredible tritium micro gas tubes on the dial and hands that create a distinctive glow (in a range of colours) for increased ease of reading at night. The gas maintains its extraordinary luminescence for at least 25 years, and does not dim at night, unlike modern luminous paint. The watch also features a detailed engraving of an astronaut on the caseback.

The Maurice Lacroix Masterpiece collection was the company's first line of beautiful, high-end watches that used mechanical movements founded on the best Swiss traditions. In 2006, it also became the first collection to use its in-house manufacture movements, propelling the brand into the upper echelons of haute horlogerie. With its position as one of the finest boutique watchmakers in the industry now firmly secured, Maurice Lacroix has gone from strength to strength, and this piece is a magnificent example. Also using an in-house movement, the watch has been skeletonised to stunning effect. The “Squelette”, as it's called, uses the finest hand-crafted traditional workmanship to create a watch with a modern, innovative spirit.

Montblanc's watchmaking career took off in 1997, after a long history of making the finest quality pens and having already been absorbed into the Richemont Group along with the likes of IWC and Jaeger-LeCoultre. But the brand didn't get serious attention from the watch community until its acquisition of the historic and prestigious Minerva manufacture, which allowed it to create its own in-house movements and step fully into the limelight. The new 1858 collection, of which this is a stunning limited edition example, was conceived to celebrate Minvera's long history, with a design that beautifully captures the style of its 1930s inspiration.

Bell & Ross has long been passionate about military watches—unsurprising given its perpetual focus on bringing function and utility to the forefront of luxury watchmaking. Most of the brand's true military styles have been reserved for the Vintage collection, but some of the best pieces to receive its coveted “Military Type” label can in fact be found in the instrument series (BR01 and BR03), which was originally based on aircraft cockpit instruments. Bell & Ross state that these pieces pay tribute to the first professionals, historically, who relied on wristwatches. They display an authentic military awareness of a need for extreme legibility, both at day and night, as well as serious durability and precision.

Inspired by the men’s suit of the same name, this Longines Heritage Classic Tuxedo Chronograph pays tribute to the carefree nature of the late 1940s that came after the austerity of the Second World War. This piece, then, with its black and white concentric dial, embodies the sartorial style of that era, while remaining up to date with handy features such as the automatic calibre L895 and chronograph sub dials at 3 and 9 o’clock. The tachymeter scale is beautifully accented in blue, matching the hands of the small seconds and minutes registers, as well as the big seconds hand.  This Longines is an ideal watch for fans of vintage aesthetics but modern specs.

The U-2 is one of the most important high tech spy planes in the US Airforce. Nicknamed the Dragon Lady, early versions of the U-2 were in operation at the beginning of the Cold War, and continue to be flown by exceptional pilots based in Beale, California. Needless to say, this is the type of aviation history that Bremont adores. The U-2 collection is a sincerely heartfelt tribute to these amazing machines and the brave souls who fly them, often over 80,000 feet into the stratosphere for 12 hours or more at a time. The beautifully designed U-2 watches have, like the plane, been tested at even higher altitudes, as well as at temperature extremes of -40ºC or more, including tests “in the field” with the U-2 pilots themselves. The watch's ultra-durable Trip-Tick case contains an inner bezel operated by a crown at 4 o’clock.

This Corum has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history. Launched as part of the instrument series in the mid-00s, the Bell & Ross BR03 collection can be seen as the iconic BR01's smaller-cased brother. Like the bigger watch, the BR03 is all about utilitarian luxury, striving for extreme clarity, precision and reliability, designed for professionals as well as watch collectors. Its immediately recognisable square case and instrument-style appearance has put it at the centre of the brand's popularity, and the smaller size makes the BR03 more comfortable for many wearers. The Phantom version made waves as one of the first and most successful all-black luxury watches—the full effect of this incredible model has to be seen to be believed.

“A true collaboration in research and development”, this watch hails from an exceptional collection that represents a groundbreaking partnership between aerospace giant Boeing and British horological brand-of-the-hour, Bremont. These timepieces use the most cutting-edge materials from Boeing's state-of-the-art facilities, although Bremont is keen to stress that in spirit they pay homage to an earlier chapter of the company's aircraft-building history. The partnership also involves the extraordinary expertise of the University of Sheffield's Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre (AMRC), to achieve the highest quality precision engineering. The watches are tested to the toughest levels of endurance.

The de Havilland DH-88 Comet was a legendary aircraft known for setting a string of extraordinary records in the 1930s. The plane was built for the famous MacRobertson Air Race from London to Melbourne in 1934 because there were no other British aircraft suitable for entry. Three teams flew DH-88 Comets on the race, and one of them, named Grosvenor House, won it—setting a new record of just under three days, despite the two pilots having to deal with severe exhaustion and mechanical failures. This fantastic limited edition commemorates this remarkable chapter with gorgeous rose gold and steel GMT timepieces that incorporates a fragment of original spruce plywood from the undercarriage of Grosvenor House in the rotor. Proceeds from sales were donated by Bremont to the Shuttleworth Trust to help maintain the aircraft, which continues to give regular displays.

Inspired by the men’s suit of the same name, this Longines Heritage Classic Tuxedo Chronograph pays tribute to the carefree nature of the late 1940s that came after the austerity of the Second World War. This piece, then, with its black and white concentric dial, embodies the sartorial style of that era, while remaining up to date with handy features such as the automatic calibre L895 and chronograph sub dials at 3 and 9 o’clock. The tachymeter scale is beautifully accented in blue, matching the hands of the small seconds and minutes registers, as well as the big seconds hand.  This Longines is an ideal watch for fans of vintage aesthetics but modern specs.

A superb diving watch, TAG Heuer's Aquaracer was first launched in 2004 as an evolution of the equally superb Heuer 2000 diver conceived by Jack Heuer in the 1980s. The series was devoted to professionals and adventurers, as well as water-sportsmen of all kinds, and particularly sailors and yachtsmen. The watches have improved and evolved over the years, leading to a range of magnificent models like the one for sale here, with its 300m water resistance, big date and chronograph functionality. Impressively, there's a tenth of a second counter at 6 o'clock, which is testament to the exceptional reliability and accuracy of the caliber inside.

Expanding on their hugely admired Heritage Black Bay series, Tudor released its Black Bay Fifty-Eight in 2018, inspired by the brand’s reference 7924 Oyster Prince Submariner, released in 1958—hence the name. Previously released Black Bays, still in production, had bigger cases—41mm, or even 43mm for the bronze model—but at 39mm the Black Bay Fifty-Eight is noticeably smaller and will suit those with a smaller wrist. A classic steel dive watch with a retro feel, including the faux-aged lume and distinctive red triangle on the aluminium bezel, this is a COSC-certified chronometer with 200m water resistance and an in-house movement—unlike the earliest Black Bays. Increasingly sought-after, this is a future classic that has further enhanced Tudor’s reputation and allowed it to step out of the shadow of its older sibling, Rolex.

Originally an evolution of its early automatics, the IWC Ingenieur was designed to combine the self-winding movement with the shock and magnetic resistance pioneered in some of the brand's pilot's watches. While the concept was successful and enjoyed various upgrades (including input from the legendary Gerald Genta), it was beginning to peter out in the early naughties. Seeking to refresh the collection, IWC partnered with Mercedes' high performance division, AMG, to create a series of cutting-edge timepieces that demonstrated both brands' commitment to the highest precision engineering. This model is made from zirconium-based ceramic, inspired by AMG's disc brakes, and houses the famous in-house Caliber 80110.

In watch form, the Carrera has been in existence since 1964, and continued Heuer’s great legacy in providing racing drivers with timing instruments. Named after the intense ‘Carrera Panamericana’ road race of the 1950’s (which also gave its name to the eponymous Porsche), the Carrera continues to provide timing for some of the world’s most prestigious racing teams today. This recent addition to the Carrera fold fully embodies that racing heritage with its lovely, paired-down tribute to vintage timepieces. The watch uses TAG's famous 1887 movement, a smooth column-wheel chronograph that features a modern version of the remarkable oscillating pinion first patented by the brand in 1887.

Sleek, menacing and black as night, the PAM 441's dark allure is not the result of any external PVD or DLC. It's a fully ceramic case, much harder than steel and amazingly durable, the result of an exceptionally long and arduous process of diamond-wheel machining and microglass blasting to achieve the gorgeous matt finish. The material is too hard to mould and is originally created by extreme isostatic pressing of zirconium oxide followed by sintering at around 1,500°C. The beautiful in-house P.9000 movement has an impressive power reserve of three days and also features a GMT complication.

This Hublot has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history. All our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind.

This gorgeous Portuguese Automatic has many excellent qualities, but perhaps the most interesting is the movement's power reserve. It's not just the impressive length of stored power, but also the technical ingenuity employed to go above and beyond the call of duty. The watch is engineered to come to an automatic stop after seven days, despite the fact that the actual power reserve is more like eight days. Why? This avoids relying on the last part of the mainspring's stored power, which would entail diminished torque and potential problems with consistent accuracy. When coupled with the Portuguese's handsome appearance and prestigious history, this watch is a very enticing offer indeed.

The de Havilland DH-88 Comet was a legendary aircraft known for setting a string of extraordinary records in the 1930s. The plane was built for the famous MacRobertson Air Race from London to Melbourne in 1934 because there were no other British aircraft suitable for entry. Three teams flew DH-88 Comets on the race, and one of them, named Grosvenor House, won it—setting a new record of just under three days, despite the two pilots having to deal with severe exhaustion and mechanical failures. This fantastic limited edition commemorates this remarkable chapter with gorgeous rose gold and steel GMT timepieces that incorporates a fragment of original spruce plywood from the undercarriage of Grosvenor House in the rotor. Proceeds from sales were donated by Bremont to the Shuttleworth Trust to help maintain the aircraft, which continues to give regular displays.

This gorgeous Portuguese Automatic has many excellent qualities, but perhaps the most interesting is the movement's power reserve. It's not just the impressive length of stored power, but also the technical ingenuity employed to go above and beyond the call of duty. The watch is engineered to come to an automatic stop after seven days, despite the fact that the actual power reserve is more like eight days. Why? This avoids relying on the last part of the mainspring's stored power, which would entail diminished torque and potential problems with consistent accuracy. When coupled with the Portuguese's handsome appearance and prestigious history, this watch is a very enticing offer indeed.
