The Transocean collection is one of Breitling's most sophisticated and elegant. Inspired by 1950s and 60s chronograph designs, it brings the brand's unmatched sporting watch prowess to new audiences, powered by Breitling's remarkable chronograph movements. This Unitime Pilot features the company's superb world timer complication, first developed in the 1950s but now improved with in-house calibre B05 (based on the groundbreaking B01). The high-frequency automatic chronograph movement allows the wearer to shift time zones with incredible ease via the crown, which controls the cities, hour hands and 24-hour ring simultaneously.

Given the Big Bang's origins, with its porthole-inspired design, there have been nautical themes in the collection from the start—if faint ones. So when it came time for Hublot to create its first “serious” diving watch, it made some sense to turn to the King Power, the even bigger, bolder version of the already spectacular Big Bang series. Hublot was never going to do things by halves. Made of lightweight titanium, this “Oceanographic” has a beastly 48mm case distinguished by the monstrous crown at 2 o'clock (its marginally smaller brother at 4 o'clock is for the inner bezel), and a super-legible, lume-heavy dial. The crystal is a massive 6.5mm thick, providing the immense water resistance (4,000m) that would keep this extraordinary watch safe and sound on the ocean floor.

Expanding on their hugely admired Heritage Black Bay series, Tudor released its Black Bay Fifty-Eight in 2018, inspired by the brand’s reference 7924 Oyster Prince Submariner, released in 1958—hence the name. Previously released Black Bays, still in production, had bigger cases—41mm, or even 43mm for the bronze model—but at 39mm the Black Bay Fifty-Eight is noticeably smaller and will suit those with a smaller wrist. A classic steel dive watch with a retro feel, including the faux-aged lume and distinctive red triangle on the aluminium bezel, this is a COSC-certified chronometer with 200m water resistance and an in-house movement—unlike the earliest Black Bays. Increasingly sought-after, this is a future classic that has further enhanced Tudor’s reputation and allowed it to step out of the shadow of its older sibling, Rolex.

Breitling's legendary Aerospace watches were originally unveiled in the mid-1980s as part of the Navitimer collection, created as the next step in the evolution of the brand's cutting-edge instruments for pilots. With the most accurate, high-tech Swiss superquartz movements on the market, the Aerospace was rapidly adopted by professionals as the ideal multi-function tool watch—its robust and lightweight titanium case and advanced analogue-digital display were also decisive factors in its popularity. Today, Aerospace models remain favourites for collectors and professionals alike, and they continue to provide the outstanding accuracy, reliability and legibility that have long made them so highly prized.

Introduced in 2013, the Blackbird is a seriously good looking update for Breitling's Avenger series, and a welcome new member of the brand's growing compendium of awesome “stealth” (black-on-black) pieces. The watch may be a reference to the equally cool, black and stealthy SR-71 Blackbird – a legendary US Air Force reconnaissance plane that played a key part in the Cold War. With its carbon-treated titanium case and comparatively slim profile, this Blackbird is as ergonomic and lightweight as its namesake. The dial is super legible and glare-proof, while the movement is based on a premium Swiss chronometer.

“A true collaboration in research and development”, this watch hails from an exceptional collection that represents a groundbreaking partnership between aerospace giant Boeing and British horological brand-of-the-hour, Bremont. These timepieces use the most cutting-edge materials from Boeing's state-of-the-art facilities, although Bremont is keen to stress that in spirit they pay homage to an earlier chapter of the company's aircraft-building history (this piece is inspired by its twin-engined Model 247 airliner from the 1930s). The partnership also involves the extraordinary expertise of the University of Sheffield's Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre (AMRC), to achieve the highest quality precision engineering. The watches are tested to the toughest levels of endurance.

This beautiful dress watch from Jaeger-LeCoultre is not just exceptionally well-designed, with a clean, easily readable face and gorgeous case proportions, it also represents phenomenal value for money on its movement, which features several intricate complications. The watch, released in 2014 and inspired by a vintage 1945 piece from the JLC archives, has a moonphase and a complete calendar with displays for date, day of the week, and month. With all this, it still manages to maintain a refined, minimalist aesthetic based around a highly uncluttered dial—in large part thanks to the uncommon pointer-type date display around the dial's circumference.

Bell & Ross has long been passionate about military watches—unsurprising given its perpetual focus on bringing function and utility to the forefront of luxury watchmaking. Most of the brand's true military styles have been reserved for the Vintage collection, but some of the best pieces to receive its coveted “Military Type” label can in fact be found in the instrument series (BR01 and BR03), which was originally based on aircraft cockpit instruments. Bell & Ross state that these pieces pay tribute to the first professionals, historically, who relied on wristwatches. They display an authentic military awareness of a need for extreme legibility, both at day and night, as well as serious durability and precision.

“A true collaboration in research and development”, this watch hails from an exceptional collection that represents a groundbreaking partnership between aerospace giant Boeing and British horological brand-of-the-hour, Bremont. These timepieces use the most cutting-edge materials from Boeing's state-of-the-art facilities, although Bremont is keen to stress that in spirit they pay homage to an earlier chapter of the company's aircraft-building history (this piece is inspired by its twin-engined Model 247 airliner from the 1930s). The partnership also involves the extraordinary expertise of the University of Sheffield's Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre (AMRC), to achieve the highest quality precision engineering. The watches are tested to the toughest levels of endurance.

Celebrated Italian jeweller Bulgari has been making its own timepieces since 1980 but watches have always played an important role for the brand. Since it started developing its own calibres it has produced a number of impressively thin and complicated models, including tourbillons and minute repeaters, with many of these coming within the Octo range. This Octo model comes in rose gold and is paired with a fine alligator strap. The octagonal case—which has a distinctive layered design— harks back to the designs of Gerald Genta, whose brand Bulgari purchased in 2000. The skeletonised dauphine hands and baton markers are also rose gold, with Arabic numerals at 12 and 6 o’clock and a date aperture at 3 o’clock that’s small enough not to intrude on the delightfully clean dial. A transparent caseback reveals the BVL 193 automatic movement with 50-hour power reserve. There’s no better dress watch to pair with a tuxedo.

Grand Seiko continues to excel at the apex of Japanese watch-making with a sublime range of techniques and skills that exist nowhere else. The most remarkable aspect of this dress watch from its Elegance collection is the lacquer made from the sap of the urushi trees found under Mount Iwate in northern Japan. The lacquer is mixed with iron to give it its deep, jet-black colour. The GS logo and hour markers for 6 and 12 o’clock are individually crafted by a urushi master who builds up the lacquer to create a 3-D profile before coating with powdered gold and polishing. Within the 39mm 18k rose gold case you’ll find Grand Seiko’s manual-wind Caliber 9S63, which holds a 72-hour power reserve. It’s also limited to just 150 pieces.

The “California” style dial, famous for its combination of Roman numerals, Arabic numerals and regular indexes, as well as the lack of brand name or other lettering, was used in Panerai's very earliest watches from the 1930s. The name comes from a company in California that was known for refurbishing many such dials. The 424 is based very closely on the original prototype Californias commissioned in 1936 by the Royal Italian Navy. This modern version with superb finishing is particularly delightful thanks to the stunning case, rich brown hue and the gold hands and minute track that go so nicely with it.

Calatrava began as a medieval order of religious knights; their emblem was to be adopted many centuries later by perhaps Switzerland's most prestigious and revered watchmaker of all time, Patek Philippe, as the brand logo (here seen on the strap clasp). Its flagship Calatrava watches are among the most elegant and distinguished in the world, as exemplified by this stunning commemorative edition for the company's 175th anniversary. Limited to just 400 pieces, the watch houses an upgraded in-house CH 28-520 movement with a multi-scale chronograph capable of computing a range of calculations (including pulsometer, telemeter and tachymeter), with a sweep chronograph hand that doubles as conventional seconds.

The “California” style dial, famous for its combination of Roman numerals, Arabic numerals and regular indexes, as well as the lack of brand name or other lettering, was used in Panerai's very earliest watches from the 1930s. The name comes from a company in California that was known for refurbishing many such dials. The 424 is based very closely on the original prototype Californias commissioned in 1936 by the Royal Italian Navy. This modern version with superb finishing is particularly delightful thanks to the stunning case, rich brown hue and the gold hands and minute track that go so nicely with it.

Breitling’s Navitimer pilot’s watch boasts the proud distinction of being the first Swiss wristwatch and chronograph in space, having been worn by NASA astronaut Scott Carpenter while orbiting the Earth in 1962 on the Mercury-Atlas 7 mission. Launched in 1952, it’s now one of the most recognisable watches around, with its three-register dial ringed with a tachymeter scale and circular aviation slide rule. This particular version in 18k rose gold is limited to 159 pieces and features specially tinted SuperLuminova coating on the hands and numerals to add to the vintage look. It’s powered by the in-house Caliber B09 which holds a power reserve of 70 hours.

In 1884, in a small town up in the Jura mountains called St. Imier, Léon Breitling opened a workshop that specialised in high-precision scientific measuring and timing equipment. So good were his creations that their popularity demanded he relocate to a larger workshop, which he did in 1892. The new factory was on Montbrillant Street, La-Chaux-de-Fonds, and it remained there until 1979. Taking its name from this historic location where many watchmaking firsts occurred, the Breitling Montbrillant sources its visual inspiration from the aviator watches of the 1940s and 1950s that debuted and featured the famous Breitling slide rule. The Datora model, with its additional calendar complications, is inspired by a particularly successful piece from this period.

The Transocean collection is one of Breitling's most sophisticated and elegant. Inspired by 1950s and 60s chronograph designs, it brings the brand's unmatched sporting watch prowess to new audiences, powered by Breitling's remarkable chronograph movements. This Unitime Pilot features the company's superb world timer complication, first developed in the 1950s but now improved with in-house calibre B05 (based on the groundbreaking B01). The high-frequency automatic chronograph movement allows the wearer to shift time zones with incredible ease via the crown, which controls the cities, hour hands and 24-hour ring simultaneously.

Breitling's legendary Aerospace watches were originally unveiled in the mid-1980s as part of the Navitimer collection, created as the next step in the evolution of the brand's cutting-edge instruments for pilots. With the most accurate, high-tech Swiss superquartz movements on the market, the Aerospace was rapidly adopted by professionals as the ideal multi-function tool watch—its robust and lightweight titanium case and advanced analogue-digital display were also decisive factors in its popularity. Today, Aerospace models remain favourites for collectors and professionals alike, and they continue to provide the outstanding accuracy, reliability and legibility that have long made them so highly prized.

Breitling's legendary Aerospace watches were originally unveiled in the mid-1980s as part of the Navitimer collection, created as the next step in the evolution of the brand's cutting-edge instruments for pilots. With the most accurate, high-tech Swiss superquartz movements on the market, the Aerospace was rapidly adopted by professionals as the ideal multi-function tool watch—its robust and lightweight titanium case and advanced analogue-digital display were also decisive factors in its popularity. Today, Aerospace models remain favourites for collectors and professionals alike, and they continue to provide the outstanding accuracy, reliability and legibility that have long made them so highly prized.

The Transocean collection is one of Breitling's most sophisticated and elegant. Inspired by 1950s and 60s chronograph designs, it brings the brand's unmatched sports watch prowess to new audiences, powered by Breitling's remarkable chronograph movements. This limited edition Unitime Pilot features the company's superb world timer complication, first developed in the 1950s but now improved with in-house calibre B05 (based on the groundbreaking B01). The high-frequency automatic chronograph movement allows the wearer to shift time zones with incredible ease via the crown, which controls the cities, hour hands and 24-hour ring simultaneously.

In 1884, in a small town up in the Jura mountains called St. Imier, Léon Breitling opened a workshop that specialised in high-precision scientific measuring and timing equipment. So good were his creations that their popularity demanded that he relocated to a larger workshop, which he did in 1892. The new factory was on Montbrillant Street, La-Chaux-de-Fonds, and it remained there until 1979. Taking its name from this historic location where many watchmaking firsts occurred, the Breitling Montbrillant sources its visual inspiration from the aviator watches of the 1940s and 1950s that debuted the famous Breitling slide rule. This wonderful special edition, dubbed “100 years of aviation”, was made for the anniversary of the Wright brothers' landmark first flight in 1903.

This Breitling has undergone a thorough inspection of accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history. Our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind, in conjunction with any remaining manufacturer’s warranty from new or from service.

The Rolex Explorer is one of the most highly valued and sough-after models in the world of vintage watch collecting. Originally based on the model worn by Tenzing Norgay in the first ever successful ascent of Everest in 1953, the famous ref 1016 Explorer was an evolution of two equally interesting preceding watches, the 6350 and 6610, and was manufactured from the late 60s to mid 80s. A versatile vintage timepiece that enjoyed numerous variations, the Explorer 1016 remains one of the best examples of Rolex's genius for combining sport and dress elements in their watches.

The “California” style dial, famous for its combination of Roman numerals, Arabic numerals and regular indexes, as well as the lack of brand name or other lettering, was used in Panerai's very earliest watches from the 1930s. The name comes from a company in California that was known for refurbishing many such dials. The 424 is based very closely on the original prototype Californias commissioned in 1936 by the Royal Italian Navy. This modern version with superb finishing is particularly delightful thanks to the stunning case, rich brown hue and the gold hands and minute track that go so nicely with it.

“A true collaboration in research and development”, this watch hails from an exceptional collection that represents a groundbreaking partnership between aerospace giant Boeing and British horological brand-of-the-hour, Bremont. These timepieces use the most cutting-edge materials from Boeing's state-of-the-art facilities, although Bremont is keen to stress that in spirit they pay homage to an earlier chapter of the company's aircraft-building history (this piece is inspired by its twin-engined Model 247 airliner from the 1930s). The partnership also involves the extraordinary expertise of the University of Sheffield's Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre (AMRC), to achieve the highest quality precision engineering. The watches are tested to the toughest levels of endurance.

Tudor has stepped out of the shadow of its older sister brand Rolex in recent years, offering watches that feature some of the hallmarks of its more illustrious sibling but at a more accessible price point. It forged its distinct personality largely by delving into its archives and reviving old models, including the Pelagos, a version of a Tudor Submariner from the 1970s. This left-hand winder is powered by an MT5612 in-house calibre, which replaced the ETA movement of previous Pelagos models. It bears the now-iconic Tudor ‘snowflake’ hands, echoed in the square indexes, and the date is displayed in the window at 3 o’clock. The 42mm case is a blend of steel and titanium, while the bezel—also titanium—is coated in matt black ceramic. A handsome and versatile divers’ watch, it is water resistant to 500 metres, boasts a helium escape valve at 3 o’clock and holds a 70-hour power reserve.

This Tudor has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. All our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind.

The Autavia is one of TAG Heuer’s several iconic sports chronographs that includes the Carrera and, more famously, the Monaco. Produced between the 1960s and the 1980s, it was inspired by the period dashboard instruments of racing cars and worn by drivers including Jo Siffert. This version combines a three-register chronograph with a GMT function and also features a ‘Pepsi’ bezel which has retained its vivid blue and red colours in this particular example from circa 1971. TAG Heuer brought back the Autavia line in 2016 after a long hiatus so this original vintage model, made long before Heuer merged with TAG (Techniques d’Avant Garde),  is highly sought-after among collectors of the brand. The watch runs on a Valjoux 724 manual winding movement, which is based on the same movement that powered early Rolex chronographs. A vintage perforated strap completes the motor-racing aesthetic of this wonderful timepiece.

There’s a reason Audemars Piguet is a member of the so-called Holy Trinity of watchmakers and it’s not for its sporty Royal Oak model, exceptional as it is. This model—named after its co-founder, Edward Auguste Piguet—is a reminder of the brand’s mastery of elegant watches with high complications. Reminiscent of the company’s pre-Royal Oak era, this platinum-cased rectangular dress watch features a manual wind movement with tourbillon, visible through the large aperture at 6 o’clock, while above it is a rectangle filled with a mesmerising gulloche pattern and the Audemars Piguet name beneath 12 o’clock. Odd numbers are represented by baton indices and even numbers by Breguet-style Arabic numerals, both of which are applied. Boasting a beautifully finished movement visible through the caseback, this is an exceptional timepiece by one of the world’s greatest watch brands.

“A true collaboration in research and development”, this watch hails from an exceptional collection that represents a groundbreaking partnership between aerospace giant Boeing and British horological brand-of-the-hour, Bremont. Originally an evolution of its early automatics, the IWC Ingenieur was designed to combine the self-winding movement with the shock and magnetic resistance pioneered in some of the brand's pilot's watches. While the concept was successful and enjoyed various upgrades (including input from the legendary Gerald Genta), it was beginning to peter out in the early naughties. Seeking to refresh the collection, IWC partnered with Mercedes' high performance division, AMG, to create a series of cutting-edge timepieces that demonstrated both brands' commitment to the highest precision engineering. This model is made from zirconium-based ceramic, inspired by AMG's disc brakes, and houses the famous in-house Caliber 80110.

You may have noticed the Hublot branding on Ferrari cars and drivers in recent years—this is of course the result of a powerful partnership that works two ways. Hublot has been creating extra special timepieces in honour of the legendary Italian carmaker, including its record-breaking “LaFerrari” watch that turned heads with a 50-day power reserve. This stunning Big Bang is only slightly less impressive. It's a visual treat, with the chequered carbon fibre bezel augmented by the strikingly skeletonised dial, tinted sapphire and Ferrari's stallion at 9 o'clock. The interior is no less amazing, boasting Hublot's groundbreaking in-house calibre, the UNICO, with tungsten rotor, flyback capability and three days of power.

This Tudor has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history. All our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind.

Piaget was founded in 1874 and over the course of its history has earned a reputation as an accomplished manufacturer of ultra-thin movements, which they supplied to the likes of Rolex, Omega and Audemars Piguet for many years. Its elegant Altiplano line, which uses its very thinnest movements, includes what was once the world’s thinnest self-winding watch, the Ultimate 910P. That measured in at a wafer-like height of 4.3mm, while this Altiplano Skeleton model in a white gold 38mm case isn’t far behind at a super-slender 5.34mm. Its in-house calibre 1200S is stamped with the prestigious Geneva Seal and incorporates a platinum micro-rotor, visible through both sides of the case. The power reserve on this stunning dress watch is 44 hours.

The “California” style dial, famous for its combination of Roman numerals, Arabic numerals and regular indexes, as well as the lack of brand name or other lettering, was used in Panerai's very earliest watches from the 1930s. The name comes from a company in California that was known for refurbishing many such dials. The 424 is based very closely on the original prototype Californias commissioned in 1936 by the Royal Italian Navy. This modern version with superb finishing is particularly delightful thanks to the stunning case, rich brown hue and the gold hands and minute track that go so nicely with it.

When Buzz Aldrin stepped out of the lunar module, codenamed ‘Eagle’, and onto the powdery surface of the moon, the Omega Speedmaster on his wrist became the legendary Moonwatch. Tested to the limits by NASA for the rigours of space flight, the Speedmaster had in fact been into space before the testing had even begun. In October 1962, astronaut Wally Schirra took his own personal Speedmaster on board Sigma 7 and orbited Earth a total of six times for the Mercury 7 mission. The Speedmaster continued to provide NASA astronauts with invaluable service for the Apollo 13 mission, when it was used to time the crucial burn that would return the astronauts safely to Earth.

This gorgeous Portuguese Automatic has many excellent qualities, but perhaps the most interesting is the movement's power reserve. It's not just the impressive length of stored power, but also the technical ingenuity employed to go above and beyond the call of duty. The watch is engineered to come to an automatic stop after seven days, despite the fact that the actual power reserve is more like eight days. Why? This avoids relying on the last part of the mainspring's stored power, which would entail diminished torque and potential problems with consistent accuracy. When coupled with the Portuguese's handsome appearance and prestigious history, this watch is a very enticing offer indeed.

“A true collaboration in research and development”, this watch hails from an exceptional collection that represents a groundbreaking partnership between aerospace giant Boeing and British horological brand-of-the-hour, Bremont. These timepieces use the most cutting-edge materials from Boeing's state-of-the-art facilities, although Bremont is keen to stress that in spirit they pay homage to an earlier chapter of the company's aircraft-building history. The partnership also involves the extraordinary expertise of the University of Sheffield's Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre (AMRC), to achieve the highest quality precision engineering. The watches are tested to the toughest levels of endurance.

column21: In watch form, the Carrera has been in existence since 1964, continuing Heuer’s great legacy in providing racing drivers with timing instruments. Named after the intense 'Carrera Panamerica' road race of the 1950s (which also gave its name to the eponymous Porsche), the Carrera has long been sought to provide timing for some of the world’s most prestigious racing teams. This addition to the Carrera collection fully embodies that racing heritage with its large 60-second chronograph counter, as well as racing-themed colouring and tachymeter scale on the bezel.

Before the legendary Calibre 360, which made headlines as the first mechanical chronograph movement capable of measuring hundredths of a second, there was the Calibre 36. Equally legendary, in its way, the 36 can count tenths of a second thanks to its super-high frequency of 5Hz (most high-end chronographs beat at 4Hz). This might remind you of another famous chronograph movement, and you'd be right: the Calibre 36 is a modified version of Zenith's El Primero—ironic, considering Heuer and Zenith were competitors in the famous 1969 race to build the first automatic chrono—although this one has been upgraded with additional flyback capability. This gorgeous, cutting-edge Carrera evolves the remarkable Mikrograph design with a silver ring encompassing a gloriously brushed anthracite centre.

This Panerai Radiomir is 1 of 1000 made and features a ‘tropical’ dial. 
The watch’s dial has been fashioned to resemble the patina seen on vintage Panerai watches which have suffered the effects of radioactive exposure. The Radiomir paint in the vintage watches emitted gamma rays, from the radioactive Radium, and aged the watch in a fashion which turned the originally black paint to a light brown colour. 
Brevetatto, the Italian for patented, is inscribed around the bezel and refers to the design of the watch which adheres to a vintage aesthetic, Panerai have used a 12-sided bezel like those found on prototype watches from the 1930’s.

Originally an evolution of its early automatics, the IWC Ingenieur was designed to combine the self-winding movement with the shock and magnetic resistance pioneered in some of the brand's pilot's watches. Created by the legendary designer Gerald Genta in the 1970s, the watch was allegedly inspired by a diving helmet, giving Genta the relatively new idea of leaving the functional case elements like screws and bores exposed, instead of hiding them away. This modernist aesthetic was a huge success for IWC, and the Ingenieur has become a horological icon. The same principles are still evident in this stunning “Climate Action” limited edition made in support of The Climate Group, a non-profit campaigning for a low-carbon economy.

The U-2 is one of the most important high-tech spy planes in the US Airforce. Nicknamed the Dragon Lady, early versions of the U-2 were in operation at the beginning of the Cold War, and continue to be flown by exceptional pilots based in Beale, California. Needless to say, this is the type of aviation history that Bremont adores. The U-2 collection is a sincerely heartfelt tribute to these amazing machines and the brave souls who fly them, often over 80,000 feet into the stratosphere for 12 hours or more at a time. The beautifully designed U-2 watches have, like the plane, been tested at even higher altitudes, as well as at temperature extremes of -40ºC or more—including tests “in the field” with the U-2 pilots themselves. The watch's ultra-durable Trip-Tick case contains an inner bezel operated by a crown at 4 o'clock.

This exquisite Panerai gem is a masterclass in subtlety in fine watchmaking. At first glance, the watch seems not too dissimilar to other Luminor pieces, with its gorgeous vintage Italian aesthetic, beloved of so many collectors. But inside, the PAM 306 is powered by Panerai's in-house calibre P.2005, which boasts a magnificent 30-second tourbillon cage. Where other brands would have put the prestigious tourbillon on the dial, Panerai keeps it a subtle feature for true watch lovers to admire through the caseback—alongside the equally impressive six-day power reserve display. The watch is a titanium limited edition of just 150 pieces, and also features GMT and day/night indications, while the small dot in the 9 o'clock subdial shows the tourbillon's half-minute rotation.

First released in 2009, the original King Power is a sizeable watch at 48mm, making it a controversial piece that splits opinion, although it has attracted the attention of two incredibly famous sporting legends in Diego Maradona and Usain Bolt, elevating the watch’s appeal. This limited-edition King Power Tourbillon GMT is one of only 28 examples in existence, making it a perfect collector’s piece. With a hand-wound tourbillon GMT movement visible through the skeleton dial and a handy calendar in the 9 o’clock position, all sat within a porthole-shaped bezel, the King Power Tourbillon GMT Zirconium is a futuristic watch suitable for everyday wear.

This Breguet has undergone a thorough inspection of water resistance, accuracy, functionality and condition to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history. All our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind.

From the brand that was founded by the Godfather of horology, Abraham-Louis Breguet, this remarkable model is a world-timer with a highly unusual instant jumping time-zone display covering 24 cities. The pusher at 8 o’clock is used to set the reference city, while the crown at 3 o’clock sets the time. Switching between two cities is simple, masking the complexity of the automatic movement within, which can be viewed through the transparent caseback. The watch also bears the hallmarks of this illustrious watchmaker, with classic Breguet Roman numerals and ‘pomme’ hands. The case is rose gold with an ornate fluted band and the dial is dominated by a map of the western hemisphere, with a day and night indicator between 3 o’clock and 4 o’clock. Windows at 12 and 6 o’clock reveal the date and the city to which the displayed time is set. This is one of the most luxurious travel watches around and a must for any serious Breguet collectors.

This rare and incredibly elegant perpetual calendar is a true technical marvel. It's not just the quantity of data it records, from the date (including a four-digit year display) to the moonphase (with separate indications for northern and southern hemispheres) and even the seriously impressive seven-day power reserve (indicated inside the 3 o'clock subdial). The most extraordinary part of the watch is in fact the humble—yet sophisticated—crown. Based on the original design by the legendary watchmaker Kurt Klaus, the entire watch is set by the single crown; all components are connected so that you don't have to redo each little display one by one.

IWC's Top Gun series stands as a tribute to the elite pilot's training centre for the US Marines in Miramar, California, immortalised by the iconic 1986 Tom Cruise motion picture. The design is built to recall the deck watches of the 1930s and 1940s, referencing IWC's history in pilot's watches.  This impressive watch also features an elaborate Top Gun engraving, stunning anthracite dial and an extra lightweight ceramic and titanium case made with zirconium oxide fired at temperatures approaching 2,000 degrees centigrade. The in-house calibre 51111 has a seven day power reserve, and the watch comes with a military style green textile strap.

IWC's Da Vinci collection pays homage to one of the most inventive thinkers of history, the Renaissance Italian genius who was actually one of Europe's earliest mechanical horologists. A number of da Vinci's inventions, while unable to be built during his lifetime, have since been incorporated into mechanical watches. IWC's first Da Vinci timepiece, from the 1960s, showcased some of the most advanced quartz technology ever made at the time. The collection was revived in the 1980s, this time featuring a spectacular mechanical movement with a perpetual calendar designed by the legendary Kurt Klaus. Since then, Da Vinci watches have achieved more world firsts and turned many heads. This beautiful, platinum, retro-flavoured “vintage” edition was inspired by one of the earliest models.

“A true collaboration in research and development”, this watch hails from an exceptional collection that represents a groundbreaking partnership between aerospace giant Boeing and British horological brand-of-the-hour, Bremont. These timepieces use the most cutting-edge materials from Boeing's state-of-the-art facilities, although Bremont is keen to stress that in spirit they pay homage to an earlier chapter of the company's aircraft-building history. This exceptionally rare GMT limited edition, boasting an advanced aerospace-grade titanium case, was made exclusively for Royal Navy crew members who operate a Merlin helicopter—an image of which can be seen on the dial.

The de Havilland DH-88 Comet was a legendary aircraft known for setting a string of extraordinary records in the 1930s. The plane was built for the famous MacRobertson Air Race from London to Melbourne in 1934 because there were no other British aircraft suitable for entry. Three teams flew DH-88 Comets on the race, and one of them, named Grosvenor House, won it—setting a new record of just under three days, despite the two pilots having to deal with severe exhaustion and mechanical failures. This fantastic limited edition commemorates this remarkable chapter with gorgeous rose gold and steel GMT timepieces that incorporates a fragment of original spruce plywood from the undercarriage of Grosvenor House in the rotor. Proceeds from sales were donated by Bremont to the Shuttleworth Trust to help maintain the aircraft, which continues to give regular displays.

The Big Bang has long been prized for its bold, uncompromising design and innovative use of new materials. Drawing on and expanding the porthole and fusion ideas of previous Hublot watches, the Big Bang was instantly hailed as outstanding when launched in 2005, and is now firmly established as one of the most iconic sports watches of the 21st century. But it wasn't until more recently that the watch really came into its own with the addition of Hublot's proprietary Unico movement, made entirely in-house. A major milestone for the brand, the Unico stars in a new series of Big Bangs with gorgeously skeletonised dials, such as the superb carbon fibre, flyback model on offer here.

Nicolas Rieussec was the first collection launched by Montblanc after the company took control of the prestigious Minerva manufacture in Villeret. The watches are named after the French inventor of the chronograph, which was originally a device that measured intervals by moving a pen in contact with rotating paper, drawing an arc as it went (hence the name chronograph, from the Greek for “time-writing”). The Nicolas Rieussec watches were also the first to house an in-house Montblanc movement, propelling the brand into the upper echelons of haute horlogerie. Matching tradition with innovation, this stunning watch is a monopusher column-wheel chrono, with a second timezone on the main dial paired with a day/night indicator that mirrors the date window.

Here we have a very special model, available in only 100 pieces worldwide, with a remarkable red-tinted crystal and a stunning, skeletonised dial. This unique King Power watch has a large ceramic case and sandblasted bezel. The Big Bang has long been prized for its bold, uncompromising designs and innovative use of new materials, and is now firmly established as one of the most iconic sports watches of the 21st century. Featuring the in-house calibre UN-170 movement, boasting an impressive power reserve of 170 hours, the Skeleton Tourbillon features advanced silicium technology. Released in 2014 after a standout display at Baselworld a year prior, the Skeleton Tourbillon Manufacture is an excellent example of a skeleton watch—down to the leaf-shaped hour and minute hands, whose tips are also skeletonised. As in the name, even the tourbillon itself is impressively skeletonised, being a first for the watchmaker. Ulysse Nardin even designed the tourbillon from scratch, opting out of simply skeletonising one of its existing movements. Perfect for collectors, being very rare, this stunning watch is limited to just 99 pieces in both white and rose gold.

Describing its aesthetic as elegant, simple and creative, Vacheron Constantin has continually aimed to enhance and reinvent the art of fine watchmaking since its introduction over 265 years ago, cementing its place within the top three watchmakers in the world. This Patrimony exists within a classic line of Traditionnelle watches, and features a stunning open-worked, skeletonised dial that perfectly shows off the beautiful inner workings of the calibre 1003 SQRH. This movement features 118 components and 18 jewels that oscillate at 28,800vph plus a 31-hour power reserve. The movement, fitted with a solid 22-karat gold oscillating rotor, is also certified with the Hallmark of Geneva. With its striking white gold dial, bezel and black alligator strap, this watch is a bonafide head-turner.

The Big Bang has long been prized for its bold, uncompromising designs and innovative use of new materials. Drawing on and expanding the porthole and fusion ideas of previous Hublot watches, the Big Bang was instantly hailed as outstanding when launched in 2005, and is now firmly established as one of the most iconic sports watches of the 21st century. The watches are known not just for their eye-catching, stylish designs, but also for their sense of fun and the fact that they are not afraid to move beyond aesthetics associated with “traditional” or historic watchmaking. This bright and delightfully skeletonised “Aero Bang” edition, limited to just 500 pieces, features a superb ceramic case.

This is an especially rare and unusual complication from the ultra-prestigious and highly prized manufacture Arnold & Son, and in fact hails from the brand's most exclusive watch series, the Instrument collection. The DBG is a fascinating watch that is inspired by two historical masterpieces by John Roger Arnold, son of the legendary London watchmaker of the same name who, together with Breguet, invented watchmaking as we know it today.

The aim was to build a watch capable of showing two time zones simultaneously, with the ability to set quarter- or half-hour differences. This was a major technical problem for watchmakers, because the gearing in a movement does not allow completely independent adjustment. Arnold solved the issue by installing a second barrel, gear train and escapement, completely separate from the main movement. This is the same system used in this DBG, which has two symmetrically arranged mechanical halves, partially visible on the dial, as well as two main displays. The small subdial at 12 o'clock shows the two systems' equation of time.

Corum has launched a number of highly unusual designs since its launch in 1955, with notable models including its heritage coin watches—made using real gold coins—and even a watch with a dial coated in a genuine bird’s feather. Its first Golden Bridge model was launched in 1980 and the collection is characterised by a baguette-shaped manual movement that spans the dial from top to bottom and is displayed through the transparent dial and caseback. It remains a unique construction in the world of fine watchmaking and is one of the most striking skeleton dials around. The tonneau-shaped case is made from yellow gold and the crown is located at the bottom of the case rather than the side, adding to its highly unorthodox aesthetic.

“A true collaboration in research and development”, this watch hails from an exceptional collection that represents a groundbreaking partnership between aerospace giant Boeing and British horological brand-of-the-hour, Bremont. These timepieces use the most cutting-edge materials from Boeing's state-of-the-art facilities, although Bremont is keen to stress that in spirit they pay homage to an earlier chapter of the company's aircraft-building history (this piece is inspired by its twin-engined Model 247 airliner from the 1930s). The partnership also involves the extraordinary expertise of the University of Sheffield's Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre (AMRC), to achieve the highest quality precision engineering. The watches are tested to the toughest levels of endurance.

This Panerai Radiomir is 1 of 1000 made and features a ‘tropical’ dial. 
The watch’s dial has been fashioned to resemble the patina seen on vintage Panerai watches which have suffered the effects of radioactive exposure. The Radiomir paint in the vintage watches emitted gamma rays, from the radioactive Radium, and aged the watch in a fashion which turned the originally black paint to a light brown colour. 
Brevetatto, the Italian for patented, is inscribed around the bezel and refers to the design of the watch which adheres to a vintage aesthetic, Panerai have used a 12-sided bezel like those found on prototype watches from the 1930’s.

Panerai has a long history of making stylish and super-reliable watches for professional divers, beginning with its famed WW2 contract for the Italian Navy's “Frogmen”. The PAM Submersible pieces are among Panerai's finest diving tools, and this one is particularly remarkable. While the watch runs on a superb Swiss mechanical movement, an electronic module has also been fitted. Consisting of a pressure transducer, microprocessor, lithium battery and other components, it acts as a depth gauge, allowing wearers to measure their distance below the surface on a three-part scale around the outside of the dial. The movement has achieved COSC certification, and so too the depth gauge has been independently tested and certified by the Swiss Federal Office for Metrology (METAS).

This Hublot King Power is 1 of 500 and is fashioned out of black ceramic. 

The watch features a foudroyant at 3 o’clock on the dial, this is a complication that counts 1/8th of a second. The timepiece also features a rattrapante or a split-second chronograph which can be accessed using a pusher built into crown. At 48 mm this Hublot King Power is the epitome of an oversized watch, the timepiece maintains a classically Hublot aesthetic with the porthole inspired casing and the H patterned Hublot bezel bolts. The blackening of the main dial and sub dials sacrifice legibility for style, and the monolithic black impression of the watch certainly leaves an impression.

This special limited edition Panerai Luminor pays tribute to some of the brand's vintage early 20th century models when Panerai was making watches for the Italian and Egyptian Navies. At this time, certain rare models had the words “Marina Militare” and “8 giorni brevettato” (“8 days patented”), which have been replicated here. In addition, the 339 was the first watch to feature Panerai's special ceramic case material. It's called “composite” instead of ceramic to differentiate it from the ceramics of other watchmakers, which are typically made with a zirconium base. Panerai's is made by electrochemical processes using aluminium, making it harder and tougher than other ceramics, not to mention lighter than even titanium. The in-house P.2000/7 movement has an impressive power reserve of eight days, a nod to the original "8 giorni brevettato".

column21: Released in 2014, the Hublot Classic Fusion Tourbillon Night-Out is described as Hublot’s evening watch. This Night-Out in particular is a glitzy showstopper, as opposed to the original more pared down Night-Out. It boasts a diamond paved dial and rose gold bezel set with even more diamonds and a tourbillon, visible at 6 o’clock, making for a striking design element which is also visible on the sapphire case back. A spin off from the original Classic Fusion introduced in 1980, with its port hole inspired bezel, the Night-Out adds some exciting features to Hublot’s more understated and minimalistic original Classic Fusion line.

The de Havilland DH-88 Comet was a legendary aircraft known for setting a string of extraordinary records in the 1930s. The plane was built for the famous MacRobertson Air Race from London to Melbourne in 1934 because there were no other British aircraft suitable for entry. Three teams flew DH-88 Comets on the race, and one of them, named Grosvenor House, won it—setting a new record of just under three days, despite the two pilots having to deal with severe exhaustion and mechanical failures. This fantastic limited edition commemorates this remarkable chapter with gorgeous rose gold and steel GMT timepieces that incorporates a fragment of original spruce plywood from the undercarriage of Grosvenor House in the rotor. Proceeds from sales were donated by Bremont to the Shuttleworth Trust to help maintain the aircraft, which continues to give regular displays.

In the interests of preserving original features, utmost care has been taken to sympathetically restore this watch. It has also been referenced against technical documents and manufacturer records where available to ensure authenticity and a clean history.

The first AMVOX was launched in 2004 by Jaeger-LeCoultre in partnership with legendary carmaker Aston Martin. While this brand's initials account for the first two letters of the AMVOX acronym, the “vox” part refers to JLC's iconic 1950s Memovox diving watch, which was known for its extraordinary alarm function. Created by design genius Francis Cretin, the watch was made with more than passing echoes of the glorious Memovox (especially the Polaris model), while simultaneously introducing ideas from Aston Martin dashboards. This superb, more recent limited edition is the fifth of the AMVOX models, and boasts a prestigious world timer complication.

The “California” style dial, famous for its combination of Roman numerals, Arabic numerals and regular indexes, as well as the lack of brand name or other lettering, was used in Panerai's very earliest watches from the 1930s. The name comes from a company in California that was known for refurbishing many such dials. The 424 is based very closely on the original prototype Californias commissioned in 1936 by the Royal Italian Navy. This modern version with superb finishing is particularly delightful thanks to the stunning case, rich brown hue and the gold hands and minute track that go so nicely with it.

This remarkable Audemars Piguet perpetual calendar in platinum was created to celebrate the thirtieth anniversary of the brand's reference 25548 model, which was released in 1978 and helped keep its tradition of haute horlogerie alive during the quartz era. Limited to just 90 pieces, it bears all the hallmarks of high-end Swiss watchmaking, with hand-finishing throughout, from the movement components to the noticeably thin case and its brushed steel sides. On the metallic blue sunburst dial are four registers that show both the triple calendar and leap year indicator, as well as the moon phase. Through the exhibition caseback you’ll find a spectacular winding rotor that is both skeletonised and hand-engraved while the bridges bear classic Geneva stripes. This is Audemars Piguet at its finest.

Named after the village of Le Brassus in the Vallee de Joux where Blancpain makes some of its most complicated timepieces, this stunning split-second chronograph from Switzerland’s oldest watchmaker comes in an exquisite rose gold case, matched by the dial’s Roman numerals and ‘feuille’ hands.  A power reserve indicator is positioned at 12 o’clock, while a date aperture is discreetly placed at 6 o’clock. The automatic movement can be viewed through the exhibition caseback and features a skeletonised, engraved rotor with the letter ‘B’ at its centre. This is a chance to own a highly elegant chronograph at the dressier end of the spectrum, from one of Switzerland’s most prestigious watch brands.

Founded in 1846 but revived in the 1980s after a period of dormancy brought on by the quartz crisis, Ulysse Nardin is a hallowed watchmaker that made its name with extremely accurate marine chronometers. These days its known for producing technological wonders such as the Freak and astronomical watches like the Planetarium Copernicus. Its El Toro collection brings an element of fun and colour to high-end watchmaking, combining a GMT function with a perpetual calendar that also, unusually, displays the year—all of which comes via an idiosyncratic layout on the deep red dial. The case is platinum with a black ceramic 24-hour bezel and features a sapphire caseback—which bears the words ‘Boca Raton, Concourse d’Elegance’, after the classic car event—revealing the automatic Caliber UN-32  movement within. This watch is limited to just 500 pieces.

column21: Hublot burst onto the Swiss watchmaking scene in 1980 with the most groundbreaking new design that the industry had seen in years. The idea was simple: a luxury gold watch made in the bold “porthole” style, but fitted with a rubber bracelet. The idea of “Fusion” was born—and innovative combinations of materials have remained a key part of the Hublot brand ever since. This extra special piece harks back to Fusion with a glorious skeletonised design that allows for a spectacular view of the ultra-thin movement and its 90-hour power reserve. As ever, the materials are remarkable: there's a stunning titanium case, bezel and screws, a ruthenium anthracite mainplate and bridges, all paired with a fine leather strap.

In watch form, the Carrera has been in existence since 1964, and continued Heuer’s great legacy in providing racing drivers with timing instruments. Named after the intense ‘Carrera Panamericana’ road race of the 1950’s (which also gave its name to the eponymous Porsche), the Carrera continues to provide timing for some of the world’s most prestigious racing teams today. This recent addition to the Carrera fold fully embodies that racing heritage with its lovely, paired-down tribute to vintage timepieces. The watch uses TAG's famous 1887 movement, a smooth column-wheel chronograph that features a modern version of the remarkable oscillating pinion first patented by the brand in 1887.

This technically superlative Ingenieur from IWC features a “double” or “split seconds” chronograph, one of the most difficult and challenging mechanical complications in high-end watchmaking. Where a regular chronograph simply records time elapsed between pushing the start and stop buttons, a split seconds chrono allows you to time laps or intermediate intervals. There are in fact two seconds hands, one of them ingeniously hidden behind the other; an extra pusher at 10 o'clock stops the first hand, recording the initial time, while the other seconds hand continues to run. As well as being mechanically impressive, this Double Chrono is also an imposing wear, with a large titanium case and bezel, five ceramic screws and a rubber-coated crown and pushers—all materials inspired by IWC's partnership with the Mercedes Formula One team.

The Da Vinci collection has been around for over 30 years now and this Da Vinci Perpetual Calendar Digital in platinum showcases the very best of the range. A limited-edition piece of just 500 worldwide, this watch is sure to excite the collectors among us. Featuring hours, minutes, seconds, date-month, chronograph and leap year indicators, it is perfect for those after a practical watch that still delivers on style. Housed inside the IW376106 is a member of the 89000-calibre family, which combines powerful chronograph movements with flyback function that controls the likes of the month display. This timepiece is ideal for avid fans of IWC’s Da Vinci collection and watches that are as functional as they are beautiful.

IWC's Da Vinci collection pays homage to one of the most inventive thinkers of history, the Renaissance Italian genius who was actually one of Europe's earliest mechanical horologists. A number of da Vinci's inventions, while unable to be built during his lifetime, have since been incorporated into mechanical watches. IWC's first Da Vinci timepiece, from the 1960s, showcased some of the most advanced quartz technology ever made at the time. The collection was revived in the 1980s, this time featuring a spectacular mechanical movement with a perpetual calendar designed by the legendary Kurt Klaus. Since then, Da Vinci watches have achieved more world firsts and turned many heads. This beautiful, platinum, retro-flavoured “vintage” edition was inspired by one of the earliest models.

The Royal Oak Offshore, released in 1993, certainly raised eyebrows due to its hefty case size of 42mm, so much so it was quickly nicknamed ‘The Beast’. This special-edition 2007 release of the Alinghi Royal Oak Offshore is limited to 2,007 pieces. Made of platinum and forged carbon, it makes for an interesting redesign of the original Offshore and was created to celebrate the Alinghi sailing team’s victory, after which Audemars Piguet invited representatives of the international press to Valencia to unveil its exciting new creation. Developed with brilliant shock and water resistance and featuring a flyback chronograph function as well as a 10-minute countdown, this timepiece is purpose-built to keep in with the 11-minute race start rule. The dial perfectly echoes the nautical world, with counter hands shaped like the prow of a ship and the Alinghi logo at 3 o’clock. This timepiece is perfect for collectors and fans of watches and sailing alike.

column21: Before the legendary Calibre 360, which made headlines as the first mechanical chronograph movement capable of measuring hundredths of a second, there was the Calibre 36. Equally legendary, in its way, the 36 can count tenths of a second thanks to its super-high frequency of 5Hz (most high-end chronographs beat at 4Hz). This might remind you of another famous chronograph movement, and you'd be right: the Calibre 36 is a modified version of Zenith's El Primero—ironic, considering Heuer and Zenith were competitors in the famous 1969 race to build the first automatic chrono—although this one has been upgraded with additional flyback capability. This gorgeous, cutting-edge Carrera evolves the remarkable Mikrograph design with a silver ring encompassing a gloriously brushed anthracite centre.

This IWC has undergone a thorough inspection of accuracy, functionality and condition at our IWC certified service centre to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been checked against our records to ensure authenticity. All our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind.

Part of the Portugieser family—one of IWC’s flagship models originally released in 1939—the IWC Portuguese Tourbillon Mystere 5042 was later released between 2008 and 2009. This piece features an automatic movement beating at a frequency of 19800 bph, which provides a 168-hour power reserve once fully wound. With a tourbillon escapement at 12 o’clock, and a date display in a stylish arc that reaches from the three to the six on a 31-day indicator, this special limited-edition Portuguese features a white gold case with an ardoise-coloured dial. With only 500 pieces ever made, it is a rarity, perfect for collectors.

Patek Philippe’s Grand Complications collection prides itself on displaying the brand's expertise in all horological complications. This includes tourbillons, grande and petite sonnerie striking mechanisms, minute repeaters, perpetual calendars (this takes account of monthly variations, including those in leap years), moon phases, and split-second chronographs. Patek have even managed to build the world’s most complicated portable timepiece this century on two separate occasions. The 5940 was introduced at Basel World 2012, and originally featured a yellow gold cushion-shaped case. Its self-winding calibre 240 Q movement displays the day, date, month, leap year and 24-hour indication by hands. In 2017 the reference 5940R-001 was added to the collection, featuring an updated rose gold case.

The de Havilland DH-88 Comet was a legendary aircraft known for setting a string of extraordinary records in the 1930s. The plane was built for the famous MacRobertson Air Race from London to Melbourne in 1934 because there were no other British aircraft suitable for entry. Three teams flew DH-88 Comets on the race, and one of them, named Grosvenor House, won it—setting a new record of just under three days, despite the two pilots having to deal with severe exhaustion and mechanical failures. This fantastic limited edition commemorates this remarkable chapter with gorgeous rose gold and steel GMT timepieces that incorporates a fragment of original spruce plywood from the undercarriage of Grosvenor House in the rotor. Proceeds from sales were donated by Bremont to the Shuttleworth Trust to help maintain the aircraft, which continues to give regular displays.

This Panerai has undergone a thorough inspection of accuracy, functionality and condition at our Panerai certified service centre to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been checked against our records to ensure authenticity. All our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind.

It has also been checked against our records to ensure authenticity. All our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind.

Originally an evolution of its early automatics, the IWC Ingenieur was designed to combine the self-winding movement with the shock and magnetic resistance pioneered in some of the brand's pilot's watches. Created by the legendary designer Gerald Genta in the 1970s, the watch was allegedly inspired by a diving helmet, giving Genta the relatively new idea of leaving the functional case elements like screws and bores exposed, instead of hiding them away. This modernist aesthetic was a huge success for IWC, and the Ingenieur has become a horological icon. The same principles are still evident in this stunning “Climate Action” limited edition made in support of The Climate Group, a non-profit campaigning for a low-carbon economy.

This IWC has undergone a thorough inspection of accuracy, functionality and condition at our IWC certified service centre to determine the level of reconditioning required to meet our strict standards. It has also been checked against our records to ensure authenticity. All our watches have a 24-month warranty for your peace of mind.

This gorgeous, cutting-edge Carrera evolves the remarkable Mikrograph design with a silver ring encompassing a gloriously brushed anthracite centre.
